elli
2016-10-03 08:10
Next steps & priorities for cryptology squad: 1. Transition to the next security architecture (a) Security review on the protocol messages for the next consensus architecture FAB 351- all ( @aso , @adc, elli) => Done (b) Creation of protobuffs based on the previous bullet point FAB 489 - @adc (with help from @aso) => In progress (c) Transition the crypto code to the new architecture - @aso => Todo 2. Modular crypto library, with multi CSP support (FAB-355) (a) Definition of the crypto provider interface - @adc , @vpaprots , Tamas => In Progress (b) Software provider - @vpaprots => In Progress (c) Refactoring on the hyperledger code to use that library - @adc => In Progress

has joined #fabric-crypto

kostas
2016-10-03 17:07
has joined #fabric-crypto

silliman
2016-10-03 18:37
has joined #fabric-crypto

jyellick
2016-10-03 19:45
has joined #fabric-crypto

jyellick
2016-10-03 19:56
Hey @elli, just had a long talk with @keithsmith about bootstrapping. Also talked some with @kostas and @simon and there seems to be considerable resistance to using the transaction format as is for configuration changes as it is complicated to produce and consume. Maybe this is my poor understanding of the transaction format, so perhaps you can enlighten me. Still, I would like to see how we can support the use case enumerated in my email a while back. Namely, I would like to create a binary blob (a configuration) and send it to parties for review and approval (endorsement, but no actual execution or execution results), then collect this into a transaction which can clearly (and efficiently) be identified as a 'configuration transaction'. I think that if the fabric transaction format can be generalized to support this simply, that would be ideal. However, it might be simpler just to start from scratch. I think many of the problems which are being solved for the fabric transaction type can be eliminated for the reconfiguration transaction type because there is no need for unlinkability. We could also use a globally unique sequence number or some such to prevent replay, as these configuration changes will always allow for a high degree of orchestration.

simon
2016-10-03 19:56
has joined #fabric-crypto

grapebaba
2016-10-04 00:02
has joined #fabric-crypto

thiruworkspace
2016-10-04 00:04
has joined #fabric-crypto

elli
2016-10-04 09:41
I see, yes we would need to make transaction structure simpler for these cases.

elli
2016-10-04 09:47
Wondering if it would make sense that we have a special type of proposal called {orderer-reconfig}, that contains information on the new configuration (or parts of its) of the ordering service. Endorsement for this would be null. So overall, the client/orderer-service admin, would need to sign a transaction that has one proposalAction, with proposal header (as is now) and with payload this new configuration file. No EndorsedActions henceforth, just the external transaction signature coming from the orderer-service admin (some sort of simplified fabric-client here).

elli
2016-10-04 09:52
The committing peers would need to run some sort of VSCC in this case, that is, make sure that is the defined admin who signed the tx based on the latter configuration, and apply the configuration changes but giving it as input to some sort of reconfig function.

elli
2016-10-04 09:53
Asking @aso, and @adc on this, as we have been discussing a couple of ideas there, also considering re-using our existing chaincode-infrastructure, and endorsement logic. In this case, you would assume system chaincode proposal that is endorsed with the simulation results (reconfigured orderer-system variables) by the administrator node (priviledged) node. ESCC would be naturally a signature from the latter. And VSCC would be signature checking and direct application of system state updates.

simon
2016-10-04 11:07
@elli but orderer reconfig needs a (separate) set of signatures to show authorization

elli
2016-10-04 11:07
correct.

elli
2016-10-04 11:09
meaning that in the case where one implements this reconfig mechanism by reusing our infrastructure" then configuration would include a CA, potentially and an admin certtificate taht should be providing the endorsement throughout ESCC.

elli
2016-10-04 11:10
not sure how this is to run. But assuming that ordering service is separate from the rest of the networks. Shouldnt there be some admin of its? Is it all distributed ?

elli
2016-10-04 11:10
How would i (i = blockchain developer) know who to pay for this service if we assume that this is offered as service.

elli
2016-10-04 11:11
What would the business model be in this case?

simon
2016-10-04 11:11
no idea how the business angle is

simon
2016-10-04 11:11
but last time i talked with binh, the reconfiguration design was:

elli
2016-10-04 11:11
cause this would help much in bootstrapping and designing reconfiguration opearations

simon
2016-10-04 11:11
orderer network requires a multisig for reconfiguration

simon
2016-10-04 11:12
this is entirely independent of the fabric network

elli
2016-10-04 11:12
multisig coming from t out of n orderers?

simon
2016-10-04 11:12
no, from authorized people

elli
2016-10-04 11:12
cool

simon
2016-10-04 11:12
creation of a signed reconfiguration happens offline

simon
2016-10-04 11:13
and the reconfiguration can of course change the multisig required to do the next reconfiguration

elli
2016-10-04 11:13
from reconfiguration request perspective it may not be different if you have one or more signatures required. if they come from the client side (assuming a n off-badn way of producing it).

elli
2016-10-04 11:14
Meaning that the system could treat this request in the same way.

simon
2016-10-04 11:14
i expect the format to be "N out of these following certificates need to sign"

simon
2016-10-04 11:15
of course you could automate the reconfiguration by using some sort of reconfiguration endorsement chaincode

simon
2016-10-04 11:15
but i'd be very careful about this

simon
2016-10-04 11:16
because the security of the chain hinges on the orderer configuration

simon
2016-10-04 11:16
if somebody can reconfigure it at will, the whole network can be taken over

elli
2016-10-04 12:52
well this refers to the case where you trust onen or a few selective endorsers of course

elli
2016-10-04 12:53
otherwise you would still need t out of n endorsers to endorse this ...

elli
2016-10-04 12:54
There needs to be "multisig" when invoking this system chaincode. Now the question is, who should be executing this invocation tx.

elli
2016-10-04 12:56
- option 1: selective priviledged endorsers, that provide endorser signatures (known to orderer infrastructure for endorsing system chainocde invocations) and VSCC does what in our chancdes VSCC does: endorser signature check, certificate validation, version checks, and application of state changes.

elli
2016-10-04 12:57
- option 2: ESCC is not needed, but VSCC does the execution using peers (orderers) current state. Assuming this is a system chaincode, executed after the tx is totally ordered, there may not be serious problems there(?) Wdyt?

elli
2016-10-04 12:57
Again, without considering channels.

cca
2016-10-04 13:02
The answer to the question here depends on how modular one wants to make the "orderers" (providing the consensus service but not state). If a 3rd party lib can be plugged in (i believe some folks are looking at Apache Kafka), this must be independent. If considering a self-built consensus service (for reconfig re-using our infrastructure), it *may* use such support; but it would be more modular to construct it first independently, not assuming such explicit interaction with the blockchain peers and requests. I recommend to keep the two separated, keep in mind the possible link, but only link them later.

simon
2016-10-04 13:05
@elli I don't understand what you're saying

simon
2016-10-04 13:06
i don't think the configuration of the orderer network should be tied to anything in the fabric "network"

elli
2016-10-04 13:06
it should not

elli
2016-10-04 13:06
they have their own CA/certificates etc..

simon
2016-10-04 13:06
reconfiguration requirements are defined as a property of the orderer config

elli
2016-10-04 13:07
but to some extend if orderers are removed, e.g., fabric endorsers should know no?

simon
2016-10-04 13:07
orderer reconfig is authorized towards the fabric network because the orderers sign the batch which contains the reconfig

elli
2016-10-04 13:07
so the client-tx

elli
2016-10-04 13:08
sorry the client-proposal

simon
2016-10-04 13:08

simon
2016-10-04 13:08

simon
2016-10-04 13:08

elli
2016-10-04 13:08

elli
2016-10-04 13:10
Meaning again, it does not have to be chaincode proposal like

elli
2016-10-04 13:10
but it is a form of a proposal. It is some message that upon advertized to the fabric endorser, will cause some internal state to change.

simon
2016-10-04 13:11
not only endorser

elli
2016-10-04 13:11
fabric peer.

simon
2016-10-04 13:11

elli
2016-10-04 13:11

simon
2016-10-04 13:11
so in a way it is a management message originating from the ordering service

elli
2016-10-04 13:12
But what is not clear to me, is the following. Do orderers already have a protocol in place that would enable them to validate reconfiguration messages among them?

simon
2016-10-04 13:12
we don't have code for that yet

simon
2016-10-04 13:13
but essentially a reconfiguration request/message which does not bear the right signatures would be discarded

elli
2016-10-04 13:13
Right. So, since there are many common points (the way is see it) from security perspective with the proposal messaging, and state updates, etc. why cant we reuse what we have

elli
2016-10-04 13:13

simon
2016-10-04 13:13
if it contains the right signatures, it gets ordered and applied after ordering

elli
2016-10-04 13:13

elli
2016-10-04 13:14
So this is option 2

elli
2016-10-04 13:14
(from the list above).

simon
2016-10-04 13:14

simon
2016-10-04 13:15

elli
2016-10-04 13:17
right

elli
2016-10-04 13:18
But, to a large extend this should be hte case for our transactions.

elli
2016-10-04 13:18
As membership service moves to a library.

kostas
2016-10-04 13:26
How would that be the case with membership services moving to a library?

elli
2016-10-04 13:28
What i mean is that membership service code will become a library, for ppl to use it as they wish.

elli
2016-10-04 13:28
Many ppl already have the requirement of adding their own certificates etc.

elli
2016-10-04 13:28
So, we have to face the same problem in transactions.

elli
2016-10-04 13:29
We need to make the structure generic enough to capture potentially different types of certificates than our

elli
2016-10-04 13:29
ECerts/TCerts.

elli
2016-10-04 13:29
transaction/proposal etc meaning.

elli
2016-10-04 13:31
So, for me it does exist some ordering service root CA, and some fabric network root CA.

elli
2016-10-04 13:32
And both networks need to know both of them.

jyellick
2016-10-04 13:32
Perhaps there is some deployment scenario I am not thinking of, but I don't anticipate the orderer service needing a CA

elli
2016-10-04 13:32
(or more than one)

cca
2016-10-04 13:32
For keeping the orderer service modular, it must not know of transactions, only broadcast requests; there will be a special request that triggers its reconfiguration, just like here : http://www.di.fc.ul.pt/~bessani/publications/dsn14-bftsmart.pdf, page 3. From the orderer service, a CA is not strictly needed, a list of identities can be enough.

elli
2016-10-04 13:32
CA or certificates of the peers.

cca
2016-10-04 13:32
certificates = public keys, you mean?

elli
2016-10-04 13:33
right

cca
2016-10-04 13:33
(they are called ceritificates, but they are not really certificates that need an anchor with a CA cert)

cca
2016-10-04 13:33
ok

elli
2016-10-04 13:33

thiruworkspace
2016-10-04 13:53
Hi Elli, In this text "client signature on the trans..", the client signature would be coming from the client SDK right? additionally, do you except both the cert and the sign digest... or does fabric have a public ledger of participants public keys?

elli
2016-10-04 13:55
Hi, so the "client signature on the trans.." refers indeed to the client-sdk produced one, correct.

elli
2016-10-04 13:56
The transaction structure, has already a field in its header referring to a "creator", that should be matching the signature included in the transaction.

elli
2016-10-04 13:56
Where by transaction structure, i refer to the one in the .pdf that Angelo posted :slightly_smiling_face:

elli
2016-10-04 13:57
@elli mentioned a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/adc/F2JKXGXEU/protobufmessagesandflow.pdf.

elli
2016-10-04 13:58
There is no assumption for the certificates being publicly available somewhere, especially cause that certificate could be anonymous. Enrollment certificates could make sense to be publicly available.

elli
2016-10-04 13:59
What is publicly available and inserted in some form in the blockchain, is the root ca that signs peers/clients' certificates.

jyellick
2016-10-04 14:03
@elli Another case I thought of for supporting a secondary transaction format. I am thinking of the case where a group of parties wants to put an assertion on the chain, but actually modifying state does not make sense. For instance, with a side-chain, the participants might want to push a hash onto the main chain, asserting that everyone agrees with the current state of the side-chain. You could of course implement this as a custom chaincode that creates a random key and assigns the hash to it, but that's a little indirect and almost obfuscated. It seems like there are other cases where the transaction is just a group attestation (which has no meaning to anyone not involved)

elli
2016-10-04 14:04
Aha, so you are saying that there may be needs, where ResponsePayload does not need to have extensions.

jyellick
2016-10-04 14:07
Yes, I would argue that ProposalResponsePayload would be empty in these cases

elli
2016-10-04 14:07
no epoch

elli
2016-10-04 14:07
?

jyellick
2016-10-04 14:09
Ah, I guess there is an epoch and hash buried in there, so it would just be the extensions

jyellick
2016-10-04 14:10
Why is the ProposalHash and Epoch in that submessage instead of in the ProposalResponse?

jyellick
2016-10-04 14:10
Oh, I see, because that is what is actually signed

jyellick
2016-10-04 14:11
But it's confusing to me then, that `ProposalResponse.Response` is not included in the signature

simon
2016-10-04 14:55
can we use ASN1 DER for all messages that are referenced by the root hash?

jyellick
2016-10-04 15:12
Root hash? My concern is that these messages must necessarily be allowed to occur later in the chain as well. If we use ASN1 DER, it seems like we need to have an envelope which types the encoding

soldat
2016-10-04 19:14
has joined #fabric-crypto

kostas
2016-10-04 23:59
@elli @cca: Kafka does indeed keep it pluggable here -- they just define an `Authorizer` interface. (They also ship with a basic implementation of it that they call `SimpleAclAuthorizer`.)

kostas
2016-10-05 00:01
When the broker starts up, it constructs the Authorizer object and initializes it with a config. The ACLs are posted in the ZooKeeper ensemble. When the first request comes in, the broker checks its auth cache -- it's empty, so it requests it from ZK and caches it for all subsequent requests.

kostas
2016-10-05 00:02
If you want to dive into more detail, KIP-11 makes for a good starting point: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/KIP-11+-+Authorization+Interface

kostas
2016-10-05 00:04
And this post provides step-by-step directions for hands-on experimentation: http://www.confluent.io/blog/apache-kafka-security-authorization-authentication-encryption/

elli
2016-10-05 06:36
Thanks much @kostas!

kostas
2016-10-05 13:10
You're welcome

vpaprots
2016-10-05 18:01
Question.. TCert derivation algorithm. And HSMs.. does anyone have experience with Safenet? or Thalos? and their custom apis?

vpaprots
2016-10-05 18:02
I've been trying to see how to support HSMs in the fabric.. thats one piece that is not PKCS11-pluggable.. ideas how you would implement it with your favorite HSMs?

vpaprots

cbf

troyronda
2016-10-05 22:01
@vpaprots yes - have the functionality that is outside of the normal PKCS11 to be pluggable for each HSM vendor and have as much as possible go to the HSM vendors normal PKSCS11 library (e.g., ECerts).

thiruworkspace
2016-10-05 23:48
just to clarify it could be root and other intermediate certs as well right?

thiruworkspace
2016-10-05 23:54
@elli additionally, can we also publish the CRL certs in the blockchain?

adc
2016-10-06 06:26
@jyellick, regarding your question on why `ProposalResponse.Response` is not included in the signature, the answer is that at the message level we care to put signatures on what will end up in the ledger and ProposalResponse.Response will not go to the ledger. The hidden assumption is that TLS is running and that protests ProposalResponse.Response. But I will give to is a second thought :slightly_smiling_face:

adc
2016-10-06 06:30
@jyellick, regarding the other transaction format, I guess you refer to the assertion type. In this case, would ProposalResponsePayload.extension contain the assertion itself? Does the assertion need an endorsement? If a group of endorsers (from a subledger) wants to assert something on the main ledger, probably they don't want to reveal that the assertion is coming from a certain subledger but at the same time there must be a way for the committing peer to validate this assertion, no?

elli
2016-10-06 06:56
https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/archives/fabric-crypto/p1475735182000170

elli
2016-10-06 06:57
@adc, @jyellick: we may want to change name on this field, cause indeed ProposalResponse.Response would make people think this piece as the core part of the response :slightly_smiling_face:

adc
2016-10-06 06:58
make sense

elli
2016-10-06 07:03
@thiruworkspace : Right. Especially for the peer (endorser) certificates it would make sense to announce the whitelist or the blacklist of certificates through the blockchain. This would prevent committing peers coming to different conclusions w.r.t. a specific endorser certificate (providing a signature in the transaction) is invalid.

elli
2016-10-06 07:07
For user-certificates, one could follow the same path, though in this case the responsibility of checking the certificate validity of the user may be passed to the endorsers of the chaincode that user tries to invoke, and not checked for validity at the committing peer side. The latter is something that @vukolic proposed. That would work as long as we do not have the requirement to support transactions whose execution/validity takes place at the committing peer side entirely.

stevenroose
2016-10-06 07:28
has joined #fabric-crypto

elli
2016-10-06 07:39
Just created another channel to discuss these protobufs, called fabric-next-proto.

garisingh
2016-10-06 07:39
has joined #fabric-crypto

adc
2016-10-06 08:43
@kostas, thanks for the links about kafka authorization. Is it already in the plan to support kafka in the fabric? In order for the consensus to be pluggable we would need a way to generalize access control at the fabric, right?

thiruworkspace
2016-10-06 11:11
:+1: .. would this be included within any existing JIRA?

elli
2016-10-06 11:21
Hm, I believe https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-116 should cover this, though it does not clarify a CRL. @keithsmith would know.

kostas
2016-10-06 13:08
@adc: It is not, and I don't think it will be any time soon. The Kafka option is there to (a) test whether we're building the orderer plugins in a modular way, and (b) have a point of reference when it comes to block throughput and latency. https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-32

adc
2016-10-06 13:10
got it, thanks. Anyway, we need to design an api that allows to specify the credentials at the consensus client side

adc
2016-10-06 13:10
And it should be generic enough too.

adc
2016-10-06 13:11
We might take as point of reference KAFKA for this

kostas
2016-10-06 13:11
Agreed, that was my thinking anyway.

adc
2016-10-06 13:24
good!

mart0nix
2016-10-07 13:42

mart0nix
2016-10-07 13:42
hello

mart0nix
2016-10-07 13:43
sharing some feedback about our business application requirements in terms of auditing

mart0nix
2016-10-07 13:43
We currently envision the following roles Lead Auditor Auditor Regulator/Law Enforcement Lead Regulator/Law Enforcement Agent Supply-Chain Member Lead Supply-Chain Member General Agent Supply-Chain Member Limited Agent the leads will create delegate roles (agents) I found that the fabric supports delegate roles which I think it's a great idea I wasn't clear if the current delegation feature works on system-level roles (admin, client, auditor) or it could also work on user-defined roles

tim.s
2016-10-07 14:45
has joined #fabric-crypto

elli
2016-10-10 07:20
Hi, @mart0nix, thanks!

elli
2016-10-10 07:22
So far the attributes/roles specified in the fabric TCerts of a user who is in possession of an attribute/role, are managed/certified by the membership service.

elli
2016-10-10 07:23
But it is true that the notion of "registrar" exists, where "registrar" is an entity that can register other users into the membership service.

elli
2016-10-10 07:26
@thiruworkspace : So for the membership services API, this is to be accommodated via this jira item https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-389

elli
2016-10-10 07:30
With the endorsing peers validation APIs and process are related the following jira items: https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-40, https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-397. For validation of their endorsements (signature validation if endorsement is only a signature) the membership services APIs (in FAB-389) should cover this. @jyellick , @muralisr to confirm :slightly_smiling_face:

thiruworkspace
2016-10-10 16:02
Thanks @elli

weeds
2016-10-10 16:14
Keith Smith posted high level google document -CFSSL. The only thing we will do uniquely is TCERT generation and we would use CFSSL for ECERT generation. Elli said they were going to look to see if the API on the same or wrapper they can use. They need some modularity of crypto and all the fabric can go through that so if some company or 3rd party- they can substitute their implementation - they can substitute the lever itself-- that way they can do it easily and not managing fabric code deeper. Elli wants to check to see if CFSSL can do that--> this is for version 1.0

weeds
2016-10-10 16:16
PKCS11 is something that is supported from HSM.

weeds
2016-10-10 16:17
The question is where does this API sit in terms of CFSSL for HSM support? WE are not concerned that HSM is not possible with CFSSL- concerned if the interface that CFSSL crypto library is compatible with the Hyperledger crypto interface, and we need to make sure there are no conflicts.

weeds
2016-10-10 16:18
Keith and Elli said they may take a look tomorrow and post on slack to see what's in the CFSSL code

weeds
2016-10-10 16:22
Key lifecycle is being worked- generate key, derive key and sign/verify capabilities methods, and one of the goals is to plug in their own. Angelo has been working on this for bccsp. Angelo wants to try to post slides to get feedback as this is recent items he's been working on.

weeds
2016-10-10 16:25
BCCSP is the blockchain cryptographic service provider that offers the implementation of cryptographic standards and algorithims. This covers key lifecycle, sign/verify operation, and encrypt/decrypt operation. Genkey, derivekey, getkey, importkey, sign, verify, encrypt, decrypt are the different type of BCCSP interfaces he's working. He tried to submit this in the implementation in his PR today.

weeds
2016-10-10 16:27
what is the difference between getkey/importkey relative to SKI?-- SKI is subject key identifier- when you want to address key on HSM, you need to have SKI -unique key in HSM. For example, Your enrollment key of endorser will come with an SKI- this way it does not leak any information of the key.

weeds
2016-10-10 16:28
There is typekey interface- key represents a key. it can be a symmetric or assymetric. In case of an asymmetric key, the key can be public or private. in case of private assymetric, the publickey() method allows to retrieve the corresponding public-key. A key can be referenced via the subject key identifier (getSKI)

weeds
2016-10-10 16:31
There are 5- fabric crypto provide submissions- starting with 1605 (which is under code review)

weeds
2016-10-10 16:38
Angelo plans to post a set of carts talking about the BCCSP

garisingh
2016-10-10 16:39
``` The question is where does this API sit in terms of CFSSL for HSM support? WE are not concerned that HSM is not possible with CFSSL- concerned if the interface that CFSSL crypto library is compatible with the Hyperledger crypto interface, and we need to make sure there are no conflicts. ``` this statement confuses me. CFSSL is simply a mechanism to request signed certificates. On the client side, it can generate the equivalent of a CSR and on its "server" side (also via command line) it can issue signed X509 certificates. It includes an interface for plugging in PCKS11 libraries. You can actually check out the code from letsencrypt where they actually provide a concrete implementation of a PKCS11 provider

weeds
2016-10-10 16:42
One area that help could be used for community how to plug in CSP for China, etc,..

elli
2016-10-10 17:58
@garisingh: BCCSP (Blockchain crypto service provider) aimed to offer an low-level interface to do key-generation/sign/verify signature and encrypt/decrypt using certain algorithms. Thus the question came up (by @keithsmith) if the interface of crypto library used within CFSSL is compatible with the one of BCCSP. That is if we could use BCCSP as a single crypto library / dependency in the system.

hart.montgomery
2016-10-10 18:34
has joined #fabric-crypto

garisingh
2016-10-10 18:55
Thanks @elli. most of cfssl is a wrapper around go crypto anyway. But I don't see why it would be an issue

elli
2016-10-10 18:56
Aha, ok. So, we could implement our wrapper around our crypto library?

elli
2016-10-10 18:56
Just a question of whether we could make cfssl "refer" to our crypto lib

garisingh
2016-10-10 19:27
cfssl is really just a library for certificate authority activities. So not sure we would even need to go that far? we should just leverage it to perform PKI CA functions?

keithsmith
2016-10-10 19:30
so are you saying that we should or shouldnt use cfssl apis to generate an ecert?

garisingh
2016-10-10 19:40
we should

keithsmith
2016-10-10 19:41
so we would need to somehow plugin the bccsp apis underneath the cfssl api to generate the ecert it seems

keithsmith
2016-10-10 19:42
am I missing something?

garisingh
2016-10-10 19:48
why underneath?

garisingh
2016-10-10 19:49
what's so special about an eCert?

garisingh
2016-10-10 19:50
it's an ECC private key and then request a signed X509 public key

garisingh
2016-10-10 19:55
on the other hand, you don't have to use cfssl to generate the private key (and thus the public key) at all

keithsmith
2016-10-10 19:58
I was looking at using the following cfssl api to gen the root cert for example. If we use this, then the private key is created underneath this api

keithsmith
2016-10-10 19:58
cfssl gencert -initca CSRJSON

keithsmith
2016-10-10 20:00
Im trying to find which APIs I could call which would allow me to gen my own private key and pass it in

garisingh
2016-10-10 20:02
ah - that's on the CA side

garisingh
2016-10-10 20:02
which I would see ZERO use for bccsp

garisingh
2016-10-10 20:02
I though you were talking about a client who want to get an eCert?

keithsmith
2016-10-10 20:03
no, they were talking about plugging the bccsp apis into membersrvc in v0.6

adrianhopebailie
2016-10-10 20:03
has joined #fabric-crypto

keithsmith
2016-10-10 20:04
so i started wondering how this would work in v1 when using cfssl in a cop server

garisingh
2016-10-10 20:04
in a cop server I don't think you use bccsp at all

garisingh
2016-10-10 20:06
well - I'll take that back - it depends on the APIs you present form the server - I see you are still looking at using grpc-based external API for cop server in v1?

keithsmith
2016-10-10 20:07
i take by your asking that you think we should stick with REST?

keithsmith
2016-10-10 20:07
we arent far down that path

garisingh
2016-10-10 20:08
I think REST / HTTP would be easier for clients to integrate with - for example a mobile device which wants to enroll.

garisingh
2016-10-10 20:09
seems like cfssl had a decent set of REST/HTTP APIs and actually just recently added some type of auth endpoint as well?

keithsmith
2016-10-10 20:11
i havent seen the auth endpoint, but ill look again anyway, I wasnt sure if mixing REST for cop and GRPC only for peer was preferable, but certainly makes it easier though maybe more work for SDKs

garisingh
2016-10-10 20:14
most other CAs will have HTTP-based endpoints as well - e.g. any SCEP-based CA. So reality is there will always be a mix of HTTP and GRPC when pulling in different CAs. I am not opposed to GRPC for COP either. But if we can leverage as much of CFSSL as possible should save some time. Of course you could probably look at possibly replacing the CFSSL API server with the GRPC APIs as well. I briefly checked that our yesterday but not in enough depth to actually see how feasible it would be

keithsmith
2016-10-10 20:16
ok well support REST 1st and only add GRPC if/when needed

keithsmith
2016-10-10 20:18
I just git pulled and dont see the auth endpoint but will look deeper. That actually was the other reason I was going for GRPC, because it wasnt clear how intrusive it would be to add security to the existing endpoints

garisingh
2016-10-10 20:23
in the docs section of cfssl there was something about authentication

keithsmith
2016-10-10 20:31
yes, see it thx

adc
2016-10-11 08:41
@garisingh, @keithsmith, @lli: if I got it correctly, CFSSL exposes an interface called signer.Signer that can be used to plug different signing capabilities. So, if we really want, we can potentially put our BCCSP there.

adc
2016-10-11 08:42
I'm also trying to understand how HSM is integrated in CFSSL but I'm struggling in setting it up using SoftHSM. Any idea?

garisingh
2016-10-11 09:11
here's a link to see work that the LetsEncrypt team did - https://github.com/letsencrypt/pkcs11key

adc
2016-10-11 09:21
Yes, yes. So, essentially in CFSSL one creates a new local signer (local.NewSigner) and passes a crypto.Signer. Then, letsencrypt provides the PKCS11-based crypto.Signer

adc
2016-10-11 09:21
super easy

adc
2016-10-11 09:21
actually, we have to do the same in fabric

adc
2016-10-11 09:21
we need a BCCSP-based crypto.Signer in order to sign TCert and ECert

adc
2016-10-11 09:22
so the BCCSP can be integrated in CFSSL easily

adc
2016-10-11 09:22
if needed at all

pospi
2016-10-13 02:24

adc
2016-10-13 07:41
Hi @pospi, what do you want to achieve exactly?

pospi
2016-10-13 08:31
we're thinking about resource authorization- say there is an asset stored in an S3 bucket or Dropbox folder that party A owns and wants to provide to party B- so A requests release of the asset and B accepts to recieve the authorization URL. That would be the simplest version but there may be times when multiple entities are signatories to party A

adc
2016-10-13 08:36
That sounds as and endorsement process. A would send a proposal to transfer the asset and this proposal has to be endorsed by B plus all (or a threshould of) signatories to party A. How does this sound to you?

garisingh
2016-10-13 08:37

garisingh

ryokawawork
2016-10-18 01:29
has joined #fabric-crypto

ryokawawork
2016-10-18 01:44
Hi, is there any documentation for the specification of encryption of the transactions and the world state (KVS)? I am asking this because it is often required to encrypt databases in the financial industry. And also I am thinking about using the history of the transactions for auditing, where decryption of the transaction payloads is required.

ryokawawork
2016-10-18 01:48
According to the source codes (fabric/sdk/node/src/hfc.ts, and fabric/core/crypto/validator_state.go), the payload of a invoke transaction is encrypted by a one-time public key, its private key is encrypted by the chain key, and transferred to a peer using toValidator field of a transaction.

ryokawawork
2016-10-18 01:51
A value of the world state is encrypted by State Key, which is derived from the Chain Key and used fro decryption of return values of query transactions. Keys (of KVS) are not encrypted. The Chain Key is common to all the members and is a symmetric key.

ryokawawork
2016-10-18 01:54
Am I understanding the spec correctly? I am also reading Protocol Spec, but bit confused. I suppose this document includes future plans, or parts which is not up-to-date... http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/protocol-spec/#4-security_1

ryokawawork
2016-10-18 01:55
I am now using Fabric v0.6.0-preview.

adc
2016-10-18 06:50
@garisingh, understandable. Luckily that code can be reused in v1 easily

adc
2016-10-18 06:56
@ryokawawork, you are mostly correct. regarding transactions, let me clarify that the chain key is public-key whose associated secret key is distributed to all the validators at enrollment time. For the state, there is a root state key that is specified in the deploy transaction. From this key, the code derives the keys and the IVs. The chain (secret) key is involved in this process only to extract the root state key from the deploy transaction

adc
2016-10-18 06:58
@weeds, just to clarify, Alessandro will work on the implementation on client SDK at endorsing/committing peers to perform signature and verification of signatures for Version 1.0. Elli, will submit slides on channel bootstrapping asap. Thanks :slightly_smiling_face:

ryokawawork
2016-10-18 07:24
@adc Thank you! I had misunderstood the chain key. The chain key is not a symmetric key but a public key used by members and the associated private key is used by validators to decode the transaction. And also thanks about explaining the root state key.

adc
2016-10-18 07:24
sure :slightly_smiling_face:

mart0nix
2016-10-18 08:04
can this information regarding the various keys and how they are used together become part of a Wiki

aso
2016-10-18 15:36
Hi all, today I did some preliminary work to take on FAB-580 as soon as we settle on the core of the next architecture

weeds
2016-10-18 16:25
i thought I would share some information that Elli shared with me that might be helpful

weeds
2016-10-18 16:25
Work items associated with fabric-CSP (BC-CSP), i.e., FAB-354, FAB-355, FAB-615 has been completed from our side (Angelo) and is now on Gerrit under review. In fact 11 changesets have been submitted there (as listed below): https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1605/1 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1641/2 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1645/2 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1647/2 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1653/2 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1683/2 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1689/2 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1691/2 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1693/2 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1695/2 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1813/2

weeds
2016-10-18 16:27
Work items progressing associated to protocol buffers and associated security checks for next architecture, i.e., FAB-351 (including FAB-489, FAB580-582): Protocol buffers have long been discussed on the channels.

weeds
2016-10-18 16:27
Work items associated to Channel access control management(FAB-633). The team has prepared a first draft of a design for secure creation and consulting of ACL for channels. We are taking rounds into updating the design, and plan to share it with extended team and community to get input once we get a good draft finished

jonathanlevi
2016-10-18 16:36
@weeds (et al.), thanks for sharing. All, 1) Feel free to add me as a reviewer when you submit such items. 2) These are very well structured. Cant miss that! 3) Noted that these were (originally) submitted as part of the `v0.6` branch, but at some point before the release, we chose to hold back so that we could get the v0.6.1 release tagged/published last weekend. How do we want to merge these/whats the strategy/schedule? That is, do we want these on a(nother) separate branch? I dont have a strong opinion either way, just let me know what makes the most sense to everyone I believe we are done with the v0.6 branch as of last Sunday - but let me know.

2016-10-21 09:24

adc
2016-10-21 09:57
Everything under the bccsp package can be merged easily. It has only dependencies onto the primitives package which has not been modified. After that, I can re-apply the refactoring to have all the other components using the BCCSP. How this sounds?

garisingh
2016-10-21 10:01
this sounds about right. not exactly sure what you mean by `re-apply the refactoring to have all the other components using the BCCSP`? My assertion would be that at this point there actually is no crypto in use for the new peer / endorser code. For example, assuming the BCCSP is integrated into the src tree (as we are discussing), next step for example would be to have the peer code (default ESCC and VSCC) leverage BCCSP for signing and verification.

garisingh
2016-10-21 10:02

adc
2016-10-21 10:04

garisingh
2016-10-21 10:07

garisingh
2016-10-21 10:08

garisingh
2016-10-21 10:09

jonathanlevi
2016-10-21 14:11
@weeds Yes, this makes sense (to "jump on" the latest). @garisingh, @adc : OK, then lets resubmit these against `master`. Sounds good. Probably after the `v0.6` > `master` work is done and possibly the `convergence` though after taking a quick look at it, I dont expect conflicts as the above items are mostly new.

adc
2016-10-21 14:19
right

elli
2016-10-21 15:27
Makes sense.

elli
2016-10-21 15:29
Though transaction/proposal processing components on the peer/client side may make sense to call membership service interface rather than directly crypto CSP calls. Of course the transition to such calls should not be difficult to be done later.

garisingh
2016-10-21 15:32
@elli - you aren't saying that at runtime the peer would ever need to call out to membership services are you? For the client - yes - it would call membership services directly

elli
2016-10-21 15:33
correct. I am not saying that. I am saying that the peer/client would need to invoke the membership service library function to validate a a certain authenticated messsage (e.g., a message signed with a secret corresponding to a certificate).

elli
2016-10-21 15:35
So, in a way, if we are to make memberhsip service pluggable, we would need to specify APIs for peer/client to use for message authentication (signature or other means that that membership service has/adopts) and authenticated message validation (signature verification or other mechanisms that that membership service considers)

jonathanlevi
2016-10-21 15:35
Whats to `validate a signature produced by a certificate` ?

elli
2016-10-21 15:37
my bad, corrected :slightly_smiling_face:

jonathanlevi
2016-10-21 15:37
Oh, OK. To validate `with a certificate`.

jonathanlevi
2016-10-21 15:38
Sure, yes. Especially as the extensions are not standard.

elli
2016-10-21 15:38
So membership service A has standard x509 certificates and for authentication uses ECDSA key-pairs.

jonathanlevi
2016-10-21 15:38
(they are standard X509, but require logic)

elli
2016-10-21 15:38
Membership service B has idemix certificates (not x509 based) and for authentication uses RSA keys and signature of knowledge.

elli
2016-10-21 15:39
The interface of membership service as used in the core should be done in such a way, that membership service A and B can implement that interface and plugged into the peer/client code without affecting the transaction processing components of the system.

elli
2016-10-21 15:42
@garisingh , @jonathanlevi does this make sense?

elli
2016-10-21 15:42
Something we already discussed with @keithsmith, @adc, and we actually have some preliminary form of this (generic) interface.

jonathanlevi
2016-10-21 15:43
Yes, it does. Much better to have the logic encapsulated within Membership Services (that will call the underlying crypto) than require the logic in the client, using the (probably too low-level for the client) crypto CSP.

elli
2016-10-21 15:43
correct!

jonathanlevi
2016-10-21 15:44
It will be a lot easier to validate/test/extend and componentize using the external API that will allow us to have the logic in one place (and just share, rather than duplicate).

jonathanlevi
2016-10-21 15:45
[That is, I agree - this makes sense]

jonathanlevi
2016-10-21 15:45
We should probably work out a few sequence/entity-interaction diagrams at some point, at least at the higher level, to make sure that everyone is on the same page.

jonathanlevi
2016-10-21 15:47
But for now, it makes sense to expose the crypto to only one layer (above it) to consume especially while it is in the making"

garisingh
2016-10-21 15:50
ah - I see - you were talking about the "client" piece of membership services. I just want to make sure that at runtime there is no need to call out to membership services server

garisingh
2016-10-21 15:50
:wink:

garisingh
2016-10-21 15:52
I want to be able to provide my own crypto material if I want to :wink:

jonathanlevi
2016-10-21 15:52
Yes, these really need to be separate! We dont want a chrome browser that needs to call the server for `internal` logic implementation.

donovanhide
2016-10-21 19:02
has joined #fabric-crypto

jzhang
2016-10-21 19:55
has joined #fabric-crypto

muralisr
2016-10-21 19:55
https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/archives/fabric-dev/p1477079668002159

muralisr
2016-10-21 19:57
This is w.r.t encryption/decryption in app/SDK. assume this is now handled by the application level, ie app/SDK <> chaincode ?

jzhang
2016-10-21 20:03
thanks @muralisr. @elli @adc @aso this question came about when I was wondering how the SDKs endorse API would support confidentiality. would we continue to use pkChain returned from ECertCreateResp, or should we expose the payload to give the application developer a chance to encrypt it however they want (using a PKI b/w app and endorser nodes)

msoumeit
2016-10-22 05:09
has joined #fabric-crypto

jzhang
2016-10-24 14:00
@elli @adc @aso have you guys seen my question about re: pkChain from enrollment?

elli
2016-10-24 14:02
Hi; sorry. So, as of now we are focusing on having fabric work without it supporting confidentiality mechanisms on the fabric side.

adc
2016-10-24 14:02
Hi @jzhang, the latter I would say.

elli
2016-10-24 14:03
That said, confidentiality mechanisms would be shifted to the application layer, and may make sense to be based on endorser long term encryption keys and proper use of transient-data field of the proposal.

elli
2016-10-24 14:04
Of course we can also have pkChain be distributed by the membership services, but that would need to be on a per-channel basis and not sure for the first release of this code would make sense.

elli
2016-10-24 14:08
Also one could use externally decided keys... key-management would be (in my view) on the application.

garisingh
2016-10-24 14:09
@elli @jzhang @keithsmith - IMHO "fabric-cop" (at least the server portion) should no longer be handing out encryption keys. My take is that the crypto libs will need to be able to generate and wrap keys as required and we'll likely need to leverage a distribution mechanism within fabric (similar to some work @adc already did) to "share" keys as appropriate

adc
2016-10-24 14:09
this is definitely the high level direction, I would say

adc
2016-10-24 14:10
I agree

elli
2016-10-24 14:14
So, i agree that pkChain should not be generated/managed/distributed by the membership service. But do we also want to not have membership service engage to the enrollment certificate including public encryption keys of peers/clients? If so, then we would need to assume that there is some offline-interaction among applications, that leverage their signing keys (reflected in their ECerts) to announce public encryption keys of users. Auditability becomes slightly more complex there, but it is simple enough to work.

garisingh
2016-10-24 14:16
@elli - I guess I will put it this way - we need to make sure that there is no dependency on membership services for these things

jzhang
2016-10-24 14:16
so do i understand this flow correctly like this: app/sdk encrypts using each endorser certificate > endorser received and decrypts using its individual private key > execute > encrypts result using app/sdk certificate > app/sdk receives and decrypts, package up and encrypts using committer certificate > send to orderer > delivers to commiter > committer decrypts and applies the changes

jzhang
2016-10-24 14:18
as far as where encryption/decryption happens with what keys, is the above accurate or am I off?

jzhang
2016-10-24 14:19
thats assuming we dont have a chain-wide (or channel-wide) key like pkChain today any longer

elli
2016-10-24 14:19
@garisingh, what do you mean by dependency? pkChain, or pkEndorser (public enecyrption key that is generated exactly like the signing key and included currently in enrollment certificate)?

elli
2016-10-24 14:22
Cause, to do any type of key-distribution, there has to be some anker of trust (e.g., exchanged enrollment certificates that contain signature key-pairs) to have the application do the encrytpion key generation etc.

garisingh
2016-10-24 14:22
meaning a peer node should never need to call out to membership services at runtime and if I choose to use my own certificate authority I should be able to do that

garisingh
2016-10-24 14:22
sure - but that can be any trusted root authority that the members of the blockchain choose to support

elli
2016-10-24 14:23
agreed

elli
2016-10-24 14:24
there should be no dependency on the specifics of the membership service currently available in fabric, but (at least in my mind) it could have some dependency on the membership service as an entity / component of the system (assuming that this component is expressed via the membership service interface).

elli
2016-10-24 14:25
@garisingh, am I capturing the (non-)dependency requirement correctly?

elli
2016-10-24 14:27
@jzhang: the specification of a flow provided by a confidentiality library is part of the FAB-830

adc
2016-10-24 14:30
@jzhang, interesting. That's definitely a possible flow. Multiple details are hidden here and there but it looks reasonable as a very high level overview of a candidate message flow

elli
2016-10-24 14:30
But overall, I would see two levels of a confidentiality library to be plugged in: (i)at the application/chaincode level where keys would need to be part of the transient data of proposal, that are passed to the chaincode at execution time (the chaincode here is supposed to know/understand how to use these keys to encrypt its state), (ii) at the ESCC level and assuming extension of the interface of the client to the endorser.

elli
2016-10-24 14:31
Option (ii) is closer to what you describe @jzhang, but option (i) is easier to implement.

jzhang
2016-10-24 14:31
ok, ill take a look at FAB-830

jzhang
2016-10-24 14:31
are we currently leaning one way or another?

garisingh
2016-10-24 14:32
I think I'd agree. If I am a bit more explicit, from the peer perspective, a peer should NEVER have to call out to membership services like it does today (e.g. for the register/enroll, to pull down public keys, encryption keys, etc). I would also say should hold true for the ordering service and I would also say for the client SDKs as well. Per @elli , one way to do this would be to have an interface and one of the implementations could be to call remotely and one could be to use locally available material. We'll need to work through this especially as fabric-cop developes

elli
2016-10-24 14:35
Agreed. Btw, added https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-829 and some tentative description of a membership service interface/component as discussed with @keithsmith, @adc, @aso already from June.

adc
2016-10-24 14:35
having the client SDK not connecting to the fabric-cop for TCerts is challenging at the current stage

garisingh
2016-10-24 14:36
yes - tcerts I agree with

garisingh
2016-10-24 14:36
but not everyone needs them

elli
2016-10-24 14:37
Hm, but also TCerts can be generically defined.

garisingh
2016-10-24 14:37
true

garisingh
2016-10-24 14:37
with option 2/2.1

adc
2016-10-24 14:37
they should be generically defined

elli
2016-10-24 14:37
And thus their form not to depend on the exact implementation of membership service.

garisingh
2016-10-24 14:37
did we ever decide on that? seems we are the only people who talk about it

adc
2016-10-24 14:38
like it is already in 0.5, the crypto package has a CertificateHandler that can handle ECert, TCerts and so on

elli
2016-10-24 14:38
We have been discussing the interface (as a starting point) defined in https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-829 with @keithsmith. I know that Keith had some first version of it at some point, but maybe without considering generic representation of TCerts.

garisingh
2016-10-24 14:40
so Keith and team have been working to extract the current TCert implemention and make it into a library but have not changed how we generate them at this point

elli
2016-10-24 14:40
Ah sorry, you meant the TCert key-generation process.

elli
2016-10-24 14:41
I thought you referred to have a generic TCert interface enabled. Sorry, it take it back then. True, not sure if we have converged on this and when/if we should start implementing it.

elli
2016-10-24 14:42
Related discussion is here https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-635

keithsmith
2016-10-24 15:35
correct, Ash should push the current impl later today, and the plan is to do version 2 of your doc as a configurable option

weeds
2016-10-24 15:47
Ad hoc meeting with Keith Smith, Gari Singh, Elli- Fabric 829 , next sprint-- this is an interface tat describes membership services component. It has to be defined so that if someone has a different version of membership services, they can write connectors so they can leverage everything implemented. This is an interface into ms into transaction processing and ledger infrastructure. This interface would be used to encourage our bscsp. An application developer that just uses membership services instance- they don't need to know what interface we should use .

weeds
2016-10-24 15:50
On Jira boards- there are 3 groups for next two weeks 1) implementation of blockchain crypto service provider and integration to fabric--- one has to be done in golang and nodejs part that gets used by the client. A large part of golang has been implemented and submitted in 11 changes into branch 0.6 but has to be rebased into master. Items associated with bscsp to server code he tried to build some classes that cfssl can look at bscsp code without problem.

weeds
2016-10-24 15:51
BSCSP is good for abstracting a single one. Keith was looking at what Jason Yellick has done in signature validation-- Gari said that looks like it is higher level.

weeds
2016-10-24 15:52
We need to define who the consumers of that library is done. You can have simple thing in peer- endorsement chaincode- simple sign code (Murali could take this for endorser). There also might be a higher level abstraction that reads policy like Jason looks to have implemented, but it would ultimately call the verify function.

weeds
2016-10-24 15:54
Elli- from the abstraction and using the bccsp- in fab 829, we are working towards implementing nodejs client sdk and need to converge the genericf interace and run it with membership services. There is dependency on this with the 2nd group of issues highlighted for next spring- validation of transactions on commiting side, validation of security proposal at the endorser side... all of these should be using abstract interface. We need to specify that interface

weeds
2016-10-24 15:56
This is for the sdk level as well as the touch point within the peer.

weeds
2016-10-24 16:01
Example- they use x509 and use extension filled for certs to store additional data . The extension filled that the current fabric can understand.This transaction cert is acquired using some interaction with client with server side,.. the client will need to create transactions creating keys. The peer code would have to pass the code at membership services... Let's say someone comes and say I need to use not your fabric defined membership services, but want to use a different Membership services plugin. I do not want to rewrite the transaction processing code- I would need to plugin my code implementing the same interface as fabric code and allow transaction processing to issue signatures on behalf the cert structure that that other instance of membership services-- and peer code validating those sigs .

weeds
2016-10-24 16:02
It does not separate the cert infrastructure and the way that another membership services are used by transaction processing component. These have to be separated using an interface and needs to be generic enough.

weeds
2016-10-24 16:02
Something like here is the cert and verify it--- Fab 829 has some ideas on this.

weeds
2016-10-24 16:05
Binh- what is fabric client? code of membership service that could be useful for the client.(we need to complete by Wednesday to try to help get first draft of SDK spec for Friday) ...the peer donates the part of the membership service that could be useful for the peer... Binh suggesting a GRPC definition or somekind of document that we can make specification of SDK on that design doc, and we can post the document on googledocs

weeds
2016-10-24 16:13
Today in Nodejs sdk- there is membersip servcies impl... this interface was not generic enough (from memory)- it did not specify type for certificate and would not be able to parse appropriately and provide ability to say whether generic or not. Elli said she has to look into detail- felt it did not have attributes included. Keith did mention there is an interface with Tcerts with attributes. Keith suggesting her to review to make recommendation on what we need in addition in this area.

weeds
2016-10-24 16:15
We are trying to do ACL design for events and chaincodes for multichannel (fab 637, 634, and 633)

satheesh
2016-10-24 21:32
has joined #fabric-crypto

jyellick
2016-10-25 14:48
@elli I'd like to talk with you about ACLs and signature formats when it is convenient

elli
2016-10-25 14:49
Hi, sure

elli
2016-10-25 14:49
Finishing up with @adc. @aso the membership service abstract interface. Then can ping you.

jyellick
2016-10-25 14:49
Great, thanks!

adc
2016-10-25 14:52
@jyellick, actually, a nice sanity check would be to check that the membership services API fits well with your policy framework

garisingh
2016-10-25 14:53
do you implement "verify" :wink:

adc
2016-10-25 14:53
The idea is that once is time to verify signature, the call is redirected to the membership service that is able to handle multiple schemes, potentially

adc
2016-10-25 14:53
yeah, at the end, it is a verify

jyellick
2016-10-25 14:57
All signature verification will require a network call to membership services? This sounds problematic to me

adc
2016-10-25 14:58
no no, sorry

adc
2016-10-25 14:58
verify a signature will not require a remote call

adc
2016-10-25 14:59
but verify a signature is something related to an identity

adc
2016-10-25 14:59
that's the reason why we associated it to the membership services

adc
2016-10-25 15:00
there will a Verify method that will do what is necessary to verify a signature, locally in most of the cases

jyellick
2016-10-25 15:02
Now I think I am lost again. If a signature is representative of agreement from X, then it should have a chain of trust which derives from X, why do we need member services to tell us this?

adc
2016-10-25 15:03
my fault, sorry. Membership services will give us the algorithms to check that chain of trust, for example

adc
2016-10-25 15:04
why this? Because we might have different ways to enforce different chains of trust depending on the way identities are managed in the network

jyellick
2016-10-25 15:05
So is the algorithm something that's retrieved once, and then applied many times? I'm trying to think of a signature check which would not be tied to identity

adc
2016-10-25 15:05
correct

adc
2016-10-25 15:06
an example being an ECDSA signature that is verified against the verification key in a x509 certificate

garisingh
2016-10-25 15:06
we need to think about this. I still want to have ZERO dependency on having to call to a remote server for use of crypto stuff.

adc
2016-10-25 15:06
no remote calls

adc
2016-10-25 15:07
just Verify algorithms

garisingh
2016-10-25 15:07
ok - so we can set the the "parameters" (hash, key length, algorithm, etc) directly from within the code which consumes the component?

adc
2016-10-25 15:08
right

garisingh
2016-10-25 15:08
cool!!!

adc
2016-10-25 15:08
a parallel can be drawn with the BCCSP

garisingh
2016-10-25 15:08
just wanted to make sure

adc
2016-10-25 15:08
we will have something that is higher level than BCCSP that exposes a more generalized way to handle signatures, their verification and generation

garisingh
2016-10-25 15:10
yep - makes sense. I just wanted to make sure that peers, ordering service, etc did not have to call out to a server to get the crypto policy (so I assume similar settings to what we have in core.yaml today?)

adc
2016-10-25 15:11
it can go there but it can also go to the VSCC or ESCC

garisingh
2016-10-25 15:12
sure - I just meant that the peer today gets its config locally. We are on the same page :wink:

adc
2016-10-25 15:12
right :slightly_smiling_face:

jyellick
2016-10-25 15:13
How large are these? To me, this sounds like something that should be encoded into the chain config?

jyellick
2016-10-25 15:13
(And therefore in reconfiguration, and in genesis)

jyellick
2016-10-25 19:52
@elli @adc I'm having trouble mapping my temporary configuration transaction stuff to the 'next' protos that were just merged. How can we verify that an endorsement is over the same transaction header when the the transaction header is not bytes (and we cannot marshal deterministically)

muralisr
2016-10-25 19:54
@jyellick `when the the transaction header is not bytes` can you expand on that ?

jyellick
2016-10-25 19:55
In the `fabric_transaction.proto` the `Transaction` contains repeated `TransactionActions` which contain `TransactionHeader`s

jyellick
2016-10-25 19:56
Since the `TransactionHeader` is expressed as a type, and not as bytes, it's not clear how to check any signature or hash against it

jyellick
2016-10-25 19:58
@muralisr ^

garisingh
2016-10-25 20:01
@jyellick - are you looking at fabric_next.proto?

jyellick
2016-10-25 20:02
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1977/2/protos/next/fabric_transaction.proto

jyellick
2016-10-25 20:03
This was merged, with my vote, earlier as I wanted to start moving the configuration stuff onto the 'real' transaction format.

jyellick
2016-10-25 20:06
My plan was to define a new transaction type in `fabric_transaction_header.proto` called CONFIGURATION, then use a subset of the `ConfigurationEntry` proto from ab.proto as the `Proposal` `Payload`, and then use `Endorsement` over the marshaled `Proposal`, but it seems to me like this gives me two copies of the `TransactionHeader`, which I have to compare field by field to make sure they are the same. Which seems wrong.

muralisr
2016-10-25 20:09
adding @aso

jyellick
2016-10-25 20:13
Basically, I don't see how you can confirm that the `TransactionAction.header` is the same as the `Proposal.header` without doing a field by field comparison. The `ProposalResponsePayload.proposalHash` is over the `Proposal.header`, but since we don't have deterministic marshaling, I don't see how that helps.

muralisr
2016-10-25 20:14
@jyellick one of the things we talked about IIRC was that we want a Type in Transaction and the Type in TransactionHeader would have to be that

muralisr
2016-10-25 20:14
in other words, youd need to unpack the header (even if it was bytes) so you can take a look at the Type

jyellick
2016-10-25 20:15
@muralisr Yes, we did discuss this as an option, though technically, it doesn't have to be bytes and a type flag (it could just be bytes), but the type flag would be more flexible.

garisingh
2016-10-25 20:19
I now recall not being able to follow the whole conversation on this - where can I read about what the heck these fields actually mean? I'll be honest - the inline descriptions are not very clear. This looks to be some very ugly messaging

garisingh
2016-10-25 20:20
and if the transaction action.header is supposed to be the same as the proposal.header why do we have both?

muralisr
2016-10-25 20:23

garisingh

muralisr
2016-10-25 20:24

aso
2016-10-25 20:25

FYI @muralisr you can use a `>` before some text, and it will turn it into a quote, like this: > where do you see proposal.header ?

muralisr

muralisr

muralisr
2016-10-25 20:34

jyellick
2016-10-25 20:34

muralisr
2016-10-25 20:34

garisingh
2016-10-25 20:35

jyellick
2016-10-25 20:35
That seems a little sloppy to me, why are we encoding the same information twice? [edit: oops, Gari beat me to it]

muralisr
2016-10-25 20:37
Proposal is sent to the endorser, and Transaction is sent to the Orderer the same header from Proposal is taken and placed into Transaction and sent right is the header in two places in Transaction ?

garisingh
2016-10-25 20:40
I don't think the thing in the proposal is the same as in the transaction - just the same data structure

jyellick
2016-10-25 20:40

garisingh
2016-10-25 20:41

muralisr
2016-10-25 20:41
ok. my head is spinning now :slightly_smiling_face: let me read the protos again .

aso
2016-10-25 20:41
@garisingh the header in the tx has to be the same as the header in the proposal, or else the checks on slide 23 would fail

aso
2016-10-25 20:42
this is on purpose to enforce a number of security reqs such as accountability

garisingh
2016-10-25 20:42
well then we have the same header repeated multiple times? one for each transaction action, plus one for each proposal?

garisingh
2016-10-25 20:43
alright - let me review again

aso
2016-10-25 20:43
one header per action - a tx might have multiple actions

jyellick
2016-10-25 20:43
On slide 23, "ProposalResponsePayload links to the ProposalHeader and chaincodeProposalPayload through proposalHash"

aso
2016-10-25 20:43
but a single header per action

jyellick
2016-10-25 20:44
Okay, so it sounds like no duplication, but how do we know the hash of the ProposalHeader? Unless we have some custom hashing scheme for it? (As we cannot marshal and hash, because of non-determinism in protobuf)

aso
2016-10-25 20:46
right, I think we'll be forced to unmarshal and hash the contatenation of each of the fields - ugly I know, but not unheard of

aso
2016-10-25 20:47
this might actually be problematic if we have a lot of nesting

jyellick
2016-10-25 20:47
I think that needs to be very explicit then, exactly how we are supposed to hash a TransactionHeader

aso
2016-10-25 20:47
yeah, definitely

aso
2016-10-25 20:47
do you guys have time to have a chat on the phone tomorrow to hash out these important details?

aso
2016-10-25 20:48
I'd do it now but it's almost 11pm over here and I don't trust myself anymore :slightly_smiling_face:

2016-10-25 20:49

adc
2016-10-26 08:28
@jyellick, @muralisr, @garisingh, @aso I did a mistake. If you look at our pdf, Proposal.header was bytes. I changed by mistake to TransactionHeader. This should fix the issue with the checks.

adc
2016-10-26 08:29
Regarding " `TransactionAction.header` is the same as the `Proposal.header` ", the committing peer is not supposed to perform this check because it does not have the Proposal

david.acton
2016-10-26 08:31
Hey gang. I want to get TLS working in both my Dev and eventually Prod envs. For DEV membersrvc, I assume I generate self signed TLS certs. Does this cert have to be in a particular format? e.g. ECDSA, RSA etc? Would anyone happen to know the correct openssl command to run to get the right format?

adc
2016-10-26 13:46
@jyellick, @muralisr, @garisingh, @aso, @elli, @binhn, @jeffgarratt I found the following issue related to the protobuf serialization. An endorser will sign a ProposalResponsePayload message if it endorsers a received proposal. Now, this can be done in the following way: The endorser construct the ProposalResponsePayload message, marshal it and sign the bytes so obtained. But now there is an issue because each endorser might serialize in different ways and then sign different bytes. At this point, the proposal submitter is not able to put together the endowments and construct a Transaction message.

adc
2016-10-26 13:46
This needs to be addressed.

adc
2016-10-26 13:47
Just another note, @aso just noticed that in fabric_next.proto there is the following paragraph that is actually wrong: Something important to understand about protocol buffers is that while // serialization is deterministic in that it will always produce the same // bytes, deserialization is non-deterministic

adc
2016-10-26 13:47
right?

jyellick
2016-10-26 13:54
@adc I'm a little confused by the phrasing, but protobuf serialization is definitely _not_ deterministic. Two different protobuf implementations (or even the same implementation executing twice) may marshal the same structure to two different sets of bytes.

jyellick
2016-10-26 13:55
I think you may have been pointing that out to @aso but just wanted to double check

simon
2016-10-26 13:56
same bytes will produce same data structure, but not guaranteed the other way

adc
2016-10-26 13:56
That paragraph was not written by us

adc
2016-10-26 13:56
was already there

aso
2016-10-26 13:56
so without a submitting peer creating a single ProposalResponsePayload for all to endorse, we have a problem....

aso
2016-10-26 13:57
unless we use a custom hashing scheme

muralisr
2016-10-26 13:57
to clarify

muralisr
2016-10-26 14:00
SDK send to 3 endorsers. 3 endorsers send 3 ProposalResponsePayload back. These could be (should be) identical before marshalling. However the marshalled bytes and the signature they are based on would be different. So We cannot assume we can just send one of the 3 ProposalResponsePayload in transaction but have to send all 3. Note that send just 1 ProposalResponsePayload was an optimization measure. @adc @aso to correct the above as necessary

adc
2016-10-26 14:02
either we use deterministic marshalling or we need to have everything in the Transaction and then having the committing peer check for consistency

aso
2016-10-26 14:02
or we use a custom hashing scheme

adc
2016-10-26 14:02
yeah

adc
2016-10-26 14:03
also the client-sdk has to check for consistency then

aso
2016-10-26 14:03
yup

muralisr
2016-10-26 14:04
for now can we send ProposalResponsePayload ? ie, trade clarity/simplicity for optimization/complexity ?

muralisr
2016-10-26 14:04
(need to get to office will be online soon)

adc
2016-10-26 14:04
a compromise must be reached, that's for sure

simon
2016-10-26 14:07
what's the problem?

adc
2016-10-26 14:09
murali has clarified the point just a few messages earlier

jyellick
2016-10-26 14:09
> SDK send to 3 endorsers. 3 endorsers send 3 ProposalResponsePayload back. These could be (should be) identical before marshalling. However the marshalled bytes and the signature they are based on would be different. So We cannot assume we can just send one of the 3 ProposalResponsePayload in transaction but have to send all 3.

garisingh
2016-10-26 14:10
there's no guarantee for protobufs but I thought that all Google implementations actually serialize bytes the same way in practice even if not a "commitment"

aso
2016-10-26 14:10
without a submitting peer and with non-deterministic marshalling, endorsers will sign the same action (logically) represented as different bytes

jyellick
2016-10-26 14:11
@garisingh I have never witnessed protobuf marshal the same structure to two different sets of bytes. Still, they do explicitly warn that they may not, so for a long term file format, it seems like a bad bet to rely on.

garisingh
2016-10-26 14:12
agreed

garisingh
2016-10-26 14:13
I just know that there are Google projects which sign so probably why its the case

garisingh
2016-10-26 14:13
but they never make guarantees - must be nice to be Google :wink:

jyellick
2016-10-26 14:14

2016-10-26 14:14

Then my `ConfigurationPayload` which would go into the `TransactionActions` would consist of the same marshaled `ConfigurationItem` and the repeated set of endorsements.

2016-10-26 14:38

jyellick
2016-10-26 14:45
Okay, that solves that then. Another question, when I send the `Proposal` to the endorsers (in my world, these will likely be physical people) they do not reply with a `ProposalResponse`, they simply reply with an `Endorsement`?

adc
2016-10-26 14:47
what's the difference in replying with a ProposalResponse and an Endorsemnt message?

adc
2016-10-26 14:47
what do you mean by physical people? They will not use some piece of software?

jyellick
2016-10-26 14:48
Well, the `Endorsement` structure claims that: ``` // Signature of the payload included in ProposalResponse concatenate with // the endorser's certificate; ie, sign(ProposalResponse.payload + endorser) bytes signature = 2; ``` Which implies that I need to somehow generate all of these structures, none of which have meaningful data

garisingh
2016-10-26 14:48
@jyellick - is an endorser an ordering node in your case?

jyellick
2016-10-26 14:49
@garisingh No, I would expect for an endorser to be an 'admin' and not necessarily for the orderers, it could also be a peer admin, anyone who is authorized to modify the configuration initially populated in the genesis block

jyellick
2016-10-26 14:49
By physical people, I mean that it will be a human decision, of course it will likely be implemented as 'click this button to agree', but there will likely not generally be automated review.

garisingh
2016-10-26 14:50
right

garisingh
2016-10-26 14:50
(recall how I have mentioned that endorsement cannot replace signature workflow :wink: ? )

jyellick
2016-10-26 14:52
So, to frame this problem more generally, the genesis block will consist of a `Transaction` which consists of repeated `TransactionActions` each of which contains a `ConfigurationItem` the `ConfigurationItem` has a policy attached to it, with who is allowed to modify the item (what endorsements are required), so, anyone who is authorized to submit a configuration transaction can take the previous configuration, modify the bits they are authorized to (with appropriate endorsements) and then submit the configuration tx, and these new configuration will become the new chain configuration (assuming it validates). This is a special sort of transaction in that only valid ones ever make it onto the raw chain.

garisingh
2016-10-26 14:52
and there are 2 parts: submitting this to the ordering service and then the ordering service propagating this to the peers to update their config?

jyellick
2016-10-26 14:53
That's why it's critical that the ordering service be able to evaluate the transaction's validity without any dependence on chaincode, MVCC, etc.

adc
2016-10-26 14:53
got it

garisingh
2016-10-26 14:53
BUT it only cares about config transactions, correct?

jyellick
2016-10-26 14:54
I would say yes, 3 parts. Creating and submitting it to order, and then the ordering service concluding whether or not it satisfies the update policies, finally, the peers once they receive the config transaction can also verify that the ordering service is not trying to pull a fast one and change some peer policy it is not authorized to do so, by performing the check as well.

jyellick
2016-10-26 14:54
Exactly, the ordering service will only intropsect on CONFIGURATION type transactions

jyellick
2016-10-26 14:54
(And it will make sure that such transactions get their own block)

adc
2016-10-26 14:54
got it

garisingh
2016-10-26 14:55
(sorry for being dense - just want to make sure we bring it all back together instead of reading history)

jyellick
2016-10-26 14:56
Not at all, I've tried to document this some in the multi-channel document, but it should be done more explicitly

adc
2016-10-26 14:57
still not clear to me, what's the issue in creating the ProposalResponse. The client-sdk, I guess, will be used to send the CONFIGURATION Proposal to the endorsers and put together the endorsements it gets back, no?

adc
2016-10-26 14:58
probably, I'm missing something here :disappointed:

adc
2016-10-26 14:58
@jyellick, may you clarify this?

jyellick
2016-10-26 14:59
Yes, the issue I see with the `ProposalResponse` is that it assumes that the proposal is somehow 'executed' and therefore has a lot of fields that are rather meaningless when it is really a "sign if you like it, don't if you don't". These changes would not be submitted to peer endorsers, rather, I'd expect them to be emailed or whatever and signatures generated/collected manually by admins.

garisingh
2016-10-26 14:59
@jyellick wants to simply things with a COMMON transaction format for config and regular (mvcc, chaincode) transactions and re-use the structures since in the end config and mvcc end up in blocks on the peer side

garisingh
2016-10-26 14:59
correct?

garisingh
2016-10-26 15:00
so we could have something different than CHAINCODE as the type of trans

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:00
Exactly. I have custom structures today which work, but they duplicate much of what is in the fabric next structures

garisingh
2016-10-26 15:03
I think in the end we need to prove that we can support non-chaincode transaction types here

elli
2016-10-26 15:03
@jyellick, why would we need an endorsement-based logic for configuration?

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:05
Everyone bootstraps the network, and agrees that these 6 peer orgs are allowed to transact, and we're using ordering as a service, so the orderer org is not, and if any 4 of the 6 peer orgs vote to change membership, it's allowed. So, the orderer gets a transaction in which attempts to add a peer org. How does it verify that there is agreement from 4 of the 6? By checking the endorsements

elli
2016-10-26 15:05
That is, to my understanding i) reconfiguration messages are deterministically prossessed, ii) do not incur into heavy computation load that would be impossible to handle without parallelization, and iii) to have an endorsement-model we would need to have some prominent/highly priviledged endorsers that are authorized to endorse system reconfiguration proposals.

elli
2016-10-26 15:06
What is important for reconfig message authentication is the client that submits it and signsthe associated transaction but there is no need for "automated endorsement", no?

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:07
i) Yes, absolutely must be determinstic ii) They can be processed in parallel for the signature checks iii) Who is given the authority to modify configuration is a policy matter, it could be as open or restrictive as defined, but I would expect only highly privileged users would be able

elli
2016-10-26 15:07
well, however, endorsement is an automated processs

elli
2016-10-26 15:07
that is it checks the signature on the proposal and this is what it bases its evaluation on,

elli
2016-10-26 15:07
client-signature is what is important here, i think!

simon
2016-10-26 15:08
i must be missing something important

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:08
I'm not sure I agree or maybe I do not follow

elli

elli
2016-10-26 15:11

elli

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:11

2016-10-26 15:13

jyellick

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:16

elli
2016-10-26 15:21
Ok, so a configuration transaction can be consisting of the same message as Transaction in protobuf file, where type (part of transaction header) is set to CONFIGURATION (either of fabric/orderer- i leave this out for now), creator field, in the header includes a banch of certificates, and signature field contains the signatures associated with these certificates.

elli
2016-10-26 15:22
The payload of the transaction would include all the re-configuration information, say "authorized entities is now "Alice, Bob, Charlie, Lucy, Dave, and Frank"

elli
2016-10-26 15:22
this transaction is submitted to the system ledger (say this for simplicity) and its picked up by everyone, who then need to evaluate it.

elli
2016-10-26 15:23
Then is where the execution (small processing of these transactions) can take place, that would have an effect on the local state of each entity that maintains it.

elli
2016-10-26 15:23

elli
2016-10-26 15:24

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:25
First, ignoring all other parts to the scheme, what would prevent requiring that the previous config be repeated? The Transaction supports multiple `TransactionActions`, what is the complaint against requiring the entire config in the transaction?

elli
2016-10-26 15:26

elli
2016-10-26 15:26

simon
2016-10-26 15:26
jyellick: why repeat the previous config?

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:27
@simon It will vastly simplify our life for pruning, and makes it much easier to inspect the chain and from a single point see the configuration, rather than having to play the whole chain to determine it

elli
2016-10-26 15:28
Some sort of simulation result would that be.

simon
2016-10-26 15:28
i think pruning is wrong

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:28
@elli I'm not sure why committers vs clients matters here. There is an existing configuration, so grab all of the `TransactionActions` from it. Pick the ones you wish to modify, and replace them with appropriately endorsed new ones.

simon
2016-10-26 15:28
i think all of this is way too complicated and not correctly layered

garisingh
2016-10-26 15:29
@simon - for which part - just for this "config" part or for transactions / proposals in general?

simon
2016-10-26 15:30
config, i did not follow the format of the fabric messages, nor do i care for them

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:30
@simon In order to prevent DOS attacks in the BFT case, the orderer is going to have to have insight into the transaction format to verify signatures. So I see no way around the orderer knowing about the fabric transaction format. I don't like it, would love to hear another option.

simon
2016-10-26 15:31
i'd say the ordering service defines an outer format which carries signatures

simon
2016-10-26 15:31
and the fabric can fill the payload as it wants

simon
2016-10-26 15:31
no pruning

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:32
I'd say the orderer transaction format needs to have a chain ID, a submitter ID, a payload, a nonce, signatures, basically what is in the base transaction from the fabric

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:33
I think it would have made more sense to design a base transaction for the orderer, then build the fabric transaction on top of it

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:33
Rather than how we are approaching it now, which is to build the fabric transaction, and try to pick a subset of it for the orderer

garisingh
2016-10-26 15:33
(that's the conclusion I was coming to as well @jyellick - start simple and add rather than start complex)

garisingh
2016-10-26 15:33
else I think you can basically just share a very simple outer envelope

adc

elli
2016-10-26 15:49
