elli
2016-10-26 15:49
indeed

elli
2016-10-26 15:49
maybe its a multi-transaction what we have there

simon
2016-10-26 15:49
what is a multi-transaction?

elli
2016-10-26 15:50
for this we can remove this complexity and define transaction to contain only what is included in transactionACtion

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:50
I think what I am driving at, is I don't understand how a transaction can have a repeated field which contains the transaction's header(s)

elli
2016-10-26 15:50
for now it will anyway be one transaction per transaction :slightly_smiling_face:

elli
2016-10-26 15:51
the field does nto contain only transaction header

elli
2016-10-26 15:51
but also transaction payload

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:51
To us, I think a transaction is a header (which prevents replay, and provides identity), a payload, and a signature

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:52
If you want a 'multi-transaction', then I would make that payload be a message which contains repeated transactions, or some other format

elli
2016-10-26 15:52
So if we have transaction include

elli
2016-10-26 15:53
timestamp, header, paylaod (parts of transactionAction) directly, and a signature without any repetition,would this simplify things in your opinion?

simon
2016-10-26 15:53

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:53

elli
2016-10-26 15:53

elli
2016-10-26 15:53

elli
2016-10-26 15:53

elli
2016-10-26 15:53

simon
2016-10-26 15:54
hey let me propose something completely new:

simon
2016-10-26 15:54

2016-10-26 15:54

simon
2016-10-26 15:54

simon

elli
2016-10-26 15:55

jyellick
2016-10-26 15:56

simon
2016-10-26 15:56
yes

simon
2016-10-26 15:57
and given that it is a deterministic format you could even implement a faster version

simon
2016-10-26 16:04
of course the payload still will need to be an array of bytes to provide layering

elli
2016-10-26 16:05
Hm ok, to change slightly the discussion, we prepared this https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-829 as proposal for generic membership service interface.

elli
2016-10-26 16:05
ACtually a membership service provider interface (the client side mostly).

jyellick
2016-10-26 16:10
@elli I'm a little confused about what membership services is supposed to do in v1. My assumption was that it would issue the t-certs/e-certs for an organization, but that the signature validation etc. must be able to be performed without access to membership services, only to the chain?

elli
2016-10-26 16:16
Correct. The interface i referred to has to do with the interface that transaction processing part of the client has with the membership service part of the client

elli
2016-10-26 16:17
It should be transparent to how and when the server is contacted

keithsmith
2016-10-26 16:17
There are 3 touch points for membership services: 1) server 2) client (how the SDK talks to the server) and 3) peer (how the peer processes certs issued by server)

elli
2016-10-26 16:17
correct

elli
2016-10-26 16:18
actually the server can be hidden from the client

keithsmith
2016-10-26 16:18
For #3, it has generally been just normal PKIX checking

elli
2016-10-26 16:18
but ok the interface should be accommodatin auditing requirements on the server side

keithsmith
2016-10-26 16:18
yes, that is true also ... only the client knows how to talk to the server

keithsmith
2016-10-26 16:20
anyway, Elli, you said that we needed to change #3 and perhaps #2 also to be able to plugin Identity Mixer later

keithsmith
2016-10-26 16:20
that is what you are working in in FAB 829, right?

garisingh
2016-10-26 16:20
@jyellick - are you adamant about the fact that a "fabric" transaction and an "orderer" transaction need to share the same format? I am not so sure I agree that they need to be and/or should be and the more I think about it, the more I think it will cause more harm than good. Here's my thoughts / understanding: - I assume that we agree that we determine the identities used for access control for the Broadcast and Deliver services/APIs via the certificates used to sign the "messages" sent to either of those services? So this means that we need to have the messages sent via Broadcast be signed by the "client" - For messages sent via Broadcast, we would also need to know the channel, payload, cert of sender and signature. So the "header, payload, signature" structure works well here and the ordering service really does not need to know anything about the payload EXCEPT in the case where this is a CONFIG transaction? I would assert that you could add that as a "type" to the header and/or have a separate service/API for config. I also assume that CONFIG messages must be sent to the intended channel for ordering purposes - For non-CONFIG messages, the orderers make sure the signature is valid on the broadcast message and that the signer is allowed to broadcast to the channel. So for "normal" broadcast messages (e.g. fabric transactions), the orderer views these as opaque and simply orders them and delivers to anyone connected on target channel - For a CONFIG message (determined by the type in the header or there could actually be a separate service/API for config), the orderer actually needs to execute some logic to make sure that the config change is valid, the sender is authorized, etc. The creation of this message would occur outside of the fabric (typically) and any type of signatures which needed to be gathered would be done outside of the fabric and the ordering service. All of this information would be in the "payload" of the broadcast message. Assuming that the CONFIG change met the rules / constraints, there might be certain of these types of message (or maybe all) which would need to be delivered to peers connected to the channel the config is for. I would actually assert that the ordering service should actually deliver this as a batch of 1 and I think that perhaps you introduce a "type" field in the batch/block header so that when the receiving peer(s) get it, they know that this is a special batch/block. I think that if done this way, then the ordering service needs to know nothing about fabric (or any other things which wants to use it) transactions and you have a well-defined way of distributing config to peers using a "config" batch/block

elli
2016-10-26 16:21
@keithsmith correct.

garisingh
2016-10-26 16:24
I think we need to stop calling the "crypto" layer which components use to do basic crypto "membership services" :wink:

garisingh
2016-10-26 16:25
"cop-client" or something

keithsmith
2016-10-26 16:25
Gari, do you agree with comments in https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-807 wrt both orderer and peers using common code to parse the 3 types of cert lists?

garisingh
2016-10-26 16:26
it's confusing given the legacy of the current stuff

garisingh
2016-10-26 16:26
yeah - we should share crypto stuff wherever possible

kostas
2016-10-26 16:26
> I would actually assert that the ordering service should actually deliver this as a batch of 1 and I think that perhaps you introduce a "type" field in the batch/block header so that when the receiving peer(s) get it, they know that this is a special batch/block. Was this assertion ever contested? This has been the assumption in all the discussions I've taken part in.

kostas
2016-10-26 16:27
(I've only scrolled back to yesterday's discussions so perhaps I've missed something.)

simon
2016-10-26 16:28
why batch of 1?

garisingh
2016-10-26 16:28
@kostas - I try to follow all the conversations and write ups, so perhaps there was no disagreement on some of those points but I'll be honest it is not super clear to me (which is likely that I am not involved in every discussion)

garisingh
2016-10-26 16:28
because I put a "type" field in the batch header

simon
2016-10-26 16:28
aha

garisingh
2016-10-26 16:28
could be more as long as they were all config transactions

garisingh
2016-10-26 16:29
it basically gives the orderer freedom to deal with config as it likes

simon
2016-10-26 16:29
why is this part of the batch and not part of the payload format?

simon
2016-10-26 16:29
@keithsmith what are CRLs used for in the orderer?

garisingh
2016-10-26 16:30
because then the config and fabric transactions would have to share something in common - which is what I wanted to avoid

garisingh
2016-10-26 16:31
and I wanted to ensure that the ordering nodes do not ever have to know anything about a fabric transaction. The opposite is OK - fabric can know about ordering batch format and config payload / format

keithsmith
2016-10-26 16:33
@simon CRLs would be for revoked peer and end user certs, but wouldn't that still need to flow thru this config update? I'm assuming you don't need to support revocation of orderer certs

simon
2016-10-26 16:33
okay

simon
2016-10-26 16:34
why is this cert list a special type? it could be maintained as a part of the ledger, no?

keithsmith
2016-10-26 16:38
Actually, the orderers will need to process CRL also, to make sure they reject traffic from a revoked peer cert

simon
2016-10-26 16:39
okay

keithsmith
2016-10-26 16:39
It is a "special type" only in the sense that it identifies it's use as a list of revoked certs rather than a list of trusted certs

jyellick
2016-10-26 17:13
> are you adamant about the fact that a "fabric" transaction and an "orderer" transaction need to share the same format? @garisingh I would be adamant that the thing the fabric sends to the orderer must be encoded in the same way the thing that contains the config is encoded. In other words, the ordering service should not have to understand fabric transactions to validate their signature, and then additionally understand ordering transactions and how to validate them. What you propose, is what I would prefer, an ordering transaction type which is the only thing the orderer accepts. It can wrap whatever fabric structure is required, and the fabric structure can depend on the orderer constructs, like the header to prevent replay, or not, does not matter to me. The sticky points to me, are that the specification says that the client sends a fabric transaction to the orderer (not an orderer transaction), and that the raw ledger work claims to store fabric transactions (again, not orderer transactions). Because those two things didn't seem likely to switch off the fabric transaction type to an orderer transaction type, I was attempting to switch the orderer onto the fabric transaction type, even though it seems like a suboptimal solution to me.

binhn
2016-10-26 17:32
We need to be careful here not to mix up the transactions. The intent for CONFIG type tx is for the orderers to act on them without the existence of a chaincode (remember all txs on peers involve some chaincode). Some CONFIG tx may also be exec on peers

jyellick
2016-10-26 17:34
@binhn The question is whether we try to take the proposed fabric transaction format, and add a type for CONFIG transactions, or whether we create a more generic orderer transaction type, and rework the fabric transaction type on top of it. I think @garisingh and I would propose the latter, while others (I'll let them identify themselves) would opt for the former.

jyellick
2016-10-27 15:47

aso
2016-10-27 16:10
@jyellick @muralisr pushed new comments and minor changes

aso
2016-10-27 17:40
@jyellick I wanted to follow up here on > What if we required that every transaction is endorsed by the proposer? This seems like it would solve the problem of 'stolen' proposals. If the network wanted to allow 'proxied' proposal submission (where there is a different transaction submitter than proposal creator) then this could still be supported.

aso
2016-10-27 17:43
I'm not sure I fully understand yet. Here's my doubt: how can we support transactions that can include multiple actions, where each action may result from the proposal of a different client, while still ensuring that only one actor signs the transaction?

jyellick
2016-10-27 17:45
But the transaction must be signed by one actor?

aso
2016-10-27 17:45
currently yes, only by one

aso
2016-10-27 17:45
we could have multiple sigs

aso
2016-10-27 17:45
or multisigs

aso
2016-10-27 17:45
but that wasn't discussed so far

jyellick
2016-10-27 17:45
Ultimately, it will be a single client who submits the transaction

jyellick
2016-10-27 17:45
And I would think there should be a transaction header, which that client must sign over

aso
2016-10-27 17:46
right but we want to retain the consent of the submitting actor in its signature of the tx. If the actions are from somebody else, where is *their* consent recorded?

aso
2016-10-27 17:47
imagine both of us submits a proposal, gets an endorsed action

aso
2016-10-27 17:47
now we want to create a tx with both our actions

aso
2016-10-27 17:47
who signs it?

aso
2016-10-27 17:47
if only one does, the other can always claim it didn't mean to do that - it's my word against yours

aso
2016-10-27 17:48
but the second anyone signs, then they are bound by the signature

aso
2016-10-27 17:48
they can't claim that they didn't mean to

jyellick
2016-10-27 17:54
I still maintain, whoever submits it, must sign it, as the submitter

aso
2016-10-27 17:54
I don't disagree with that

jyellick
2016-10-27 17:54
And I would say there can only ever be a single submitter

jyellick
2016-10-27 17:54
(for a particular tran)

aso
2016-10-27 17:55
in that case, how do you solve our little dispute of a tx signed by you with both our proposal actions?

aso
2016-10-27 17:55
I can claim I didn't give you any authorization - and then in front of the judge they'll say "no, sorry. Ale is Italian and we don't trust them" and then I'm screwed :stuck_out_tongue:

garisingh
2016-10-27 17:56
????

aso
2016-10-27 17:56
@garisingh the disucssion concerns a transaction containing 2 actions stemming from proposals from 2 different clients

aso
2016-10-27 17:56
who signs that transaction?

garisingh
2016-10-27 17:57
I don't think we were trying to support transactions from multiple submitters (clients) in the same envelope

aso
2016-10-27 17:57
then we're good

aso
2016-10-27 17:57
but I think @jyellick had reservations about that

aso
2016-10-27 17:57
(if I understood correctly)

jyellick
2016-10-27 17:59
It is more that having the creator specified in a repeated header implies to me that it is possible

jyellick
2016-10-27 18:00

2016-10-27 18:00

kostas
2016-10-27 19:26

kostas
2016-10-27 19:28
And can we clarify what is the difference between `CONFIGURATION_TRANSACTION` and `CONFIGURATION_ITEM`? (I can guess, but I don't want to.)

jyellick
2016-10-27 19:52
I was just discussing this with @muralisr we could add a field of type `FABRIC`

muralisr
2016-10-27 19:59
sounds like if we did that then `Transaction2` becomes `Data` for `Type == FABRIC` and we dont need `SignedTransaction`

muralisr
2016-10-27 19:59
did I read that right ?

muralisr
2016-10-27 20:56
actually talking with @binhn we could consolidate even further like so

muralisr
2016-10-27 21:00
```Envelope == SignedData Payload == SignableData Header == SignatureHeader so that Envelope { Payload, Signature } Payload {Header, Data} maps to @jyellick structures. ie, basically use standard names such as Envelope, Header etc to describe generic objects and then `Data` becomes specialized based on Header```

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:19
@garisingh @binhn @kostas @simon @muralisr I think we really need to make a decision as to whether configuration tx is on the fabric transaction type with fabric style endorsements or not. I've heard very different stories depending on who I ask. Below is my understanding: There are some who suggest that configuration transaction endorsement should be done by endorsers (even if it requires out of band manual human interaction to approve the endorsement). This means all orderering entities would need deploy endorsing peers to support reconfiguring the ordering network. Pros: Reuse of components, reuse of concepts Cons: Violates layering idea of the orderer network being unaware of the peer, fabric transaction format is complex There are some who suggest that configuration transaction endorsement should be done entirely in an out of band procedure using a simpler mechanism than endorsement, with admins doing key signatures manually out of band (because modifying config should always require human approval). Pros: Makes bootstrapping simple, keeps orderer concept relatively isolated from fabric concepts Cons: Require reinventing mechanisms from the fabric

garisingh
2016-10-27 21:21
I go with the latter - separate from fabric.

garisingh
2016-10-27 21:21
And I think the only reinvention might be policy which we could share

kostas
2016-10-27 21:22
Strong vote for the latter option.

binhn
2016-10-27 21:23
why would " fabric transaction format is complex ?

binhn
2016-10-27 21:24
i am fine with have manual configurations for orderer but if it requires to be in the ledger, it need to be a transaction

binhn
2016-10-27 21:25
which should be interpreted by the peers on both endorsing (if required) and validating

binhn
2016-10-27 21:25
channel creation, for example, cant and shouldnt be done manually

binhn
2016-10-27 21:26
the current transaction object is defined to contain a header and a payload. The payload depends on the type in the header

binhn
2016-10-27 21:26
why would that be complex?

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:27
If we are doing automated endorsement over it, then I maintain we _must_ use the Proposal/ProposalResponse/etc. which I think, are complex.

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:28
There is no technical reason which would prevent us from using this construct, I've been thinking about how we might do this, and I actually think it can be made mildly elegant, but I have not worked all the kinks out.

binhn
2016-10-27 21:28
what CONFIG trans that dont effect the peers ? separate those out and handle them on the orderer

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:28
But I think the aggregation of the transaction proposal, proposalresponse etc. is undeniably complex

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:29
Having different styles of config endorsement seems like a bad road to me.

binhn
2016-10-27 21:29
for those that effect the peer and ledger, we need to follow a clear path otherwise we would only confuse developers

binhn
2016-10-27 21:30
nothing prevent us from defining another type of trans

binhn
2016-10-27 21:33
if a trans (regardless of type) effecting both peer and orderer, it needs to travel the same path, so that all the APIs would work the same way; some of them (types) might not need endorsements

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:34
I'm confused how you could have a reconfiguration transaction without endorsement

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:34
(here I use endorsement in a generic non-fabric way)

binhn
2016-10-27 21:36
what are the reconfiguration transactions that we know of today? after all, endorsement is a process determined by the app, not the fabric

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:40
Changing transactor membership, changing orderer membership, changing policy (including modification policies for the membership)

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:42
(And possibly other chain configuration data which we haven't realized we need yet)

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:43
Changing orderer addresses, orderer characteristics (think pbft f, or K, or L), changing other chain characteristics like block size or batch timeout, changing block validation policies, expiring certs (are a few more that come to mind)

binhn
2016-10-27 21:44
do we need to record these changes on the ledger or some private orderers db?

binhn
2016-10-27 21:45
if ledger, which ledger and which peers maintain the ledger?

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:47
I would say these are the properties of the 'configuration block'. A 'configuration block' should contain all the configuration for the chain, so that any peer or orderer, given this block (and told to trust it) could completely participate in validation and reception of the chain going forward. (For a peer, for application logic, they would likely need past blocks).

muralisr
2016-10-27 21:50
@jyellick if these properties are on the `configuration block` are maintained on the ledger .. seems to logically follow that they are maintained as states on a chaincode OR are they are maintained outside of the ledger in some trusted manner ?

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:51
I'm wary of the term 'the ledger', to me this implies some database or other

binhn
2016-10-27 21:51
chain = channel + ledger which is created by the application + peers, so without that, there would be no chain to begin with We could treat this config block as a structure maintained by the orderers some how and given to the application when the app creates a chain

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:52
I would see there being a simple transformative function "Config" -> In memory structure. When a peer starts up, it picks the most recent config block, and uses that for config.

muralisr
2016-10-27 21:52
ok

muralisr
2016-10-27 21:53
so its not part of the block but modified in some trusted manner

binhn
2016-10-27 21:53
so this has nothing to do with transactions

binhn
2016-10-27 21:53
just some confguration on the orderer

muralisr
2016-10-27 21:53
if thats true then we dont need a transaction to modify it

binhn
2016-10-27 21:53
an API

binhn
2016-10-27 21:54
how would existing peers learn about the changes on the configuration block?

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:55
Whenever the configuration changes, a new configuration block is emitted as the next block in the chain

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:55
A configuration block only ever contains exactly one 'configuration transaction'

binhn
2016-10-27 21:55
no, youre mixing the metaphor of transaction with configuration data on orderer

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:56
This is chain wide configuration

binhn
2016-10-27 21:56
which chain?

binhn
2016-10-27 21:56
there are multi chains

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:56
Each channel has a chain

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:56
Every chain has a most recent configuration block

binhn
2016-10-27 21:57
that doesnt work

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:57
Why?

muralisr
2016-10-27 21:57
we can say (1) config is on ledger and would need to be managed using a chaincode (config being properties) or (2) config is outside of ledger and does not need fabrics transaction semantics (no need to invoke chaincode etc)

muralisr
2016-10-27 21:58
what we CANNOT say is config is on ledger but does not need fabrics transaction semantics as theres no way you can modify the states represented by the configuration outside of the chaincode pathIm thinking states as properties tat have to be manipulate via RW set

jyellick
2016-10-27 21:58
(2) is not an option, config must be processed in line with the blocks, otherwise it is extremely hard not to be non-deterministic

binhn
2016-10-27 21:58
t1 broadcasted before config changes; t2 broadcasted after config changes; t1 and t2 were ordered in the same block; config changes was in another block; which block get to peer first?

jyellick
2016-10-27 22:00
Config is not changed until it makes it into a block. The transactions are processed against the most recent config change. If it's in a block before the block this tx is bound for, then you apply that config. If the tx was processed before that config, then it wouldn't.

binhn
2016-10-27 22:00
if 2 is not an option, then we must use transaction it is for auditability and all the apis to work the same way

muralisr
2016-10-27 22:01
oh I see

jyellick
2016-10-27 22:01
We can do (1), but per @kostas and @garisingh they do not like the idea of it

muralisr
2016-10-27 22:01
you are saying youll construct a block on the fly and just plug it in

jyellick
2016-10-27 22:01
(I also believe @troyronda and @simon do not like the idea of using the fabric transaction)

muralisr
2016-10-27 22:01
gosh

jyellick
2016-10-27 22:02
@muralisr It is not that complicated. The transaction that comes in contains the config.

jyellick
2016-10-27 22:02
There's not transformation, nothing complicated, we just validate it, and if it's good, throw it in a block. If it's not, we discard it.

jyellick
2016-10-27 22:03
As my initial post to this whole discussion, I see pros and cons to reusing the fabric transaction. I just need a decision as I can't implement both.

jyellick
2016-10-27 22:03
(Or rather, it would be a waste to do both)

muralisr
2016-10-27 22:03
right

binhn
2016-10-27 22:03
if its on ledger, how would we get/query the content?

binhn
2016-10-27 22:04
how would the ledger know to build the merkle tree

jyellick
2016-10-27 22:04
I would imagine a switch that says "If it's configuration, pass it to this little library, it will either tell you the config was inappropriately updated (in which case, you have a problem and should stop participating in the network) or, it will hand you back a little map of the config values, or some other convenient structure.

muralisr
2016-10-27 22:04
so then this is what needs to happen ledger peeks into the tran and if a CHAINCODE tran does read/write consolidation or if its a CONFIG transaction it would just call an API into the peer to set it

muralisr
2016-10-27 22:04
?

jyellick
2016-10-27 22:05
Right. When you receive a block from ordering, you already need to inspect it to make sure it's valid. So, extend that further, if it only has one transaction, check to see if it's a config tran, and if so, try to apply it.

muralisr
2016-10-27 22:06
ok

binhn
2016-10-27 22:06
so now on every call, we need to check type

kostas
2016-10-27 22:06
This makes perfect sense to me.

muralisr
2016-10-27 22:07
in other words, ledger needs to be aware of CONFIG type and treat it differently

muralisr
2016-10-27 22:07
well, we already peek into the tran in the ledger

binhn
2016-10-27 22:07
this wouldbe exception processing; ugly

binhn
2016-10-27 22:08
bad design

jyellick
2016-10-27 22:08
Then why do we support non-chaincode types?

binhn
2016-10-27 22:09
it should behave the same from persistence point of view some that we can protect the other APIs

muralisr
2016-10-27 22:09
just for reference

muralisr
2016-10-27 22:09
@muralisr uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/muralisr/F2V94SWKG/pasted_image_at_2016_10_27_06_09_pm.png

muralisr
2016-10-27 22:09
thats what we do today to prepare for read/write

binhn
2016-10-27 22:10
ledger now operates on read-write-set, this config type would not have that but it changed the state

jyellick
2016-10-27 22:12
If we ever support another transaction type like, say UTXO, we will have to process the transaction differently. The config transaction is just a very very simple sort transaction which doesn't require a backing DB to parse.

kostas
2016-10-27 22:12
Assuming that this is a bad design, how is it better than violating this nice layer separation between orderers/endorsers that we currently have?

binhn
2016-10-27 22:13
we already violate the layer by sending an unknown block to the ledger maintained by the peers

jyellick
2016-10-27 22:13
Peers layer on top of ordering, so it is fine for them to need to know about ordering concepts

kostas
2016-10-27 22:14
I disagree. Consider what the alternative path entails for orderers.

garisingh
2016-10-27 22:14
my take is very simple - the ordering service should have no awareness of fabric transactions. Now the peers will need to know how to interpret batches of opaque messages and special config messages. That's because they use the ordering service.

garisingh
2016-10-27 22:14
it's as simple as that. config of the ordering service is not governed by peers

binhn
2016-10-27 22:15
i agreed, but there are config trans that governed by the peers

binhn
2016-10-27 22:15
such as channel

garisingh
2016-10-27 22:15
for fabric - opaque will be fabric transactions

garisingh
2016-10-27 22:16
then those can be fabric transactions

binhn
2016-10-27 22:16
rest my case

garisingh
2016-10-27 22:16
ordering service needs to know nothing about those other than to order them as opaque and deliver to the proper channel like any other mesages

garisingh
2016-10-27 22:17
hang on

garisingh
2016-10-27 22:18
someone will need to tell the ordering service to create / modify a channel and add/remove members/identities. that is an orderer specific transaction.

garisingh
2016-10-27 22:18
this whole thing seems messy to me - let me step away for a few and think about this

muralisr
2016-10-27 22:19
meanwhile can we merge https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2071 ?

garisingh
2016-10-27 22:19
creation of a channel and telling peers to join a channel actually are 2 separate things

muralisr
2016-10-27 22:19
If we are ok with the changes, I can incorporate them

garisingh
2016-10-27 22:20
one is an orderer API (create the channel) and agreement to use/join is a fabric transaction

binhn
2016-10-27 22:20

garisingh
2016-10-27 22:20

jyellick
2016-10-27 22:21
@garisingh This has always been my viewpoint, that anyone with authority to create a channel on the ordering service can do so, with whatever properties they want. It is up to the peers to decide whether or not they wish to join that channel.

kostas
2016-10-27 22:21
Telling peers to join a channel is something that happens between the company's app and the company's peers. This has nothing to do with ordering.

troyronda
2016-10-27 23:07
@jyellick: It would be nice if other types of messages could be sent through consensus (for possible extensibility). I also think this is a possible consideration for versioning. I have typically advocated that many application-level configurations should be endorsed as fabric transactions.

troyronda
2016-10-27 23:10
I would also think that several middle-level configurations surface in a similar way ... such as creation of subledgers, peer membership, etc. I would also advocate for those items as being endorsed (regardless of the transaction type) and not use a totally out-of-band mechanism.

troyronda
2016-10-27 23:28
Sorry - I was editing :)

jyellick
2016-10-27 23:28
@troyronda Sorry if I put words in your mouth, just thought I'd seen you +1 a comment about building the fabric Tran on an orderer Tran

troyronda
2016-10-27 23:32
No worries - I did intend that part :)

troyronda
2016-10-27 23:38
@jyellick: Btw - I was reading a gerrit change log where my understanding was that the Metadata field isn't included in the hash structure of a block. Is there an equivalent in batches?

troyronda
2016-10-28 00:14
And is the metadata intended to be synched between peers along with the rest of the block data?

jyellick
2016-10-28 00:52
Metadata is intended to be synced, and is usually used to contain signatures, for instance if 3 of 4 ordering nodes need to sign, there are four different valid sets of signatures (five if you want to be technical) , which would result in four different hashes if they were included in the block hash. It's okay to sync this unhashed data because the receiver can verify it.

jyellick
2016-10-28 00:55
As far as batches vs blocks, they're the same data structure

troyronda
2016-10-28 01:19
Cool.. excellent.

muralisr
2016-10-28 05:09
protos integrated with https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2081/

aso
2016-10-28 07:54
@muralisr cool, I'll attempt a rebase of my patch on top of that branch

teddy
2016-10-28 08:55
has joined #fabric-crypto

teddy
2016-10-28 09:07

@teddy - reposting this over in membership services

muralisr

muralisr
2016-10-28 12:09

simon
2016-10-28 14:25
i feel my remark about not using protobufs for persistent data structures is being ignored

garisingh
2016-10-28 14:30
@adc - can you rebase https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2029/ (and perhaps the change sets which come after it)

adc
2016-10-28 14:30
sure

jyellick
2016-10-28 14:31
@simon I'm not opposed to switching to another structure, I just have no experience with ASN.1 or how to define it in a schema-like fashion (like protobuf), which is why I submitted my work on top of protobuf as it was the path of least resistance

simon
2016-10-28 14:32
you just define a go structure

simon
2016-10-28 14:32
and voila, marshal/unmarshal with ASN.1

garisingh
2016-10-28 14:33
although we do need to support other languages besides for Go

jyellick
2016-10-28 14:34
How about doing something like a SignedMessage, where you have a payload (a structure) and a signature. How do you know what bytes to check the signature over, do we then need to remarshal? (So essentially, the path would be. Unmarshal outer struct, read signature field, re-marshal inner struct, verify? If so, that also doesn't seem extremely elegant)

simon
2016-10-28 14:36
the GO ASN.1 parser allows you to have a `DataBytes` field (or similar name)

simon
2016-10-28 14:37
where it stuffs in the bytes that filled the structure

jyellick
2016-10-28 14:39
Oh, interesting. Personally, I think ASN.1 sounds like a good idea, but so much of the system is built on protobuf, I'm not sure if its use would be deemed too confusing.

simon
2016-10-28 14:40
well now is really the time to decide and do it

garisingh
2016-10-28 14:41
well it could be interesting to TRY to mix them in - given that almost all of our higher order protobuf messages end up simply carrying bytes in order to address non-deterministic serialization

garisingh
2016-10-28 14:42
so perhaps protobuf as part of GRPC is nice for the "protocol" messages / envelopes and when we end up using "bytes" we move to ASN1?

garisingh
2016-10-28 14:43
potentially means having 2 sets on encoders / decoders as part of any library interacting with the GRPC services, but that's not so bad

jyellick
2016-10-28 14:44
Looks like there is a js implementation out there, https://github.com/PeculiarVentures/ASN1.js the license looks a little goofy because it's nonstandard, but it's the one most links seem to point to

garisingh
2016-10-28 14:44
we are already dealing with ASN1 anyway today in the NodeJS SDK for the crypto stuff

garisingh
2016-10-28 14:44
(certificates, etc)

jyellick
2016-10-28 14:44
Ah okay, I suppose X.509 is all ASN.1

simon
2016-10-28 14:44
yes

aso
2016-10-28 14:45
fwiw: I completely agree with @simon : stuff that is persisted should be serialized in standard ways. This way, any other implementation will at least be able to read the ledger

aso
2016-10-28 14:45
also: the crypto world with x509 has embraced ASN.1

jyellick
2016-10-28 14:46
@aso I'm not sure I entirely agree that protobuf is not 'standard'. It's well documented and standardized with lots of different language implementations, but I would agree its non-determinstic marshaling nature makes it poorly suited for crypto work

aso
2016-10-28 14:47
good point - being standard is just one piece of the puzzle; deterministic marshalling is another equally important one

aso
2016-10-28 14:48
ASN.1 seems to tick both boxes

aso
2016-10-28 14:48
does anyone know how ASN.1 relates to protobufs when it comes to i) speed of un/marshalling and ii) marshalling metadata overhead?

jyellick
2016-10-28 14:52
I think @simon did a test, and ASN.1 was noticeably slower. Whether it's enough that we care, or makes up for the nested unmarshaling of the protos, I'm not sure

garisingh
2016-10-28 14:53
(funny - was about to basically say the same thing)

adc
2016-10-28 14:53
is there a clean way to patch the protobuf to have deterministic serialization?

garisingh
2016-10-28 14:53
of course the nice thing about protobufs is that they do support a nice compatibility layer

garisingh
2016-10-28 14:54
@adc - the google stuff is deterministic today they just make no guarantee nor require it in their spec

muralisr
2016-10-28 14:54
regardless of what we end up using, just want to point out that theres encapsulation confined to protos/utils and externals dont/shouldnt deal with structure internals. as long as we keep it that way it shoulnt be too hard to move to any format

muralisr
2016-10-28 14:56
my way of saying we dont have to change immediately . and perhaps we could review https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2081/ with that in mind ?

adc
2016-10-28 14:56
+1

jyellick
2016-10-28 14:58
Re determinism: I _think_ one of the ideas for protobufs is that they want to allow for messages to be built incrementally, rather than a `Marshal` on a completed structure, they want to support adding fields one at a time (in arbitrary order) to do the marshaling incrementally for applications where that makes sense. Maybe I am making this up, but believe I read this somewhere.

garisingh
2016-10-28 15:01
from some dude on stack overflow: ``` In general, the same data will serialize in exactly the same way. However, this is not guaranteed by the protobuf specifications. For example, the following differences in encoding are allowable and must decode to the same result in all conforming libraries: Encoding fields in different order than the tag number order. Encoding packed fields as unpacked. Encoding integers as longer varint byte sequences than needed. Encoding same (non-repeated) field multiple times. Probably others. ```

garisingh
2016-10-28 15:02
`Note that most protobuf implementations (including the official ones) will always write protos in a canonical format as long as there are no unknown fields present.`

aso
2016-10-28 15:11
@garisingh @jyellick : is the information about "what marshalling scheme was used for this chain" even stored somewhere on the chain? should it be?

jyellick
2016-10-28 15:13
@aso That's a tricky one, since we'd have to define an encoding for how to store the encoding. (To your original question, no, not stored anywhere)

aso
2016-10-28 15:15
in some crypto schemes, the encoding of "what crypto algorithm was used to encrypt me" was the code of the cipher itself. It's a way, perhaps not the best. I believe it was done in the context of "crypto that you can decrypt in NN years from now"

jyellick
2016-10-28 15:17
I still feel like you need some foreknowledge. If it's code, how is it encoded? At some point, you have to pick an initial representation

aso
2016-10-28 15:17
true that

aso
2016-10-28 15:17
so we should just assume that the encoding is known, and fixed forever for the entire chain

adc
2016-10-28 15:20
yes, the initial representation is what is provided by a Turing machine :slightly_smiling_face:

adc
2016-10-28 15:22
also that is problematic, actually :disappointed:

adc
2016-10-28 15:23
we need a trusted setup assumption then

jyellick
2016-10-28 15:23
I would think making an assumption that the chain encoding can never change drastically simplifies our life. I'm probably just ignorant of their existence, but I'm not sure of any other sort of data stream which changes the base encoding midway through. I would think if we wanted to switch to a new format, you would want to re-encode the whole chain.

adc
2016-10-28 15:23
+1

adc
2016-10-28 15:24
in that case, an hard fork is the way to go

binhn
2016-10-28 18:41
@simon @jyellick re ASN.1, Ive found this interesting thread https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/protobuf/eNAZlnPKVW4 > Protobuf to be a simpler, cleaner, smaller, faster, more robust and easier-to-understand than ASN.1 > memory allocations, thus both speeding performance and decreasing the memory footprint of our product by 50-70%

jyellick
2016-10-28 20:11
@garisingh @binhn @adc @aso @elli @kostas Per the discussion from earlier, the orderer is going to define a base transaction proto which the fabric can extend. For the base transaction/message/something type, we need: 1. A message which contains a signature and a thing that signature is over. In the fabric protos, this is a `SignedTransaction` 2. A message which represents the 'thing' that the signature is over, this should include a payload and a header, this is similar to, but slightly different from `Transaction`/`TransactionAction` because it assumes and requires a single header, which is at the top level and not nested more deeply. 3. A message which is the header to prevent replay attacks and provide the identity for the signing cert. We need to pick a name for these things 1. @muralisr proposes the name `Envelope`, the changeset I had pushed called this `SignedData`, I'd also suggest `SignedMessage` 2. @muralisr proposes the name `Payload`, the changeset I had pushed called this `SignableData`, I'd also suggest `SignableMessage` or `Message` 3. @muralisr proposes the name `Header`, the changeset I pushed called this `SignatureHeader`, I'd also suggest `MessageHeader` Personally, I'm fine with @muralisr's proposed names, the names already in the changeset, or moving to the alternate `Message` based ones, or even some other names. But, I wanted to try to get the names right so that I can minimize the amount of rebasing required. Opinions?

binhn
2016-10-28 21:13
Message would collide with another general message struct that peer has. I am fine with murali's

aso
2016-10-29 07:42
@jyellick sorry I couldn't join the rest of the discussion yesterday. Let me see if I understand correctly. How far would this mod of fabric.proto go towards accommodating your requirements? ``` message SignedTransaction { bytes transactionBytes = 1; bytes signature = 2; } message Transaction2 { enum Type { UNDEFINED = 0; CONFIG = 1; CHAINCODE = 2; } // controls how this transaction has been assembled. If it's CHAINCODE // it has been assembled via the proposal/response/endorsement flow Type type = 1; int32 version = 2; google.protobuf.Timestamp timestamp = 3; // payload is: // - an array of TransactionAction if type == CHAINCODE // - anything you want it to be if type == CONFIG bytes payload = 3; } ```

aso
2016-10-29 08:04
you'll notice that there are now two type fields: 1) in `Transaction2` in the code box up there 2) in `Header` (`protos/fabric_transaction_header.proto`) If the type field of `Transaction2` is `CHAINCODE`, it means that the message is to be interpreted as one that has followed the proposal/response/endorsement flow, and hence will have a `TransactionAction` with endorsements etc. If that type is different, it signifies that a different flow was followed (which is presumably what you wanted for the config work). The second type field in `Header` controls what specific "thing" has been endorsed via the proposal/response/endorsement flow. Your thoughts?

crazybit
2016-10-29 08:52
refer to the SignedTranasaction data structure ,looks it only supports single signature

crazybit
2016-10-29 08:52
will consider to support multiple signs?

aso
2016-10-29 10:42
the "normal" proposal/response/endorsement flow does support multiple signature to the extent that multiple endorsements may be present in the tx payload. In that case though, the tx is still only signed by a single entity, which is the one that requested the action in the first place by issuing (and signing) the proposal message. What it means for a transaction to be signed by multiple entities is not yet clear (at least to me), nor is the use-case that needs it

aso
2016-10-29 10:42
@crazybit ^^

jyellick
2016-10-29 14:53
@aso Honestly, extending the transaction as you described makes things harder for me to wrap my head around, and makes the format more complicated which is I think, the wrong direction. I think it makes more sense to start from the simple envelope message described above. Although I think it would cause some duplication, you could embed the entire fabric transaction in its payload if you wanted. But from a base transaction point of view, a payload, a header, and a signature over the two seems standard, intuitive, and easy to extend.

garisingh
2016-10-29 17:46
@jyellick - forgetting about the actual format for a moment, can we discuss the the flow of "messages" in and out of the ordering service for a minute (probably a rehash but I think I am missing something). Here's what I mean: 1) In simplest terms, the ordering service implements two "APIs" - broadcast and deliver - which are implemented as GRPC services 2) broadcast / delivery are partitioned into "channels" - i.e a broadcast client ("producer") specifies a channel, the ordering service orders (and batches) broadcast messages by channel and then delivers them to deliver clients ("consumers") who have asked for messages on that channel 3) the ordering service supports setting access control lists on "channels" for both "broadcast" and "delivery" 4) the ordering service will "enforce" access control by extracting the certificate used to sign a broadcast message and/or deliver request Hopefully at a high level the above is (mostly) correct So: 1) A broadcast client ("producer") needs to "sign" the message it sends to the ordering service. The ordering service can verify the signature and use the signing certificate to check that the sender was allowed to broadcast to the specified channel. The "producer" would need to provide the channel, a payload, signature and its public certificate. Ideally the ordering service does not care at all about what's in the payload. Let's say the ordering service is set to use a batch size of 50 for a given channel. So after it receives 50 verified/authorized broadcast messages, it will create a batch of those and "deliver" to authorized "consumers". QUESTION: what is actually in the batch? assuming the simple "channel, payload, signature<payload>,signer-certificate" content, is it batching the whole thing or is it actually simply creating batches of the "payload" ?

garisingh
2016-10-29 17:49
(notice at this point I don't care what's actually in the <payload>)

jyellick
2016-10-29 18:04
> what is actually in the batch? My inclination is to include exactly the messages that came in into the batch, not just the payloads

garisingh
2016-10-29 18:19
got it

garisingh
2016-10-29 18:19
I am good

garisingh
2016-10-29 18:22
your partner in crime set me straight :wink:

muralisr
2016-10-31 17:17

muralisr
2016-10-31 17:17

simon
2016-10-31 17:17

simon
2016-10-31 17:18
not a non-decision decision

adrianhopebailie
2016-10-31 20:55
late to the party here but fwiw we decided to go with the newer (and nicer in our opinion) OER encoding and ASN.1 for the Interledger project. ASN.1 gives you unambiguous data structures with deterministic encoded content and OER encoding is more flexible and generally simpler and nicer to use than PER and more compact than BER. Its worth noting though that you can affect your encoding or decoding performance by simply designing the messages differently. Choosing an specific encoding format doesnt magically make streaming encoders/decoders faster :slightly_smiling_face:

adrianhopebailie
2016-10-31 20:56
http://www.oss.com/asn1/resources/books-whitepapers-pubs/Overview%20of%20OER.pdf

garisingh
2016-10-31 20:56
^^^ interesting (especially the OER)

adrianhopebailie
2016-10-31 20:57
bad news is you may have to write some of the encoding/decoding stuff yourself

adrianhopebailie
2016-10-31 20:57
good news is that a lot has been done by the interledger contributors already :slightly_smiling_face:

adrianhopebailie
2016-10-31 20:58
https://github.com/interledgerjs/oer-utils

adrianhopebailie
2016-10-31 21:03
Last comment on the encoding subject is that we are also looking at CBOR which is getting a lot of traction lately and is being used in a number of projects at IETF

adc
2016-11-01 10:15
@jyellick So, if I got correctly atomicbroadcast.Payload looks like the protos.TransactionAction

adc
2016-11-01 10:15
now I understand your proposal of starting from the configuration and then generalize.

adc
2016-11-01 10:16
Again, if I get it correctly, you wanted to have atomicbroadcast.Payload as the most basic transaction unit

adc
2016-11-01 10:16
and then potentially compose this to have more complex transactions, right?

aso
2016-11-01 10:44
A potenital approach that @muralisr, @jyellick and I discussed was to converge on ``` Envelope |\_ Signature \_ Payload |\_ TransactionHeader (MESSAGE = 0; CONFIGURATION_TRANSACTION = 1; CONFIGURATION_ITEM = 2; ENDORSER_TRANSACTION = 3;) \_ Transaction \_ TransactionAction (1...n) |\_ ActionHeader \_ ChaincodeActionPayload ```

aso
2016-11-01 10:45
for the normal proposal/endorsement flow

aso
2016-11-01 10:46
and ``` Envelope |\_ Signature \_ Payload |\_ TransactionHeader (MESSAGE = 0; CONFIGURATION_TRANSACTION = 1; CONFIGURATION_ITEM = 2; ENDORSER_TRANSACTION = 3;) \_ Configuration ``` for configuration messages

aso
2016-11-01 10:46
`TransactionHeader` might look like ``` message TransactionHeader { int32 version = 1; Type type = 2; bytes creator = 3; bytes chainID = 4; } ```

aso
2016-11-01 10:47
which is fine as far as the endorsement flow is concerned because it factors all fields that have to be common to all actions in a transaction

adc
2016-11-01 12:32
which header will you use then in the Proposal?

aso
2016-11-01 12:33
One possible way would be ``` SignedProposal |\_ Signature (signature on the Proposal message by the creator specified in the header) \_ Proposal |\_ ProposalHeader (the header for this proposal containing both TransactionHeader and ActionHeader) |\_ ChaincodeProposalPayload (the payload for this proposal) \_ ChaincodeAction (the actions for this proposal - optional for a proposal) ``` where ``` message ProposalHeader { bytes txHeaderBytes = 1; bytes actHeaderBytes = 2; } ```

aso
2016-11-01 12:34
and ``` message TransactionHeader { int32 version = 1; Type type = 2; bytes creator = 3; bytes chainID = 4; } message ActionHeader { int32 version = 1; google.protobuf.Timestamp timestamp = 2; Type type = 3; bytes nonce = 4; bytes extensions = 5; } ```

adc
2016-11-01 13:03
+1

jyellick
2016-11-01 13:13
Sounds like everyone's on board with this new scheme then?

adc
2016-11-01 13:14

aso
2016-11-01 13:15

aso
2016-11-01 13:15

aso
2016-11-01 13:16

muralisr
2016-11-01 13:20

adc
2016-11-01 14:21

adc
2016-11-01 14:21
what's the difference between CONFIGURATION_TX and CONFIGURATION_ITEM, for example?

aso
2016-11-01 14:22
that's meant to be the enumeration of types

aso
2016-11-01 14:22
chaincodes will have type equal to ENDORSER_TRANSACTION

aso
2016-11-01 14:23
whereas config will have one of CONFIGURATION_TRANSACTION, CONFIGURATION_ITEM and possibly more

elli
2016-11-01 14:23
and what is the diff between configuration-transaction, and configuration-item?

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:23
@adc I had a comment on the changeset about documenting this further. `CONFIGURATION_TRANSACTION` is intended to be made up of `CONFIGURATION_ITEM`s. I did not document extensively for the moment, because the usage/implementation of this was not in the changeset

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:24
The idea being that each configuration item will need to be a set of signed data, and the whole configuration transaction is made up of many of these

aso
2016-11-01 14:25
@jyellick so you just need one type and not two then? if so, sorry about the confusion

elli
2016-11-01 14:25
so, this would be a way to atomically commit a bunch of config changes that may need endorsement from different or same entities?

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:26
@elli Yes @aso a `CONFIGURATION_TRANSACTION` would have a payload data of a repeated number of `Envelopes` which would all be of type `CONFIGURATION_ITEM` which would have a payload data of the actual config object

adc
2016-11-01 14:26
got it, okay!

adc
2016-11-01 14:26
aha, nested payloads?

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:27

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:29
@elli Somewhat, though all it needs is endorsements @adc Possibly, though I'm not sure of a way to do it less so. But reconfiguration should be relatively infrequent, it does not need to be an especially high speed path.

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:29
@kostas In `ab.proto` in the code you pulled with the new tran format

kostas
2016-11-01 14:30

aso
2016-11-01 14:31
@jyellick will you have nonces inside your `Configuration` message somewhere to protect against replays?

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:31
@aso Yes, I intend to use sequence numbers

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:33
Would like to discuss the replay potentials here more generally too for the top level message and how we detect it inexpensively

elli
2016-11-01 14:33
@aso, @jyellick: so instead of having the transaction header content as part of the action header (included in each transaction action) you made transaction header sort of common header shifted higher up. Am I correct to say this?

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:33
Yes, I would say so

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:33
I think we will likely need a timestamp or nonce or some other thing at the top level for replay

aso
2016-11-01 14:34
that's tricky for chaincodes

aso
2016-11-01 14:34
each action must have a common "top-level" header

aso
2016-11-01 14:34
if there's a nonce in there, it must be repeated

aso
2016-11-01 14:34
which is no big deal from a security perspective because the internal header will guarantee freshness

adc
2016-11-01 14:34
