elli
2016-11-01 14:41
Btw, @jyellick, @aso, is there a reason why you need to specify a configuration item structure so clearly in the protobuf instead of, e.g., having it contain a jason format representation of config changes?

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:45
@elli I'm not sure what you mean. The configuration structure was made to withstand replay and validate against signature policies, and is otherwise essentially key/value pairs where the key is a string, and the value is arbitrary bytes.

simon
2016-11-01 14:47
so values are opaque?

simon
2016-11-01 14:47
and untyped?

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:47
For now, yes.

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:47
They do have a type

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:47
But only a high level service type, like "This is fabric config" or "This is kafka config"

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:48
But the mapping of keys to underlying data types is not defined by the proto

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:48
For `Policy` type config, the structure is well defined in the proto

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:49
Nothing prevents us from more formally defining the config structures for other types, but it is generic for now.

elli
2016-11-01 14:50
Well replay has to do with the inclusion of a nonce, that to my understanding you discussed that is included in the tx header somewhere no?

kostas
2016-11-01 14:51
There is a nonce in the payload's header (in the envelope).

aso
2016-11-01 14:52
although replay attacks can occur at multiple levels. I could replay an entire tx, or only a `Configuration` message, or some signed message inside of it - we need to make sure that nothing can be replayed

elli
2016-11-01 14:52
But I am asking about the specific way you use to represent candidate configuration changes inside configurationitem.

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:52
Protecting the config from replay is relatively easy, by requiring that a sequence number is incremented, and rejecting old sequence numbers. I'm more interested in preventing replay in a performant way for more generic transactions. Because we have unlinkability between messages, it seems hard to do efficiently.

elli
2016-11-01 14:52
Well if the client wants to replay a transation, nothing can prevent him.

elli
2016-11-01 14:53
And since the client/creator is the one signing the tx i think we are safe on this aspect no?

aso
2016-11-01 14:53
I don't think there is a client in the case of config transaction

elli
2016-11-01 14:53
There has to be. The one triggering the config change.

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:54
@aso There is, there must be. Someone must inject the new config into the system and sign this message

elli
2016-11-01 14:54
Unless you refer this is part of config item.

elli
2016-11-01 14:54
The signature that is, and creator.

aso
2016-11-01 14:55
@jyellick right, although I guess it wouldn't be a normal client of the system but more like an admin - but I get your point, there is a creator always

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:55
Yes, I would expect often this would be some admin running a CLI tool, though in the channel creation case, it may be more automated

elli
2016-11-01 14:57
For replay attack, one would need to use epochs in transactions, as discussed in the past with Chet and @adc, and @aso. Replays of transactions strictly speaking would not cause a huge issue due to version dependencies.

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:58
It is more of a DoS concern for me

elli
2016-11-01 14:59
For DoS, you may have epoch numbers in transactions (chosen again by the submitting peer) included in tx header and only allow tx-es with the appropriate epoch number...

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:59
How do you know the appropriate epoch number?

jyellick
2016-11-01 14:59
(Especially if it is chosen by the peer)

elli
2016-11-01 14:59
But anyway, my question was referring to the config item structure :slightly_smiling_face:

elli
2016-11-01 15:00
@vukolic mentioned that there will be some clock

kostas
2016-11-01 15:01
There is a buffer for the epoch numbers,. As long as it's not older than, say, X epochs it can be processed.

aso
2016-11-01 15:01
why not block height?

elli
2016-11-01 15:01
in the ordering service. Is this still the possibility? If so epochs can be changing per specific clock cycles of that clock, or can be set er channel per number of blockk, etc.

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:01
@aso I like that, makes much more sense to me

kostas
2016-11-01 15:01
@aso Block height was the more natural fit to me.

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:01
With the config item structure, we have a sequence number associated with each configuration. which must be incremented by exactly one to be valid. This prevents replay

elli
2016-11-01 15:01
right, e.g., epoch number can be set to increase per X blocks.

kostas
2016-11-01 15:01
I just went with Elli's term.

aso
2016-11-01 15:01
got it

kostas
2016-11-01 15:02
> The configuration manager will verify that all configuration changes satisfy system policy, that all configuration changes have a LastModified field equal to Sequence, that no configuration has been deleted without corresponding authorization, that the configuration is well formed, and that some configuration item corresponds to the new ConfigurationEnvelope sequence number.

kostas
2016-11-01 15:03
If all configuration changes have a LastModified field equal to Sequence, why is the last check in that quote needed?

simon
2016-11-01 15:08
why a seqno?

simon
2016-11-01 15:08
why not a "lastconfig" hash pointer?

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:09
> If all configuration changes have a LastModified field equal to Sequence, why is the last check in that quote needed? In case the configuration tx doesn't actually contain any changes

simon
2016-11-01 15:09
how will a new config be authorized? i really hope it will require an admin sign the new config transaction on an airgapped machine

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:10
> why not a "lastconfig" hash pointer? I considered this, sequence number seemed smaller and easier without any obvious disadvantages

simon
2016-11-01 15:10
okay

kostas
2016-11-01 15:10
Why don't you just write that "all configuration items have a LastModified field equal to Sequence" and be done with it?

elli
2016-11-01 15:11
So you would not have the need of paralellizing config changes?

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:12
> how will a new config be authorized? Each config entry has a modification policy tied to it dictating which signatures are required to modify it >i really hope it will require an admin sign the new config transaction on an airgapped machine That seems like a good idea to me, and generally I would expect to require signatures from multiple admins.

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:13
> Why don't you just write that "all configuration items have a LastModified field equal to Sequence" and be done with it? The idea is that in general, sets of users will only be authorized to modify a subset of the configuration, it is to support changing only pieces of the configuration. The set of peer admins is authorized to change the set of peer orgs, they are not authorized to modify the orderer config, so they cannot change the sequence number of the orderer config and still have the signatures be valid.

kostas
2016-11-01 15:15
Oh, this goes back to the fact that a ConfigurationEnvelope cannot just say "I want to modify this and that" and call it a day, it needs to carry Entries for all the configuration keys that apply, regardless of whether it modifies them or not.

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:16
> So you would not have the need of paralellizing config changes? I've been thinking a lot about this. We could make the sequence number local to each config item, which would allow for total parallelization, but, this invites someone splitting up a transaction which was meant to be committed atomically and picking pieces of it.

kostas
2016-11-01 15:16
_All_ configuration for a chain.

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:17
> Oh, this goes back to the fact that a ConfigurationEnvelope cannot just say "I want to modify this and that" and call it a day, it needs to carry Entries for all the configuration keys that apply, regardless of whether it modifies them or not. I've also been thinking maybe we should allow submission of type `CONFIGURATION_ITEM` which would then generate the new `CONFIGURATION_TRANSACTION` based on the current state, but am not sold that this is a good idea yet.

kostas
2016-11-01 15:24
The signatures in the `ConfigurationEntry` are of type `Envelope`. I assume that the `Data` field of the `Payload` in that `Envelope` is set to the `Configuration` of the `ConfigurationEntry` in question?

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:25
The data of the payload should be the hash of the configuration (so as not to repeat the configuration over and over again)

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:26
Properly documenting this is on my TODO list, and was planned for when I reworked the configuration to sit on top of the new Envelope type

kostas
2016-11-01 15:26
That makes sense.

kostas
2016-11-01 15:27
That's also badly needed. I'm going through the changeset, and I'm not sure if all of this is properly documented elsewhere, dead obvious, or about to be documented.

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:28
So the changeset you are reviewing is meant to be about the new base `Envelope` and friends format

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:28
The configuration stuff was always a somewhat temporary data structure, designed to allow the proving out of the concept and the writing of code. It wasn't clear whether it would be rewritten on top of the fabric transaction, or some other thing at the time. Now that we know what 'the other thing' is, it can be formalized

kostas
2016-11-01 15:29
The changeset that I'm going through is a chance for me to catch up on all the latest message-related developments honestly. I've stopped commenting there so as not to pollute it with out-of-scope comments.

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:29
Since the form was going to change, extensive documentation didn't seem worthwhile at the time, but obviously this needs to be well documented going forward.

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:30
So what is your opinion on the parallelization of configuration updates? Should there be a global sequence number, ala the `ConfigurationEnvelope` or should we simply require that the `Configuration` `lastModified` be incremented sequentially

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:39
Another option I considered, was to make submitted `CONFIGURATION_TRANSACTION` act as an overlay. Basically, require sequential modification of each config item, and if a config change has 'version dependencies' include those dependent `CONFIGURATION_ITEM`s in the `CONFIGURATION_TRANSACTION`. The transaction is processed by the orderer into the fully populated transaction only if all of the dependencies match. But this is definitely more complex.

kostas
2016-11-01 15:40
I haven't thought much about it, but I am probably against parallelization, mainly because (I think?) it allows mixing and matching of items that were not meant to be grouped togethere.

simon
2016-11-01 15:40
what does that mean

simon
2016-11-01 15:41
parallelisation

kostas
2016-11-01 15:41
It also seems like an issue we shouldn't be concerned about. How often do we expect these to happen?

kostas
2016-11-01 15:41
Why parallelize them?

kostas
2016-11-01 15:41
Yeah, exactly.

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:43
Parallelization meaning, should we allow two configuration updates to be created in parallel, but not together, and have them each be able to be submitted and processed. Or, should the first one in 'win' and the second one be reconstructed.

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:43
In general, I would expect that reconfiguration should be infrequent and require significant human intervention.

kostas
2016-11-01 15:45
> Parallelization meaning, should we allow two configuration updates to be created in parallel, but not together, and have them each be able to be submitted and processed. Or, should the first one in 'win' and the second one be reconstructed.

kostas
2016-11-01 15:45
This doesn't make sense to me.

kostas
2016-11-01 15:45
Example?

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:45
Sure

kostas
2016-11-01 15:45
I thought by parallelization you referred to individual configuration items.

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:45
I do

kostas
2016-11-01 15:46
But now you're talking about configuration transactions where the first one wins? This is why this doesn't make sense to me.

simon
2016-11-01 15:47
ah all of this is about channels?

simon
2016-11-01 15:47
because orderer config really shouldn't change often

kostas
2016-11-01 15:48
All types of configs.

simon
2016-11-01 15:48
are we overengineering?

kostas
2016-11-01 15:48
Always.

simon
2016-11-01 15:48
sure seems like it

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:50
The current configuration looks like this: ``` SeqNo: 7, [ A: {LastModified: 5, Val: foo} B: {LastModified: 7, Val: bar}] ``` The entities in control of A and in control of B both want to update the values. Today, the flow goes as: A entities create: ``` SeqNo: 8, [ A: {LastModified: 8, Val: foo2} B: {LastModified: 7, Val: bar}] ``` B entities create: ``` SeqNo: 8, [ A: {LastModified: 5, Val: foo} B: {LastModified: 8, Val: bar2}] ``` Then, whoever submits first would be adopted, and the second would fail because it would be attempting to backlevel the other's config. However, consider instead doing away with the top level SeqNo, then you could have ``` [ A: {LastModified: 5, Val: foo} B: {LastModified: 7, Val: bar}] ``` The entities in control of A and in control of B both want to update the values. The new flow would go as: A entities create: ``` Item{ A: {LastModified: 6, Val: foo2} } ``` B entities create: ``` Item{ B: {LastModified: 8, Val: bar2}} ``` And when submitted, they both would apply cleanly.

kostas
2016-11-01 15:52
I get it now. Good idea, but would be low on my priority list, as I don't expect this to be a significant problem where collisions happen.

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:54
The thing that got me thinking about collisions was the DoS possibility, where some group starts constantly changing the config to prevent another group from being able to modify their own config.

kostas
2016-11-01 15:54
But on the background, isn't this CONFIG_ITEM translated to a CONFIG_TX that reads the current state?

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:55
Correct.

simon
2016-11-01 15:56
this is a permissioned network, no?

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:56
The reality is, that this sort of attack seems unlikely, since it would be attributable, and usually requires signatures from multiple parties. Still, if someone misconfigured their system to allow a single signer to modify something, then it would be annoying to fix.

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:56
Probably not a problem worth worrying too much about.

simon
2016-11-01 15:57
not at all about

simon
2016-11-01 15:57
again, airgapped machines with certificates, etc.

jyellick
2016-11-01 15:58
Yes, at the end of the day if the admins go and lose their keys, then there is no limit to the bad things that an attacker can do to the network.

jyellick
2016-11-01 16:06
@elli @aso @adc Then for the new transaction format, should we add an epoch into the top level header and leverage exactly that for replay prevention? Do we also need a nonce to prevent some sort of signature attacks, or is that only for replay?

adc
2016-11-01 16:07
a nonce might be used also at signing time by certain schemes with the guarantee that it is unique

jyellick
2016-11-01 16:09
I obviously defer on these crypto related decision, just trying to nail down everything that needs to be in this outer header. Per the changeset, there is the timestamp and nonce, it sounds then like this should be an epoch and nonce?

jyellick
2016-11-01 16:10
(Or, do we want to leave the timestamp for some reason?)

adc
2016-11-01 16:11
I'm fine with epoch and nonce. timestamp is not reliable

elli
2016-11-01 16:11
+1

kostas
2016-11-01 16:12
Remember that Marko wanted a timestamp for the "raw ledger" batches, and had suggested a mechanism with skews, etc.

jyellick
2016-11-01 16:12
And just to be clear, the nonce would not need to be verified against some 'set of used nonces' to validate the signature, instead it would be the client's job to guarantee the uniqueness or lose security. Instead, the only replay detection the orderer would need to perform is to validate the epoch which would be based on the block height

elli
2016-11-01 16:12
@kostas this was i think the clock that i referred to before i think :slightly_smiling_face:

adc
2016-11-01 16:12
ah, okay

kostas
2016-11-01 16:12
@elli Yes.

adc
2016-11-01 16:12
and what's the purpose for having that in the raw ledger?

adc
2016-11-01 16:13
@jyellick sounds good so far

jyellick
2016-11-01 16:15
Great, thanks @adc

kostas
2016-11-01 19:20
What's not clear to me yet is this:

kostas
2016-11-01 19:21
How do we go from a `CONFIG_TRANSACTION` that specifies the creation of a new channel to a genesis block for that channel?

kostas
2016-11-01 19:21
And I mean from a low-level, code perspective.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:22
Do we leverage the `bootstrap` package that's out there? Because if that's the case, the `bootstrap.Helper` interface will need to be extended with one more method that allows us to load config data into the helper.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:23
If the `bootstrap` package is not used, I want to know what we have in mind.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:24
This affects the way I'm rewriting the Kafka orderer for multiple channels, since I'm touching on that path.

jyellick
2016-11-01 19:27
I've actually wanted to discuss this with you, as I had a conversation with @elli around this and she brought up an interesting point about channel creation being potentially non-deterministic which makes everything a little trickier.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:28
Cool, shoot.

jyellick
2016-11-01 19:30
So, consider for a moment, that a channel creation request is received (as a configuration transaction). My original thought had been "have the orderers implicitly form a channel and consense about the genesis block for this channel". This was to prevent two different people from trying to create the same channel at once with different genesis material.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:31
If you don't mind, can we make things explicit?

jyellick
2016-11-01 19:31
Sure

kostas
2016-11-01 19:31
I want us to expand on the "have the orders implicitly form a channel" clause.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:31
Which brings me back to this question I guess: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/archives/fabric-crypto/p1478028015001540

kostas
2016-11-01 19:32
How do you get to a genesis block?

kostas
2016-11-01 19:32
`bootstrap` to the rescue, or something else? And if it's something else, what?

jyellick
2016-11-01 19:37
I was trying to side-step that for the moment, because the punchline about the non-determinism at the end I think informs the decision here. I'm not really sure what > `bootstrap` to the rescue means, but the format is not that complicated, it can be generated either by paring down the system chain config, or building it manually.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:39
`bootstrap` to the rescue is a reference to the expanded form of this statement, 10 lines up: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/archives/fabric-crypto/p1478028157001543

kostas
2016-11-01 19:40
I want to narrow down the interfaces, and figure out whether a new package/abstraction is needed.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:40
For instance:

kostas
2016-11-01 19:40
> it can be generated either by paring down the system chain config, or building it manually.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:41
I'm looking for a decomposition of that statement. What does build it manually mean?

jyellick
2016-11-01 19:41
Ah, okay, sorry, I didn't realize by "the `bootstrap` package" you meant the little shim I had added to allow the genesis block to be specified at runtime. I think no, I would not expect for this package to be re-used for creating a genesis block, it was more meant as a way to statically specify one for testing, or to load a real one from a file.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:42
Great, so the `bootstrap` package is out of this conversation.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:43
So, I've got a `CONFIG_TRANSACTION`. And let's assume it passes all the validation/policy checks.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:43
What's next? Think lifecycle of this message.

jyellick
2016-11-01 19:44
Okay, so, going by the flows I've seen. Given this TX, the App sends it via a broadcast to ordering.

jyellick
2016-11-01 19:44
The orderer recognizes this as a configuration for a channel it hasn't seen, so, assuming that it is well formed, appropriately signed, etc. It creates a new channel with the parameters specified by the TX.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:45
And then it needs to post the genesis block (via broadcast) to that channel.

jyellick
2016-11-01 19:45
The app on the other side is polling on `Deliver` waiting for the channel to exist. Once it does, it gets back a genesis block with the config tx it submitted, and it can give this block to the peers to subscribe to the channel.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:45
But you're glossing over my question :simple_smile:

jyellick
2016-11-01 19:45
> And then it needs to post the genesis block (via broadcast) to that channel. Yes, sorry to omit this

kostas
2016-11-01 19:46
How do we actually get that genesis block is my question. Everything else, I'm totally fine with.

jyellick
2016-11-01 19:47
Well, in the simplest route, the orderer which receives the transaction simply creates a new block by setting the payload to the config tx, setting the hashes appropriately, setting the block number to 0, and that's it?

jyellick
2016-11-01 19:48
I guess I'm not sure why the 'creating the block' is hard, we have to do this for a normal reconfiguration tx, not just channel creation

kostas
2016-11-01 19:49
I didn't say anything about it being hard. This is my only goal here: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/archives/fabric-crypto/p1478029206001560

jyellick
2016-11-01 19:50
I understand the goal, but there are larger unresolved holes that need to be resolved first.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:50
Related to that path?

jyellick
2016-11-01 19:51
Yes.

jyellick
2016-11-01 19:52
For instance, does the genesis block of the channel redefine all of the same parameters as the 'system chain'?

kostas
2016-11-01 19:53
You'll need to expand on "all of the same parameters as the 'system chain'."

jyellick
2016-11-01 19:53
For instance, in the PBFT case, does the channel define `f` `K` `L` etc.

binhn
2016-11-01 19:54
just jumping in here - and sure lacking context - i think for simplicity (now) we should assume channel is independent so each should have its own complete config block

kostas
2016-11-01 19:57
You cannot make the right call with what you have right now, can you? For instance, the support of multiple channels in PBFT is still fuzzy. So complete config blocks is the right way to go. Depending on what the system runs on (e.g. PBFT), the orderer logic should figure out whether you're trying to overlap a config key (e.g. `f`) that you shouldn't, and reject it.

kostas
2016-11-01 19:58
Complete config blocks seems like the safer choice.

binhn
2016-11-01 20:02
we could allow some common config to effect all channels by specifying a nil channel for example, removing a CA member

jyellick
2016-11-01 20:03
I generally agree that complete config blocks is a safer choice, but, then I see there being essentially two options: 1. The client is responsible for filling out all of the fields of the transaction, likely by taking the system chain config, removing the signatures, and modifying the chainID on all of the configuration items. Then, the orderer ensures that things match, and then processes the transaction normally. The advantage to this is that it makes the order's life very easy, but obviously pushes complexity to the client. It also loses some flexibility which I'll mention in a moment. 2. The client is responsible for filling out all of the fields which it is entitled to modify, leaving the rest for the ordering service to populate. The ordering service then completes the configuration with the parameters it is authorized to do, and creates the final configuration transaction. The downside to this is some limited additional complexity at the orderer, but it does allow for neat things, like given a set of 100 different pbft nodes, at channel creation time, the ordering service could pick 4 of them for the channel.

kostas
2016-11-01 20:04
Waiting to hear the flexibility lost with approach number 1.

jyellick
2016-11-01 20:05
The last sentence of number 2. If the orderer wants to specify a different configuration for that chain, configuration which the client cannot know in advance

kostas
2016-11-01 20:08
But that is not even a requirement (that I know of), and for all we know, this may be a feature that nobody is after.

kostas
2016-11-01 20:08
So we're adding complexity to a core component for something that is of questionable value.

kostas
2016-11-01 20:08
I am against this. (And approach number 2 as a result.)

jyellick
2016-11-01 20:09
That's fine. I think 1 is probably the correct direction, but I think these things need to be nailed down first.

binhn
2016-11-01 20:11
i think we should separate configs into 2 buckets: 1) client can specify/modify 2) managed by the ordering service

jyellick
2016-11-01 20:11
IE option 2, I think?

kostas
2016-11-01 20:12
I don't see why this is option 2?

kostas
2016-11-01 20:13
Option 1 along with logic on the orderer that rejects the config if tries to modify a key managed by the ordering service would work, no?

kostas
2016-11-01 20:13
Basically: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/archives/fabric-crypto/p1478030245001590

binhn
2016-11-01 20:14
right, client would never know about those configs , so i think like the list of orderers should not be allowed to change by the client

jyellick
2016-11-01 20:15
But then the thing you advocating for @binhn would be that the peer does _not_ specify the complete config tx, that the orderer supplements it somehow?

kostas
2016-11-01 20:16
Why would the client *not* know about these configs? They're in the system chain genesis block that it can access.

binhn
2016-11-01 20:16
right, the rest is considered fixed, supplied by the orderer to fill in the config block

binhn
2016-11-01 20:17
we dont document them as you said, if modified, orderer would reject

jyellick
2016-11-01 20:18
Okay, so then the client _does_ specify the entire config, but it does not understand the orderer config, simply copies it verbatim. Which would be (1) which I support.

kostas
2016-11-01 20:19
(I honestly think that Binh _just_ made the case for option 2.)

kostas
2016-11-01 20:24
To me the simplest way of going at is the orderer saying: "Give me _everything_ I need to know about the new channel. (Internally, if this config is to overwrite a key which for, whatever reason, we keep locked, the config is rejected with the appropriate error message.)" Maybe I'm biased, but this feels easier and a better design than saying "Give me something, and I'll fill in the rest with what applies currently."

jyellick
2016-11-01 20:26
I agree, additionally, this also easily keeps the original attribution for the channel creation, because as soon as we modify the config tx, the signature over it in the submission is invalidated.

binhn
2016-11-01 20:28
if we envision the client gets the config block and modifies it, i am ok with that, but they still need to read the doc to figure out which values can be modified

kostas
2016-11-01 20:28
(I guess the key word there being "easily" right? Because for that specific concern, I would assume that the signature of the `ConfigurationEntry` that calls for the channel creation remains, and can be linked to the creator.)

kostas
2016-11-01 20:29
@binhn But that is always going to be the case.

jyellick
2016-11-01 20:29
The configuration items are all typed

jyellick
2016-11-01 20:29
Which should make it fairly obvious, "Do not modify the ones typed orderer"

binhn
2016-11-01 20:30
> But that is always going to be the case. :slightly_smiling_face:

binhn
2016-11-01 20:32
why wouldnt we just have a json object, which we define the structure, and the client gets it, modifies it, and submits it back as a payload of the config transaction, the client signs the payload

jyellick
2016-11-01 20:33
I think that's more or less the plan, just proto instead of json

jyellick
2016-11-01 20:34
Could be rendered as JSON I suppose, but I'm not sure what the purpose would be, it's all machine manipulated?

binhn
2016-11-01 20:35
json option on the GET would be nice for debug and inspection

jyellick
2016-11-01 20:36
The bootstrapping tool will need to support pretty printing of the genesis block for analysis, maybe even to HTML or some such

binhn
2016-11-01 20:38
ok, so are we set on proto?

jyellick
2016-11-01 20:39
I would say yes. Unless we wanted to switch all of our persistent data to another encoding like ANS.1 or something, but I thought that was ruled 'too expensive' for the time being

jyellick
2016-11-01 20:39
I would not support a move to JSON, that seems like a step back to me

kostas
2016-11-01 20:39
(Keep that asterisk on the need for a timestamp, I've emailed Marko.)

binhn
2016-11-01 20:42
i say to move on with CR and change re timestamp if needed later since we need this to hammer out other stuff this week

muralisr

jyellick

muralisr

adc
2016-11-02 10:46

adc
2016-11-02 10:46

adc
2016-11-02 10:46

adc
2016-11-02 12:10

garisingh

kostas
2016-11-02 13:35

muralisr
2016-11-02 17:13

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:15
I was also considering consolidating the protos, doing something like putting the `Block` and `Envelope` definitions into `protos/common` the `Broadcast`/`Deliver` pieces into `protos/orderer` and then the fabric transaction and friends into `protos/peer`

muralisr
2016-11-02 17:17
sounds good to me.

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:18
just to make sure, the consolidation of block structure will include changes in the ledger APIs right?

muralisr
2016-11-02 17:18

muralisr
2016-11-02 17:19

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:19

dave.enyeart
2016-11-02 17:20

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:20

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:20
Yes, that we would need to change

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:20
I mean Block2 doesnt provides information about block sequence number

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:21
while ledger api has a functionality of retrieving the block by its sequence number

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:22
@c0rwin - at ledger level, it is assumed that the blocks arrive in sequence and hence while writing Block2, we had kept the fields to minimum

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:22
I assumed something like that

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:24
but still, I guess that path to write block should look like `RemoveInvalidTransactionsAndPrepare(block)` > `Commit()` > `GetBlockByNumber(seqNum)`

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:24
how this expected to work in case of failure in `Commit`?

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:26
Next block cannot be committed before a successful commit of previous block in any case - irrespective of whether the block contains seqNum or not

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:26
Because, validation of next block depends on a successful commit of previous blocks

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:28
ok

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:28
I got it

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:29
so that means ledgers has to have counters synced w/ orderers?

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:29
Only thing I am saying is that from ledger's perspective, we do not mind if sequence number is present in the block (and can think of using it for certain optimizations in retrieval but can live without it as well (as long as it is guaranteed to be delivered in sequence)

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:31
Ledger always keep track total number of blocks committed so yes, when comes back after a crash it expects blocks from there on...

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:31
so how do you make sure that block to be committed is from the next sequence number?

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:32
`RemoveInvalidTransactionsAndPrepare(block)` > `Commit()`

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:32
You mean to say that ledger can receive blocks out of order?

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:32
is there something inside ledger to prevent it?

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:33
If our assumption is wrong then we would have to build it by bufferring etc... As of now, it assumes that an upper layer is doing this

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:34
is this assumption wrong?

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:35
not sure whenever its wrong, but its optimistic IMO

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:36
somewhere some layer has to do ordering and not sure if this should be performed at multiple layers...

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:36
I thought the gossip layer was the one who buffered and ordered for the ledger?

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:37
(Unless the peer is pulling from the ordering service, in which case, things arrive ordered)

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:37
That's what my assumption was too...

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:37
In my talks with @yacovm that has been my impression. We have discussed how to do this properly

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:37
right gossip makes sure that blocks are re-ordered according to the sequence numbers

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:38
At best, in ledger - we can check that if seqNum is unexpected - raise a panic but certainly don't want to repeat what is being done by gossip

dave.enyeart
2016-11-02 17:38
I would agree with that approach Manish

dave.enyeart
2016-11-02 17:38
specifically, we are talking about the new Block header Number right

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:39
Also, I am not sure whether it is meaningful have a `DataHash` inside the block?

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:39
well, if new ab.Block is going to replace Block2 and ledger API eventually got refactored I wont have any concerns

dave.enyeart
2016-11-02 17:40
i believe that is the request that Manish is currently sizing

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:40
> Also, I am not sure whether it is meaningfull have a DataHash inside the block? I don't understand?

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:41
I think the answer to this is yes

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:41
I mean the data and data hash both with in the same block what significance the datahash carries?

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:41
The hash chain is among the headers

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:41
And a header can be used to validate the data section

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:42
ok, Im looking on it from the ledger replication perspective, new node is joining and has to get all missing blocks to its local ledger

dave.enyeart
2016-11-02 17:42
and i thought another benefit was that the data can eventually be purged while leaving the headers and hashes intact, right?

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:43
Exactly. You can for instance, present a header and signatures, without the actual block contents, and show that "Yes, this is a part of the chain"

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:43
yeap

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:43
I think this will be especially useful for things like Gossip where you want to send something which is provably chained, but not the whole block

c0rwin
2016-11-02 17:44
right, was going to type the exactly same argument :slightly_smiling_face: thanks @jyellick

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:45
While I have everyone here, something @yacovm requested, which I'm somewhat inclined to add, is to include the index of the last configuration transaction for a chain in the block header. Because, given a block header, and a set of signatures, you need a third piece of information "Which signatures are required", which is embedded in the configuration transaction. What does everyone think?

yacovm
2016-11-02 17:45
"provably chained" - can be proved with the chain?

yacovm
2016-11-02 17:46
like merkel tree, etc?

yacovm
2016-11-02 17:46
I think that's a great idea Jason!

yacovm
2016-11-02 17:46
more information cannot hurt :wink:

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:47
By "provably chained" I mean that the headers have the collection of signatures against them which "Proves" them. I use this in the same sense of the hash-puzzle proof of Bitcoin. Where the puzzle solution "Proves" that the header is valid

yacovm
2016-11-02 17:48
You'll need 2 fields though, right? 1 for orderer configuration and 1 for channel membership conf

yacovm
2016-11-02 17:48
since I think they are different types of transactions

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:48
~Hmmm, I guess I haven't not heard about the 'validator configuration transactions', can you expand?~

yacovm
2016-11-02 17:49
the orderer change

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:49
Ah, your edit clarified things

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:49
So no, all configuration goes into the same configuration block, both channel membership, and orderer configuration

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:50
My point was why can't that be simply a single hash (previous hash + this blocks hash) and let the signing happen over that...

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:50
Because then you need the whole block to validate the hash

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:50
Whereas with the two, you only need the block headers to do so

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:50
Do we need to explicitly store both previous blockhash and datahash

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:51
yes, for full validation, you anyways need to verify datahash against the data...

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 17:51
I am not sure if I am missing something here...

yacovm
2016-11-02 17:52
wait, @jyellick isn't that a problem then? it's dangerous

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:53
For full validation yes, but there are plenty of scenarios where you don't want to validate all of the data, maybe you only want to validate say, configuration.

yacovm
2016-11-02 17:53
no, wait, forget that.

yacovm
2016-11-02 17:53
I'm not thinking clearly anymore at this point of the day, it's not dangerous

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:55
So, in the configuration scenario, I want to look at the blockchain, and be able to verify that the configuration in block 10 million is valid. I don't care if the data contents of block 9,999,999 is corrupt, so I don't want to have to hash it and check it, I just care that there's a valid header chain to block 10 million

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:56
Or, maybe I don't want to keep a fully copy of the chain, because it's too big, but I also want to make sure that my copy of the chain isn't messed with. I can just retain only the headers, which form a hash chain, so it is safely tamper proof. Then, when I want to actually inspect a block, I go ask someone for it,and verify it against the small header chain I keep locally.

jyellick
2016-11-02 17:57
Basically, by splitting the block into header and data, it allows you to safely prune data out of your chain, without breaking the chain integrity.

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:00
OK, sure. Makes sense to me. So, PreviousHash is the hash of the 'header' of the previous block?

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:00
Exactly

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:01
That means that I would require two hash computations per block?

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:01
Well, from a ledger perspective, that depends. Does the ledger actually ensure there is a hash chain?

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:01
so when you get a block `i` you verify `header(i)` against body of the block `i` and also against the hash of the header of `i-1` then commit it?

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:02
I sort of assumed that the ledger is handed a block which is known to be valid. And it just applied the block contents. You could obviously check the hashes and so forth, but I had assumed this was handled further up.

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:03
and where is the signature in all that? in some wrapper that wraps the block?

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:03
OK, I did not assume so... if someone is doing is up, I can skip this...

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:03
or in the header also?

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:03
I'm also unsure, do we still have the notion of the 'validated ledger'? I wasn't sure if that made it into v1

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:04
yes, we have a 'validated ledger'.. unless, it's changed :slightly_smiling_face:

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:04
from what I understand, validating blocks will be locally in the ledger, so in v1.0 there won't be validation like they want with gossip, etc.

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:04
So in that case, you're generating a new block from the raw block and committing it?

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:04
yes

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:05
When a block arrives, either via gossip, or via the ordering service. The first step is going to be to make sure that the block is well formed, that the signatures over the header are correct, and that the header's hashes match (both data and previous).

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:05
Or, this is my assumption, at least.

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:06
If this layer does not do this, then the signature validation is a little weird to me. Because we verify a signature, but not that the hash it's signed over is valid?

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:07
wait, how is it possible that the sig is valid but the hash isn't?

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:07
I am assuming that someone doing it on top... is gossip doing this?

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:07
why would we validate with the hash

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:07
?

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:07
because, signature are for hash and data is separate...

c0rwin
2016-11-02 18:07
I though committer is expected to do it

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:07
@yacovm I mean, the signature is over the hash of the header. But if the header does not correspond to the block contents, then the signature is 'valid' but it's not valid over 'this block'

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:07
but, if the block is properly signed then it means a write-quorum of orderers made that block

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:08
oh I thought the sig is on the whole block

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:08
wait, I now I'm confused

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:08
Ah, no, signature is over the header. Has to be, otherwise you lose the prunability

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:08
signature are always on hash...

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:08
a block has a deader and a body, right?

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:08
Right, hash of the header

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:08
I'm a gossip component

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:08
I get a block

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:08
I look at the header and at the body

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:09
the header is signed, everything is A-OK

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:09
No

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:09
wait, I'm going somewhere

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:09
Okay, I say, 'not good enough', but go on

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:09
how do I validate the body assuming the header is properly signed?

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:09
You look at the `DataHash` field, and you compute the hash of the `BlockData` and make sure they match

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:09
Otherwise, I could just take a valid header, and send you garbage block contents

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:10
oh so I need to hash the body, see that the header's body-hash is equal and then verify the sig?

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:10
Exactly.

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:10
that has nothing to do with looking at the previous hash though

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:11
To me, the hash of the body matching the hash encoded in the header is part of the block being 'well formed'

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:11
I expect the ledger to do that

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:11
you also need to look at the previous block hash separately

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:11
why do *i* need to do that though?

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:11
If you have a valid block, and the previous block hash does not match, then we have a serious problem. A sort of "Panic and call the admins" sort of problem

c0rwin
2016-11-02 18:11
@yacovm: I think this should capability of committer rather than ledger

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:11
I'm asking, how is it possible that a block passed verification and *doesn't* match the prev hash?

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:11
That would only happen if the system is broken

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:12
yeah so don't you agree (Jason) that this is a very rare case, and therefore- the gossip layer should not do the book keeping of the prev hash

kostas
2016-11-02 18:12
What is exactly the use of this?

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:12
kostas- I can use that information to know when it's safe to relay a block

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:12
@yacovm I'm fine with the committing layer doing the previous block hash check, but not the data hash one

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:13
oh I don't mind that we do the hashing, I think that it's supposed to be in our layer

kostas
2016-11-02 18:13
@yacovm: You cannot.

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:13
but we need an API change for that hash thing :slightly_smiling_face:

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:13
kostas- can you elaborate?

kostas
2016-11-02 18:15
Sure.

kostas
2016-11-02 18:17
As I had noted in that phone call a couple of weeks ago. I am a Byzantine orderer, sending out block 120 that says "by the way the last configuration transaction for this chain is at block 100". (Block 100 is a config transaction that includes me as an orderer.) Meanwhile, at block 110, a new config was posted and the orderer network kicked me out, or whatever.

kostas
2016-11-02 18:17
So I'm pointing you to stale information and make you believe that you're good to relay the block.

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:17
wait wait wait

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:17
I first validate the block

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:17
how can you make that data block be signed?

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:18
i validate it with the latest conf I have

kostas
2016-11-02 18:18
If you validate that block, and by validate you mean that you have all of the chain before it, why do you need that extra bit of info to begin with?

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:18
no

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:19
that's not what I mean

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:20
I mean- when I get a block that claims the last config to be block `100`, all orderers needed to sign that block

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:20
so how do you make it happen?

kostas
2016-11-02 18:20
Block 100 is signed by all orderers, or block 122 that you just received?

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:20
122

kostas
2016-11-02 18:21
Did I miss the memo about the blocks having to be signed by all orderers?

kostas
2016-11-02 18:21
Unless we talk f+1, etc.

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:21
yeah, not all

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:21
f+1

kostas
2016-11-02 18:21
So it can certainly happen.

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:21
you're talking about a configuration increase now?

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:22
so f+1 is less than f'+1?

muralisr
2016-11-02 18:22
so .apologize for jumping in this started with discussion on consolidating ab.Block2 with fabric.Block

kostas
2016-11-02 18:22
Because a part of those those orderers were kicked out between block 100 and 110.

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:22

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:22

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:22

muralisr
2016-11-02 18:22

kostas
2016-11-02 18:23
@muralisr I can defer the conversation for later, but I'm responding to this call in here 20m ago: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/archives/fabric-crypto/p1478108757001743

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:24
@muralisr I think it's known that my vote is 'do it', with respect to @dave.enyeart and @manish-sethi I don't recall any real endorsement or objection

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:24
@jyellick - again one doubt on the block header. Let me know what am I missing if I say the following for your scenario of selective chain verification (without full data validation). Let's have a single field in the header called blockhash (which is computed as 'previous blockhash + blockdata'). For selective verification, why can't one take the field value itself for granted when it can take it's hash for granted?

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:26
@manish-sethi I give you a series of 3 headers and 3 signature sets, for blocks 1, 2, 3. And no block contents. How do I validate that no one has modified the header of block 2, without retrieving any block contents?

kostas
2016-11-02 18:27
(@yacovm: Say you need 4 signatures. You understand that these 4 signatures can be valid based on block 100, but invalid based on block 110 right? So if these 4 signatures are referenced in block 122 and they're saying "you can totally trust us because they last config block is 100" you're setting yourself up for failure.)

kostas
2016-11-02 18:28
(Let's take this to gossip-dev.)

yacovm
2016-11-02 18:28
sure

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:28
But for validating the header you need the content anyway... no?

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:29
Why?

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:29
I can give you a sequence of headers, and you can validate that they hash chain together, and have the appropriate signatures?

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:30
So if someone were to modify block 2's header, the hash chain would break

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:33
What am I missing here is that... we are trusting the signatures. What is wrong if those signatures sign the header with just one field in it and we simply trust that as well...

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:34
Two-fold

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:34
One, checking signatures is much slower. Two, you can actually safely prune signatures as well, so long as your most recent block has signatures, there's no need to retain any of the past ones.

c0rwin
2016-11-02 18:35
@muralisr: I have clarified for me assumptions made for ledger API and given that ab.Block has been merged the only missing part if refactoring of ledger API to incorporate nee Block

c0rwin
2016-11-02 18:36
i believe I can make further progress now

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:37
May be I am missing something very basic... but not able to get why two fields can be trusted and one cannot ...

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:39
Given block headers 1, 2, 3, and signatures over block 3. How can I detect a modification to block header 1 or 2 (without their corresponding data) if the hash includes that data?

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:40
my only point is that you are trusting on datahash... cannot we just trust on 'data+previoushash'

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:40
for full validation anyways data is needed

simon
2016-11-02 18:41
answer: it's how bitcoin does it

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 18:42
I am fine..If that's the reasoning... was just trying to understand the logic.

jyellick
2016-11-02 18:44
Bitcoin does it that way, which I think is worth emulating if only for the familiarity. And I still maintain there are concrete advantages for having the hash chain over the headers, like signature pruning, and hash verification being faster than signature verification.

muralisr
2016-11-02 19:00
does it sound reasonable @jyellick @manish-sethi to incorporate the new Block into ledger ( @c0rwin is unblocked from implementation but dependent on the consolidation on testing)

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 19:01

muralisr
2016-11-02 19:02
perfect

jyellick
2016-11-02 19:02

dave.enyeart

dave.enyeart

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 19:05

dave.enyeart
2016-11-02 19:05

manish-sethi
2016-11-02 19:05
otherwise, you would miss the blocks below the previous block

simon

adc
2016-11-04 15:10

2016-11-04 15:12

simon
2016-11-04 15:12

2016-11-04 15:12

simon
2016-11-04 15:12

simon
2016-11-04 15:12
run separate chains instead of channels

simon
2016-11-04 15:12

adc

garisingh
2016-11-08 12:20
@adc @elli - been looking at https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2243/2/idp/idp.go and all of the comments as well

garisingh
2016-11-08 12:20
here's my take - I think we are trying to bite off too much here on the first go around

garisingh
2016-11-08 12:21
I think we need to start simple and then back into / expand out to more functionality

garisingh
2016-11-08 12:23
basically, from a fabric and orderer perspective, what we need to start with are the Identity and SigningIdentity interfaces and concrete implementation of PeerIdentity and OrdererIdentity (the peer one might be tricky in that a concrete PeerIdentity may not always be a SigningIdentity)

elli
2016-11-08 12:26
Hm So why would peer identity and orderer identity would be different you think?

elli
2016-11-08 12:26
I mean generically defined one can have a different provider for each of them true

garisingh
2016-11-08 12:26
I think we have a use case we can try here: 1) fabric-cop can generate "enrollment" credentials 2) we can create a PeerIdentity from those credentials (would be a file-based provider later on) 3) we can leverage that identity to sign endorsements the other side: 4) on the verifying of endorsements, we need to create a PeerIdentity from the public cert used to sign (in steps 1-3 above) 5) we use that identity to verify the endorsement signature

garisingh
2016-11-08 12:26
well not sure if they would ever have different fields

elli
2016-11-08 12:27
aha

garisingh
2016-11-08 12:27
but we could go with FabricIdentity or something as well

elli
2016-11-08 12:27
but in the test file i think at least for verification we follow the same steps

elli
2016-11-08 12:27
here

adc
2016-11-08 12:27
