weeds
2016-11-08 15:20
quick meeting- Keith: you as the node sdk- you have to plug in multiple identity providers. So somewhere there is an API to be able to talk to that. -Jim: But an MSP for SDK, does not mean registration and enroll. Sometimes enroll is provided by ecerts are put in place where i can get access It will be useful iff we can separate the core API- identity based on certificates as required for signing purposes or even for encryption versus the registration and enroll. -- Elli stated- we should have api deefined for the peer and one for the application. Then one app might use membership services a or b- we can start implementing api for the peer and the minimum one. And then we can add later the api for applications to use.

weeds
2016-11-08 15:21
Keith: this means we go back what we had last week -pulling out MSP peer API, and we had a client API. At least they are separate. If we don't keep client in fabric, we're not sure where we put it. Gari: you can put it in COP, but put in separate file. It's likely going to change anyway

weeds
2016-11-08 15:23
Gari: Here is a customer example- there is a Java SDK requirement. In their case, they don't plan to use COP (many people want to use their own). We just have to have a format- so we start out with these APIs... and we can then parse that information. Identity has the ability to parse the certificate. Then, from SDK perspective- it becomes a nice interface. So if someone wants to register- they can call API and it gets loaded from the store they are using. BTW, this is how we can do unit testing.

yacovm
2016-11-08 15:24
Hey, I have a couple of questions unclear to me and if someone could explain to me that'd help: 1) In fabric v1 (next architecture) - how can a peer from org A verify an SSL certificate of a peer of org B, when they have different CAs? 2) in SSL from what I know- when you connect to a remote server, the certificate of the server needs to sign on the DNS name or ip address, because you don't know the certificate of the remote server before you connect to it, so if the certificate does not sign the hostname\ip, you won't be able to connect, right? 3) If the above (2) is true, then how will that work in fabric v1 ? the PKI infrastructure would hand out certificates with ip/hostnames signed ? 4) if the above (3) is true, then how will fabric work in a cloud environment where the ip address is something dynamic and random? Does the PKI layer know how to deal with it? It sounds to be pretty complex because you need to keep track of changing data.

weeds
2016-11-08 15:26
Keith: the signing identity-we need the implementation for signing identity and identity. What we agreed is that Elli and team would do that for ECerts. For timeline- how long is that going to take to do. Elli- there is a lot of code already ready for ecert signing functionality. And she will have to think through that with Angelo. They thought if the Ali/Angelo, they could get this within the week, they could offer the signing/verification.

jyellick
2016-11-08 15:26
@yacovm I was planning to ask the same thing here to @elli @adc @aso

weeds
2016-11-08 15:28
Gari: the main thing is hooking up between identity and the BCCSP too. Elli said that is the largest extent we have and is pretty close. Gari: We have to load up multiple root certificate authorities.

weeds
2016-11-08 15:28
Jim: isn't that supposed to go through BCCSP interface instead of specifically knowing how you sign? Gari: yes- we should hook those together

weeds
2016-11-08 15:28
Angelo checked in the signer and it's been merged in

weeds
2016-11-08 15:29
Gari: this gets us to an end to end path and a little refactoring after that... this should be the goal.

jyellick
2016-11-08 15:29
My impressions have been that: 1. The peer org CAs are encoded in the configuration, so anyone can verify that a certificate chain presented by the peer chains to a trusted CA. 2./3./4. I do not think we can do certificate validation by DNS/common name. Here we use certs for identity not location. So, a CA signing a cert chain implies that the peer is authorized to transact under the authority of that CA. Unlike with something like https on the web, where you care not simply that a CA has signed, but that the CA intended to sign for that URL. For chaincode, I know there are attributes which are set on the certificate, so that not all certificates which chain to a CA have the same authority, but from an orderer/gossip perspective, I expect this to be coarse enough that presenting a valid cert chain to a CA implies authority to transact on the network.

weeds
2016-11-08 15:29
Jim: once we have identity and signing identity- we should be able to do almost everything. It will poll the dependent classes.

weeds
2016-11-08 15:30
in the other classes- what is a member? Gari suggesting to remove that or-- should called memberservice- it's really the API side of all the registration. The rest are really entity definitions, where member is a noun and interface to call a service.

weeds
2016-11-08 15:30
Gari: I would strip down to bare minimum that we can.

weeds
2016-11-08 15:31
Jim: I am struggling with member- member respresents and enroll entity with identity provider. Enroll means you have a signed certificate,.. isn't that what identity class represents? why do we still need member?

weeds
2016-11-08 15:32
Keith: the original idp.go that he sent had different names and it did not have member. I was just trying to make progress at this point. I was trying to simplify in the one Keith sent-- Elli plans to look at it.

weeds
2016-11-08 15:33
Elli: for identity and signing identity- sounds like we are converging.

weeds
2016-11-08 15:34
Elli: there is some design work on access control for the channels. This is an item we are collaborating with consensus and endorser team. The high level flow is included in document in pdf. - fab 633

weeds
2016-11-08 15:35
from high level design- wrote a document that we are going to reach out to the community- where we are adding interfaces related to that story.. and next sprint we will implement in the next sprint

weeds
2016-11-08 15:35
There is design interface of application level and invocation access management. These are things that we are going to do in future sprints.

garisingh
2016-11-08 15:41
@yacovm : 1) In fabric v1 (next architecture) - how can a peer from org A verify an SSL certificate of a peer of org B, when they have different CAs? Part of the material that we need to distribute to all peers that are part of the network will be the set of root certificates used by each participant. We'll need to decide if we need to separate the truststore for signing/verification from the truststore used for TLS communication but basically this material needs to be collected from every network participant prior to them joining and then distributed via the appropriate config transaction(s) (which may be scoped to channels possibly). But the bottom line is that the trust stores need to be distributed 2) in SSL from what I know- when you connect to a remote server, the certificate of the server needs to sign on the DNS name or ip address, because you don't know the certificate of the remote server before you connect to it, so if the certificate does not sign the hostname\ip, you won't be able to connect, right? The CN or the SAN in the TLS certificate must match the hostname that will be used to access the endpoint. This is a must in terms of the TLS certificates that the various components need to use. The trust will be established via the truststore mentioned in 1) above 3) If the above (2) is true, then how will that work in fabric v1 ? the PKI infrastructure would hand out certificates with ip/hostnames signed ? See above 4) if the above (3) is true, then how will fabric work in a cloud environment where the ip address is something dynamic and random? Does the PKI layer know how to deal with it? It sounds to be pretty complex because you need to keep track of changing data. If you are not going to have a static IP, then you must use a FQDN instead. This is exactly what we do in BMX today

aso
2016-11-08 15:41
@yacovm @jyellick > 1. The peer org CAs are encoded in the configuration, so anyone can verify that a certificate chain presented by the peer chains to a trusted CA. I expect the same too, the (self-signed) certificates of all CAs should be available to everyone. Adding or revoking them should be a job of the configuration system. > 2./3./4. I do not think we can do certificate validation by DNS/common name. Here we use certs for identity not location. So, a CA signing a cert chain implies that the peer is authorized to transact under the authority of that CA. Unlike with something like https on the web, where you care not simply that a CA has signed, but that the CA intended to sign for that URL. For chaincode, I know there are attributes which are set on the certificate, so that not all certificates which chain to a CA have the same authority, but from an orderer/gossip perspective, I expect this to be course enough that presenting a valid cert chain to a CA implies authority to transact on the network. I agree - a node looks up another peer/node they want to talk to (somehow) or they reach out to us, at which point in the course of the TLS exchange we'll mutually authenticate based on our TLS certs. At the end of the TLS handshake, we'll know that the node at the other end of the wire possesses legitimately that certificate. At this point we need to inspect it, see who signed it (do we trust them) and what they signed (attributes) and make a determination whether we wanna talk to them.

jyellick
2016-11-08 15:43
So when someone presents their 'identity', this will be a full certificate chain, down to the CA root?

aso
2016-11-08 15:44
It should be, yes. The same happens on the web - websites usually present their chain, which is rooted with something your browser has (the set of CAs it trusts)

aso
2016-11-08 15:45
you'll notice that presenting the root is redundant

aso
2016-11-08 15:45
since you've got to have a copy of it yourself

yacovm
2016-11-08 15:45
wait wait wait, isn't that a chicken and egg problem?

yacovm
2016-11-08 15:48
5) how can I connect to an orderer (part of the fabric) if I get its certificate from the... well, ledger? 6) you're telling me there will be some system-crypto-channel in which orderers would publish certificates? 7) In fabric there will *most likely* be peers that won't be connected to the orderer directly, but will get information indirectly via other peers. They will have a bootstrapping problem, because they won't be able to connect to any peer.

aso
2016-11-08 15:48
there has got to be some root of trust hardcoded somewhere (genesis block)

aso
2016-11-08 15:49
much like when you install your browser, it comes with its set of CAs

yacovm
2016-11-08 15:49
I thought that a genesis block is now per channel

jyellick
2016-11-08 15:53
Yes, there is

jyellick
2016-11-08 15:54
In order to join a channel, you must have a copy of the genesis block (or some later config block)

jyellick
2016-11-08 15:54
So you have all the CA certs.

yacovm
2016-11-08 15:54
ok let me make it more specific, @aso - My gossip code needs a way of verifying a signature of a remote peer, having the signature, the plaintext (obviously) and the peer's (the signer's) PKI-ID. Do we still have this functionality in v1.0? (please say yes)

jyellick
2016-11-08 15:55
@yacovm I'm still confused why you are using PKI-ID when you have access to the full cert (chain)

aso
2016-11-08 15:55
is this in the scope of TLS?

yacovm
2016-11-08 15:55
no

yacovm
2016-11-08 15:56
Jason- well, as I said on gerrit- when I designed everything, I was told I'll be able to use the PKI-ID, and that was what the code in 0.5 was doing, and no one told me along the way anything different

aso
2016-11-08 15:56
so you have a message of sorts, a signature over it, and a cert

yacovm
2016-11-08 15:57
no no, it's more simpler than that- imagine I know of a peer and it's PKI-ID and I already authenticated it

aso
2016-11-08 15:57
and you want to 1) verify that signature 2) get some assurance about the signing cert - who are they? who signed their cert?

yacovm
2016-11-08 15:57
yes!

yacovm
2016-11-08 15:57
exactly - 1+2

jyellick
2016-11-08 15:57
@yacovm But could you not compute a PKI-ID from the cert if need be?

yacovm
2016-11-08 15:58
I could if I had the function that computes it (I have no idea the hash algorithm)

yacovm
2016-11-08 15:58
everything I'm talking about here is merged long ago,btw: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/gossip/api/api.go#L59

aso
2016-11-08 15:59
I think the primitives to sign/verify will be there

yacovm
2016-11-08 15:59
I expect the following abilities when the gossip is initialized: ``` Sign(msg []byte) ([]byte, error) Verify(vkID, signature, message []byte) error ```

aso
2016-11-08 15:59
they might look different from what they used to

jyellick
2016-11-08 16:00
I guess my concern, is that we had the (IMHO terrible) dependence on a network call in order to authenticate peers in 0.5. And we should not be trying to emulate this as a pattern.

jyellick
2016-11-08 16:00
Especially if we have all of the certificate material present.

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:00
@jyellick - we are getting rid of that bootstrap for enrollment

jyellick
2016-11-08 16:00
Right, I thought that was out.

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:01
@yacovm - at the end of the day, when a network starts you must have some bootstrap material which is distributed / resides outside the ledger

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:01
Wait so a quick recap- The fabric is running for 1 month, and I'm a new peer. the first thing I ever do is grab a genesis crypto block and commit it and connect with it to the orderer?

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:02
the first thing is that the existing folks need to allow you to join :wink:

jyellick
2016-11-08 16:02
Right, the 'channel join' operation takes as a parameter a genesis block (or in the future, a configuration block)

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:03
why is this context-based on a channel? I'm talking about just the first connection to an orderer

jyellick
2016-11-08 16:03
Logically, connecting to the 'system chain' and a channel are equivalent to me.

jyellick
2016-11-08 16:04
But to bootstrap a peer, you also provide it with a genesis block

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:04
so there will be an "infrastructure channel" then?

jyellick
2016-11-08 16:05
In order to first start up a peer period, the agreed upon boostrapping mechanism was to provide it with the genesis block of the 'system chain'

jyellick
2016-11-08 16:05
However, I really see no strong reason you could not bootstrap a peer to a particular channel instead of to the 'system chain'

jyellick
2016-11-08 16:05
Every genesis block need to contain a full config (complete with CA certs et al)

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:05
then you'll need to insert the certs into the genesis block of the channel

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:05
oh ok

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:09
@aso is there a way of looking up the certificate by the PKI-ID?

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:11
I understand that the certificates would be saved in the ledger, is it possible to also save their PKI-id and be able to perform a search for that?

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:11
otherwise, you won't be able to perform: verify(pkiID, sig, plaintext)

aso
2016-11-08 16:12
All the info is there - certs have a subject (who) and an issuer (who signed it), so I guess it's a matter of exposing APIs to lookup a cert by subject

aso
2016-11-08 16:12
I don't think these APIs are there

aso
2016-11-08 16:13
so you get a cert, you see its issuer and then you lookup in your trust bag if you have a cert whose subject is your issuer

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:13
but how am I going to verify someone's message by knowing only his PKI-ID and not the full cert then?

aso
2016-11-08 16:14
so you are saying that you don't even have a certificate, only an ID (like a plain string)?

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:14
yes, just that the id is the hash on the cert

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:16
that's how all the 6000+ lines of gossip code works, and I built it under the assumption that I would be able to perform `verify(PKIid, sig, text)` just like it is done in 0.5, , and as was told to me.... @adc

aso
2016-11-08 16:18
I'll reach out to you in pvt and we can try to sort it out

rickr
2016-11-08 16:29
has joined #fabric-crypto

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:46
ok so we talked on the phone and we came to a conclusion that: 1) Gossip *has* to have a way of mapping a PKI-ID of a peer to its certificate 2) The Ledger guys that are responsible for writing the certificate crypto data into the chain need to be aware of it, and need to implement a way for the crypto layer to create a mapping between PKI-ID (essentially it's a hash of the cert) to the cert itself. @elli , @adc , @aso , @garisingh and @binhn , I'll create a JIRA item in a few min, but who should I tag here to explain the need? (who is it going to be from the ledger guys? Maybe @muralisr ?)

jyellick
2016-11-08 16:48
@yacovm For my edification, why does gossip need PKI-ID instead of the cert itself? And is there an instance where a peer has a reference to a PKI-id but does not already have the corresponding cert locally?

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:49
I use the PKI-ID to identify a peer

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:49
I send this information every few seconds (configurable)

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:50
I don't want to send every few seconds a few KBs

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:50
so I need a deterministic way of converting a cert ---> to a []byte without collisions, so in 0.5 it was implemented as a simple hash.

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:51
``` And is there an instance where a peer has a reference to a PKI-id but does not already have the corresponding cert locally? ``` yeah, he won't be able to communicate with the peer until it has. I don't see it as a big problem

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:51
@yacovm - write up the requirement and tag me and murali for now

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:52
BUT

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:52
there's more to this than PKI-ID

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:52
I'll write a JIRA item, is that ok?

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:52
yep

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:52
what is there more except that?

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:55
The way you are currently using PKI-ID assumes that every peer already has and/or has access to every other peer's certificate (at least the certificate they use to sign messages). This works in v0.5/v0.6 because the peer actually calls out to membersrvcs (as I recall) to download the public certificate(s) for other remote peers. This IS NOT going to be possible in v1

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:55
so what? eventually it will have access to that, because it'll get the ledger

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:55
it'll simply re-connect

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:56
well I don't actually think that we are going to put every peer certificate in the ledger. we were going to start with putting the root certificates for every participant into the ledger not the individual peer certificates

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:57
My point is that there's more to this story

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:57
this is just one piece

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:57
this also means that when people sign messages, they need to include the public key in the message itself

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:57
hmm, and how is the authentication going to work then?

jyellick
2016-11-08 16:57
Right, the peer can absolutely maintain a cache of peer certs it knows about, when it connects via TLS it will get the certs. And I think, for gossip, this is okay.

jyellick
2016-11-08 16:57
The chain has all the _CA_ certs, and the TLS cert will chain to the CA for auth

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:58
we don't do mutual TLS

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:58
and the TLS cert is not the same as the signing cert

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:58
aha!

jyellick
2016-11-08 16:58
Peer<->Peer does not do mutual TLS? Why not?

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:58
and we track identity based on signing cert

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:58
WELL - we can move to that model

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:58
so, if the TLS certs are different, is the TLS cert self-signed?

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:58
we don't do it today

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:59
No

yacovm
2016-11-08 16:59
so?

garisingh
2016-11-08 16:59
If we do mutual TLS and in gossip you choose to use the client certificate as the PKI-ID, that may be OK

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:00
wait so just to understand what jyellic said- when I'm a peer I present to a fellow peer a certificate that has a chain of signatures all the way up to some CA which the fellow peer can verify, right?

jyellick
2016-11-08 17:00
My assumption had been that this 'presented cert' was the TLS cert. But it sounds like there is maybe some other mechanism here?

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:01
Gari- in gossip, the TLS configuration is pluggable, so I just put whatever I get, unless I don't get anything at all- and then I generate a self-signed certificate myself and use that in SSL

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:01
THIS IS MY POINT - that's what I mean by there's more to this than the PKI-ID thing

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:01
then I verify the remote peer using the PKI-ID

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:01
where'd you get it from in the first place?

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:02
you're asking jason?

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:02
no - you

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:02
where did I get what

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:02
Let's start with a simple case of 2 peers

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:02
it's the only case actually

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:03
Let's assume mutual TLS (e.g. client certificates)

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:03
mutual TLS with signed certs?

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:04
let's start with signed certs

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:04
ok

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:05
so lets say `p0` connects to `p1` and presents him with a signed challenge signed by him, and the PKI-ID (for identity)

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:05
what is the signed challenge? not TLS but application level?

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:05
yep

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:06
didn't you say they are different certs? the TLS and the peer cert?

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:07
(they could be different or they could be the same)

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:07
but let's continue

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:07
yeah but of course you understand, I already implemented everything so I assumed the "worse"

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:09
so now `p1` has some bytes which were signed by `p0` and also has `pkiID` from `p0` (which is theoretically the hash of the certificate `p0` used to sign the bytes?)

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:09
yes

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:10
and vice-versa regarding the challenge but it's not important

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:10
he now looks into the ledger and asks it- "dear ledger, give me the cert of pkiID"

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:10
so `p1` cannot verify the signed bytes without being in possession of the public key of the keypair `p0` used to sign them

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:11
yes

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:11
correct

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:11
but this isn't too hard to fix- because `p0` can send it in this 1-time-only message also the certificate of itself, and have it hash it and compare to the PKIid)

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:12
you got it

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:12
and like @jyellick said- it can cache it

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:12
and that's what I was getting at

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:12
oh, I thought you meant- there is something more *except that*

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:13
now what we would distribute would be the root certificates for all the participants

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:13
of course, one could distribute the public keys of everyone instead as well

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:14
so maybe I can skip the JIRA item then and simply assert that in the gossip's constuctor, the full cert is going to be needed to be passed, and I'll add a method `cert2PKI-ID` or something like that that is supposed to be supplied by the crypto guys

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:14
but wanted to make sure we can support a model which only requires distribution of root certificates

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:14
but would be good to document this in the overall design

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:15
BTW - (and I like this fact) - use of gossip implies that TLS is always used, correct?

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:15
no

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:15
oh - sorry - we sign the bytes

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:15
it is "adaptive" but it has to be symmetrical

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:15
"if I use TLS you should use too"

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:16
personally I think we should only enable gossip over TLS - that way we'll solve the usability / censurability / configurability right from the beginning.

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:16
if you initialize gossip with your own SSL options (serverOptions and DialOptions I think) I use them as they are, otherwise- I generate self-signed SSL certs and use them

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:16
today - it's a pain in the butt to get TLS working because it was treated as a second class citizen

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:17
yeah

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:18
so to sum things up- @adc and @elli and @aso and everyone I tagged above, the bottom line is that we'll simply pass the certificate in the authentication handshake of the gossip, but the security guys would need to implement a method that converts a cert to a PKI-ID in a deterministic way. (did I get that right @garisingh ? ) Maybe do []byte(PKI_ALGORITHM) concatenated with the public key hash?

garisingh
2016-11-08 17:20
you got it

yacovm
2016-11-08 17:25
@elli I hope you don't mind I assigned it to you, because I have no idea of what to put in other fields in the jira item (such as epic, etc.) https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1034

elli
2016-11-08 17:43
Hi @yacovm, sure. Will discuss with the team and re-assign it if necessary but keep you posted.

yacovm
2016-11-08 21:57
Wait a second @garisingh , if I cache internally the peer's certificate and it is not saved in the ledger- how does the COP infrastructure revoke a peer's certificate then?

jyellick
2016-11-08 21:59
To my knowledge, CRLs are put into the configuration block. In general, CRLs are short and not updated frequently.

garisingh
2016-11-08 22:01
right - given that you will take the PKI-ID and make sure it matches the hash of the "cached" certificate at the same time you could extract the serial number and check it against the CRL stored on the ledger

garisingh
2016-11-08 22:03
or we could have that in the method `validatePKID` or `isValidPKIID` or something

garisingh
2016-11-08 22:03
it not only checks that the hash matches but also that the cert is not revoked

yacovm
2016-11-08 22:11
got it, thanks (Jason&Gari) but also what needs to be done is something that "listens" to that chain and updates the gossip component, because the connection to the peer might be open and we would want to close it. I already have a method in the comm layer that black-lists a remote peer by PKI-Id, it can be used.

garisingh
2016-11-08 22:12
cool

garisingh
2016-11-08 22:12
I think we'll have the "means" to do what we need

yacovm
2016-11-08 22:13
v1 is going to be a monster (complexity-wise)

warm3snow
2016-11-09 08:35
has joined #fabric-crypto

yacovm
2016-11-09 12:23
Anyone home?

yacovm
2016-11-09 12:24
I've a question related to multi-channels. When an application (via node SDK) makes a peer join a channel, how does it identify itself to the peer? How does the peer recognize the "joinChannel" gRPC call is authentic?

garisingh
2016-11-09 12:41
the same way that it would make sure that the endorsement call is authentic - it checks the signature on the "message" - and of course the certificate used to sign the "message" must be trusted by the peers

garisingh
2016-11-09 12:41
Maybe I am missing something in the question?

garisingh
2016-11-09 12:46
the bottom line is that the entire system is basically based on extracting "identity" from the certificates used to sign "messages / transactions". And you can either explicitly trust the certificate or the issuer (root authority) of the certificate. (on top of this, you can also start to use attributes "embedded" in the certificates as well, but the carrier is a certificate)

yacovm
2016-11-09 12:49
The cert is included in the joinChannel message?

yacovm
2016-11-09 12:50
you're not missing anything in the question, I'm simply wondering whether a peer `p0` can relay that message to another peer `p1` and if `p1` can validate that message, that's all.

garisingh
2016-11-09 12:52
I don't see why not - given we are checking the signature of the original submitter and the signature would cover the contents to make sure that have not been changed

yacovm
2016-11-09 12:53
ok thanks, just making sure,

elli
2016-11-09 17:13
Hi, @jyellick, @aso, @binhn, @muralisr; so were wondering on the config message payload structure. Would these have a json form?

elli
2016-11-09 17:15
The reason i am asking is the following: the MSPs would need to understand that message (payload) to evaluate it with the rules associated to that MSP (if e.g., proper signatures have been provided)

muralisr
2016-11-09 17:15
just curious @elli is this wrt https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2243/

elli
2016-11-09 17:15

muralisr
2016-11-09 17:15

elli
2016-11-09 17:15

elli
2016-11-09 17:15

elli
2016-11-09 17:15

muralisr
2016-11-09 17:16
I was thinking we could find one more use for @jyellick policy framework is that where you were going with this ?

elli
2016-11-09 17:16
Had a discussion eearlier with @aso on the way an MSP should be updating its state, as well as with @keithsmith earlier.

muralisr
2016-11-09 17:16
ok

elli
2016-11-09 17:17
And what do you mean by policy framework?

elli
2016-11-09 17:17
In my mind certain config tx-s would refer to membership service provider reconfiguration.

elli
2016-11-09 17:18
Each MSP may have its own rules or policy w.r.t. how the reconfiguration takes place. E.g., MSP 1 may require that CA1 signs configuration changes of MSP1, while MSP2 would require that CA2 signs configuration changes to MSP2.

elli
2016-11-09 17:19
As configuration changes go through the blockchain and included in special transactions, i am wondering if json would still make sense to be used as an argument passed to the

elli
2016-11-09 17:19
MSP reconfigure function... or rather send to it the entire tx...

muralisr
2016-11-09 17:22
ok @elli . My question on policy framework is relevant but might be a distraction for your discussion (heres a change set https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1957 though)

garisingh
2016-11-09 17:24
we are once again on the verge of making this TOO complex without even getting the piece parts working yet :wink:

muralisr
2016-11-09 17:26

garisingh
2016-11-09 17:29

garisingh

elli
2016-11-09 17:31

elli
2016-11-09 17:31
(moving on to a simpler note)

aso
2016-11-09 17:32
One way or another, it would be *great* to have a tentative IDP interface merged soon so that on the peer side we can get a sense of what the full endorsement flow looks like

aso
2016-11-09 17:33
and I think @elli has one ready, where the format of the configuration is json, right?

elli
2016-11-09 17:33
sort of :slightly_smiling_face:

elli
2016-11-09 17:34
I have the setup method taking a input json formed string, and a sample of that string

elli
2016-11-09 17:34
hence i was wondering if it would make sense to use the same thing for reconfiguration related messages.

aso
2016-11-09 17:35
@elli got it

aso
2016-11-09 17:35
thx

elli
2016-11-09 17:37
And extending my thought, i was more generally asking/wondering, why cant a reconfiguration messages simply be defined as payload (in json format) that has added a signature on top?

elli
2016-11-09 17:37
Or is this the way we do it already?

jyellick
2016-11-09 17:48
@elli There is an encoding for policy defined you can see in the protos. As far as specific encodings for certs and such, I was going to leave this to the crypto team

jyellick
2016-11-09 17:49
The configuration messages are defined via protobuf (I don't see why this is inferior to JSON, as you can convert it to/from JSON if you want)

jyellick
2016-11-09 17:49
And the payload is essentially key value pairs, where the encoding of the value is simply bytes, likely a marshaled message of whatever form is desired.

jyellick
2016-11-09 17:50
Have you seen the configuration section in the "Next Hyperledger-Fabric Architecture Protocol messages" doc?

elli
2016-11-09 17:50
But wouldn't things be easier if we specified in the configuration the component of the system this configuration refers to and some payload that this component is able to understand?

jyellick
2016-11-09 17:51
There is a type attached to the configuration item, which indicates the encoding

jyellick
2016-11-09 17:51
(Though what that encoding is is TBD)

jyellick
2016-11-09 17:51
For the policy type, the encoding is a marshaled `Policy` message

jyellick
2016-11-09 17:52
For the orderer/peer/chain types, the encoding is not yet defined

elli
2016-11-09 17:52
I have not see i think the configuration part

jyellick
2016-11-09 17:52
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1qD2zOTxmPoss3Xop_pDdkSXHozIR4N27NEsymosW4Gk/

(For example, data record 1 can be read by user A only. data record 2 can be read by user B only etc.) Thank you.

simon
2016-11-14 13:06
what do you want to achieve?

alanlee
2016-11-14 15:08

simon
2016-11-14 15:44

adc
2016-11-14 16:42

adc
2016-11-14 16:42
you might want to apply this access control check during a query

adc
2016-11-14 16:42

yacovm
2016-11-14 18:07
Hi. https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/gossip/api/channel.go In order to support multi-channels, the gossip component needs 2 methods from the MSP (or should I say, the guys that implement the MSP?) ``` // IsInMyOrg returns whether the given peer's certificate represents // a peer in the invoker's organization IsInMyOrg(PeerCert) bool // Verify verifies a JoinChannelMessage, returns nil on success, // and an error on failure Verify(JoinChannelMessage) error ``` Is that possible to implement?

yacovm
2016-11-14 18:08
The JoinChannel message, if it's not clear- is the genesis configuration block sent from the SDK to the peers when a channel is either created or modified

vdods
2016-11-14 20:49
has joined #fabric-crypto

vdods
2016-11-14 21:09
Hi all, I'm wondering if there has been any thought put into (or perhaps an existing solution, be it external or part of Hyperledger) massive key management? By that I mean managing many keys per user, say on the order of 1 million keys.

vdods
2016-11-14 21:10
One of the motivations here being limiting the damage done in the case of a compromised key by limiting the number of transactions a key can be used for, thereby necessitating management of many keys (for one user).

alanlee
2016-11-15 02:40
Thanks @adc and @simon .

silentspark
2016-11-15 05:23
has joined #fabric-crypto

elli
2016-11-15 11:17
@yacovm, so for the former i think a form of truststore is needed indeed. @aso already allured to that in the endorser changeset that he submitted. For the latter, can u give us more details? We were thinking of adding a function to certify a signature coming from the "authorities" governing that msp (that is the privileged entities within that msp ) that is defined in some pf the policies the msp has been configured with. If this is the case, i think your verify could be implemented using that..

yacovm
2016-11-15 11:21
@elli , The former what? Method? `IsInMyOrg`?

yacovm
2016-11-15 11:24
About `Verify(JoinChannelMessage) error` - this is the to verify the message that the application sends to the peers of a channel in order to make them join a channel, or to update them about a channel's membership

yacovm
2016-11-15 11:24
The message is signed by the app, so I obviously need a way to verify that message

adc
2016-11-15 11:31
Not sure if the MSP needs to know what is a join channel message. Some other component can extract the relevant information to verify the signature and ask the MSP to perform the actual verification. The same think is happening in other places

adc
2016-11-15 11:32
No?

yacovm
2016-11-15 11:37
but see that the `JoinChannelMessage ` is an `interface{}` Meaning- if you guys know the concrete type of the message that is passed from the app, you can simply write code that takes that `interface{}`, cast it to a concrete type that you know and then make the check.

yacovm
2016-11-15 11:38
I'm not saying you need to write special code at this moment, all I'm saying- you need to be able to provide the knowledge we (gossip guys) need, and the code details is something we can work on.

adc
2016-11-15 11:39
Got it

yacovm
2016-11-15 11:40
I myself have no idea what the type of the object passed to me from the app, but I need to write the code that handles it as fast as possible for next week, that's why I layered it this way

adc
2016-11-15 11:46
Makes sense to me. From my side i expect a module that unpack the join channel message and then asks the MSP about the validity of the signature under a specific policy and give back to you a yes or no

2016-11-22 15:39

elli
2016-11-22 15:39

elli
2016-11-22 15:40
Meaning that unless you have some sort of contact point for what you call organization A, assuming that thisis represented by an MSP

elli
2016-11-22 15:40
you will not be able to send a message to all members of A

elli
2016-11-22 15:40
unless you have their contact information + certificate

yacovm
2016-11-22 15:40

elli
2016-11-22 15:40

yacovm
2016-11-22 15:40
let me rephrase maybe that'll make things more clear:

yacovm
2016-11-22 15:41
I'm a peer `p` in org A and I have a message `m` that I know I can only send to orgs A, B,C, meaning- to *any* peer in orgs A, B and C. now comes peer `q`, can I determine whether `q` is in orgs A, B or C? or not?

elli
2016-11-22 15:42
ah fine

elli
2016-11-22 15:42
this would be possible using the orgA MSP

elli
2016-11-22 15:42
that is in that chain's description

yacovm
2016-11-22 15:43
orgA's MSP is "identical"\equivalent to all peers in org A or something?

elli
2016-11-22 15:43
so in each chain we would have a description of the MSPs there in. Ideally there is one MSP per organization

elli
2016-11-22 15:43
MSP = membership service provider

elli
2016-11-22 15:43
in its simpler form consists of a CA

yacovm
2016-11-22 15:44
yeah I know the acronym but it's also a library name

elli
2016-11-22 15:44
root CA, and certificates of members of that MSP are signed with that root CA's signing key

elli
2016-11-22 15:44
at the chain creation ntime, the MSPManager that is fed the genesis block would instantiate the MSPs described in the genesis block

yacovm
2016-11-22 15:45
when you say instantiate the MSPs you mean, instantiate the MSPs of each peer in the channel, right?

elli
2016-11-22 15:45
at the chain creation, MSP defintiion is accompanied by the id of that MSP, so that identities can reference it and be parsed/evaluated with that MSP

elli
2016-11-22 15:45
so the peer gets the genesis block

elli
2016-11-22 15:46
reads the MSPs included there and asks the chain's MSPManager to create one or more MSP objects as described in the genesis block.

elli
2016-11-22 15:46
Using that , the peer can check if a given certificate/identity is a valid identity within the presmise of an MSP

elli
2016-11-22 15:47
so if you have multiple organizations in side the same MSP then you can use the OU inside the certificate for finer grained determination of the org a cert belongs to

yacovm
2016-11-22 15:48
OU is equivalent to an organization I presume?

elli
2016-11-22 15:50
organization unit

elli
2016-11-22 15:50
could be yes

yacovm
2016-11-22 15:51
and if I may be more precise and get to the bottom line- can the MSP (as a component of a peer) give me the following ability: `OrgByPeerIdentity(PeerIdentityType) OrgIdentityType`

yacovm
2016-11-22 15:52
Meaning- if I have a peer's certificate (what you guys call an identity) - can I derive from it the OU or anything that determines its organization, even if the peer is *from a different org*?

adc
2016-11-22 16:31

garisingh

elli
2016-11-22 17:14

elli
2016-11-22 17:15
the organization (as standard x509 certificates) and the MSPID of the MSP they refer to

yacovm
2016-11-22 17:15

elli
2016-11-22 17:16
Ok, an MSP aims to represent some group of certificates. Ideally this should be connected to one or more organizations.

elli
2016-11-22 17:17
This would be reflected to the root certificates included in that MSP validation path. To get the specific organization an identity belongs to, the identity is already equipped with a function to return that identity's organization within that MSP.

adc
2016-11-22 17:17

elli
2016-11-22 17:17

elli
2016-11-22 17:17
e

elli
2016-11-22 17:18
or getParticipantID()

elli
2016-11-22 17:18
but from a security perspective it is important

elli
2016-11-22 17:18
that it is always considered within the msp this identity belongs to

adc
2016-11-22 17:18
And what's the output of that function?

elli
2016-11-22 17:18
otherwise malicious MSPs can issue certificates on organizations they do not own/control.

elli
2016-11-22 17:19
identity.getParticipantID()

elli
2016-11-22 17:19
no input

elli
2016-11-22 17:19
identity represents the certificate

adc
2016-11-22 17:20
I mean, for the x509 based implementation of the MSP, what's the output of that function?

elli
2016-11-22 17:20
th ou of that identity

elli
2016-11-22 17:20
certificate

adc
2016-11-22 17:21

elli
2016-11-22 17:23

2016-11-22 17:24

adc
2016-11-23 08:29

stevenroose
2016-11-23 09:56
A thought I had this morning

stevenroose
2016-11-23 09:57
How easy is it to do SPV proving on Fabric?

stevenroose
2016-11-23 09:57
I'm thinking for IoT purposes

stevenroose
2016-11-23 09:58
A tiny device that only has a very limited amount of memory should be able to get reliable information from a chaincode contract with only a few seed nodes known

garisingh
2016-11-23 11:23
@adc - good question above. Here's my take on what we "allow" in terms of being able to identity unique members/participants/organizations (m/p/o) (using every term I know people currently use - we need to quickly hone in on one): 1) Unique certificate issuing authority - can either be a unique root or intermediate CA (e.g. each m/p/o uses it's own CA) 2) CAs are shared between m/p/o's . In this case, unique identification would be the combination of the certificate issuing authority (root/intermediate CA) and a "unique" field(s) in the Subject DN (need to think about how we allow this to be specified). Maybe it has to be a unique base DN

elli
2016-11-23 12:35
Is it reasonable to assume that the certificate will include inside (Some prefix of its OU field) the MSPID/Organization name?

elli
2016-11-23 12:37
Assuming MSPID is "assigned" by an MSP (application) at chain genesis time, followed by the MSP config info, we could "recommend" that MSPID is some organization name that appears in the OU field of all identities for which MSPManager.isValid(MSPID, identity) returns true.

elli
2016-11-23 12:38
We had a short discussion over this with @adc, and @aso this morning.

garisingh
2016-11-23 12:54
It is indeed safe to assume that we can extract the org / distinct name from the subject DN. The question is how "prescriptive" are we in terms of the form of the subject DN?

elli
2016-11-23 13:16
@garisingh so all subjects will have the same DN, and no other entities outside that MSP can have the same DN?

elli
2016-11-23 13:18
So to absolutely define the OU a subject belongs to, we wouldneed to specify, the chainid, the mspid (which will be equal to the subjects' DN), and OU of the subject where necessary.

elli
2016-11-23 13:19
To absolutely define the DN of the subject we would need to specify the chain and MSPID the identity (Subject) is valid within (given that MSPID would take its name from its subjects DN).

elli
2016-11-23 13:19
Am i correct?

garisingh
2016-11-23 13:26
Let's assume that we have a single CA and it issues certificates for all the peers for all of / each of the members

yacovm
2016-11-23 13:26
``` So to absolutely define the OU a subject belongs to, we wouldneed to specify, the chainid, the mspid (which will be equal to the subjects' DN), and OU of the subject where necessary. ``` Why the chainID?

garisingh
2016-11-23 13:29
So - you might have DNs that looks like: ``` CN=peer1, OU=org1, O=IBM, C=US CN=peer2, OU=org1, O=IBM, C=US CN=peer1, OU=org2, O=IBM, C=US . . . CN=peer2, OU=orgX, O=IBM, C=US ```

garisingh
2016-11-23 13:30
in this case, the "baseDN" is always the same : `O=IBM, C=US` and `OU` is distinct

garisingh
2016-11-23 13:33
so you'd have 2 options: 1) when you register the participant/member/org, you provide the root ca plus an explicit baseDN (the part that would come after the common name (CN)) for example: ``` org1, rootcert,basedn="OU=org1, O=IBM, C=US" org2, rootcert,basedn="OU=org2, O=IBM, C=US" ```

garisingh
2016-11-23 13:35
this option is nice because it allows you to use different suffixes for the DN or 2) you could try to be fancy and just try to extract the `OU` part out

garisingh
2016-11-23 13:36
I prefer option 1 - where basic the CN=enrollID and you require that if you use the same CA you must explicitly list the entire DN suffix / base DN

aso
2016-11-23 13:54
So, `Subject.OU` is what we'll use to identify the MSP ID for a cert - correct?

garisingh
2016-11-23 14:32
so honestly this whole MSP thing confuses me but just wanted to see what would happen with an implementation

garisingh
2016-11-23 14:33
putting that aside, let me try this another way: I'll start with the VSCC case because I think it is easiest to show what is needed / capture what we could/should do

garisingh
2016-11-23 14:34
(brb - don't let the suspense kill you :wink: )

elli
2016-11-23 14:51
:smile:

garisingh
2016-11-23 14:57
So I'm in VSCC and my goal is to make sure that the transaction conforms to an endorsement policy which says that we need endorsement for 2 out of the 3 "participants/organizations/members (p/o/m)" that are part of the chain/channel. Of course our endorsement checking is based on digital signatures. So for each EndorsementResponse in the transaction, we need to verify the signature and extract the p/o/m. I'll assume X509 method for now (since honestly I don't know how to do this for IdentityMixer). So I need the signature and the bytes of the X509 certificate to: 1) validate that this identity comes from a trusted source: So I extract the X509 certificates bytes and in order to "validate" it I make sure that is was issued by a trusted authority (in this case a certificate authority which is trusted) 2) obtain the p/o/m For step 1) above, we have already figured out the "trusted authority" so now we need to determine if this authority is responsible for multiple p/o/m's. If responsible for multiple, what can we use from the signing certificate to uniquely identity it's p/o/m ? Clearly we can't use the CN since we assume that a p/o/m can have multiple peers and it would make sense for the CN to be the enrolled peer "name". So now we basically have the remainder of the DN to work with. We could require that you must specify the entire remainder of the DN to identify the p/o/m (easy) or we could require that you have an OU as the start of the remainder of the DN and use that (still easy) or we could allow you to have a variable field in the remainder of the DN and use an expression to extract it (hardest) 3) verify the signature (of course if X509/PKIX you could really combine 1 and 3 but we'll keep them separate for supporting other mechanisms such as identity mixer) Standard verify used here based on the type of signature and the algorithm specified as part of the fabric

garisingh
2016-11-23 15:00
So what does this mean coming from the other end - i.e. when you configure a new p/o/m to be part of a chain/channel? If each p/o/m uses their own certificate authority, then all you need is the their CA cert (and it's full chain if it's an intermediate authority). If multiple p/o/m's share the same certificate authority, you need to specify the CA cert (and its chain) as well as either the full DN suffix (the part after the CN) or the OU (assuming we force that convention)

garisingh
2016-11-23 15:02
So from any X509 public cert used for signing, you should be able to extract the issuer, find that in the list of trusted root authorities and if it has no "DNs" under it, just consider it the p/o/m else match both the issuer and the OU / DN suffix

garisingh
2016-11-23 15:04
So I would have though that we would have different provider types like "X509", "IdentityMixer", etc which we could use when initially "registering / creating / configuring" trusted authorities and that each CA/optional list of DNs would be used to instantiate instances of that type

garisingh
2016-11-23 15:05
seems like we have a lot more complexity right now

garisingh
2016-11-23 15:07
(sorry for the long winded writeup)

adc
2016-11-23 15:26
so, let me make sure I understood. An MSP should be instantiated by specifying a type, a set of trusted root certificates (CAs) and for each CA a list of DNs. Now a policy to say that an identity belong to a certain MSP might say something like: the identity must be valid against the trusted root certificates and it has to be in the list of DNs. Am I correct?

garisingh
2016-11-23 15:27
pretty close - devil in the details - but yes. And sometimes if there are no DNs, it's just the root certificate that identifies the p/o/m (my new term)

elli
2016-11-23 16:42
Hm, but ok. Lets take the example of a chain where org1 org2 and org3 participate.

elli
2016-11-23 16:43
their applications talk to each other and each of these orgs provide their msp info

elli
2016-11-23 16:43
so org1 uses ca1 as rootca

elli
2016-11-23 16:43
org2 uses ca2 as rootca

elli
2016-11-23 16:43
and org3 uses ca3 as rootca

elli
2016-11-23 16:44
btw, org1, org2, and org3 can be used to identify these msp-is in the chain genesis block

elli
2016-11-23 16:47
So in this case steps 1 and 3 are already supported by the MSP interfaces. For (2) one could easily add to the MSPManager a call returning the OU/CN of an id that is redirected to the associated MSP that would include some struct {mspid = {org1, org2, org3}, http://subject.CN, subject.OU}

elli
2016-11-23 16:48
would this suffice?

elli
2016-11-23 16:49
Othwerwise access policies if defined in terms of CAs may need to be updated each time an MSP updates its rootca

adc
2016-11-23 17:20
@elli, this also makes sense to me. @garisingh, is Elli closer to what you meant?

muralisr
2016-11-23 17:22
@adc @elli @garisingh caveat emptor - Im worse than a new born babe in these matters. let me ask one thing please

muralisr
2016-11-23 17:22
:slightly_smiling_face:

adc
2016-11-23 17:22
yes, please :slightly_smiling_face:

muralisr
2016-11-23 17:24
(1) asks is this ID valid ? and (3) asks can you verify this signature . correct ?

muralisr
2016-11-23 17:25

garisingh
2016-11-23 17:26

adc
2016-11-23 17:27

muralisr
2016-11-23 17:28
where I was going with this was (2) seems to say something different . is it (a) give me the p/o/m so I (say VSCC) can do further verifications OR (b) can you MSP verify id based on the p/o/m ? the later implies theres a policy associated with the MSP

muralisr
2016-11-23 17:29
(now Ill shut up :-))

garisingh
2016-11-23 17:30
I don't equate member with MSP or at least I don't like doing it that way. We are overall missing the concept of what I called p/o/m and I would look at its "membership" info as being an attribute of it. Let me look at the interfaces again but it just seems confusing to me

garisingh
2016-11-23 17:50
@muralisr: 2) comes into play so that you can determine the number of unique p/o/m's from which you have signatures. This is required because we will allow multiple peers per p/o/m and don't want to count 2 endorsements from the same p/o/m. It may be that vscc would not normally need to see this directly depending on how policy enforcement is executed but I could see cases where custom vscc would need to have access to the p/o/m's which endorsed a transaction

muralisr
2016-11-23 18:01
I think Im getting it @garisingh

muralisr
2016-11-23 18:01
lets take 2 propositions

muralisr
2016-11-23 18:01
1) 2 out of 3

muralisr
2016-11-23 18:02
2) (POM-1 || POM-2) && POM-3

muralisr
2016-11-23 18:03
the second one is easy we can easily ask MSP directly `msp.IsPOM(pom)` and evaluate the expression in VSCC

muralisr
2016-11-23 18:04
the first one illustrates the problem outlineted . its better stated as (1) 2 unique out of 3

muralisr
2016-11-23 18:06
for (1) then VSCC has to _retrieve_ POM from MSP and then do the checks itself so what would `msp.GetPOM(cert)` look like ? Hence the discussion on CN, DN, OU etc. sounded like we need to standardize on some convention to represent POMs for our purpose ?

garisingh
2016-11-23 18:10
Correct and correct

muralisr
2016-11-23 18:11
(whew)

yacovm
2016-11-23 20:28
1) Has it been already decided whether peers use SSL certificates signed by COP, or self-signed? 2) If they are signed by COP, are they *the same* certificates that are used to verify application-layer signatures by the `msp` layer inside the peer?

garisingh
2016-11-24 10:51
Hi @yacovm - 1) I think the real question here is what we support in terms of *trust* with respect to TLS certificates, meaning the most scalable method is to trust at a CA level, but of course we could explicitly trust individual certificates as well. But we can't support a peer generating a self-signed certificate on the fly without it sharing that certificate with the rest of the network prior to trying to communicate 2) While the same certificate CAN be used for both TLS and signing, not sure whether or not we should require this to be the case.

yacovm
2016-11-24 10:55
1) why? What if the peer first connects via ssl and then authenticates using the cop-signed credentials? 2) ok. I think we should go to the most flexible approach because flexibility is more adaptive

garisingh
2016-11-24 11:28
Let's say that peer1 tries to connect to peer2 via TLS. peer1 initiates the TLS connection and as part of the TLS handshake peer2 will send out its public TLS certificate. By default (which is actually secure), peer1 will check the following things: 1) hostname verification -peer1 checks to see whether or not the certificate from peer2 matches the hostname/IP which peer1 used to connect to peer2 (basically either the common name or one of the subject alternative names (SANs) need to match) 2) PKIX checking - peer1 checks to see whether or not it trusts the issuer of the certificate (which means that if it has no knowledge of the certificate itself or the root chain for the certificate it will never establish the TLS connection) You can override these parameters, but then TLS is essentially useless from a "trust" perspective and could only be used to secure the transport communication

yacovm
2016-11-24 12:08
That's all i'm saying. Maybe you can use tls just for that and authenticate the session in the gRPC handling method

yacovm
2016-11-24 12:09
Or use a signed by cop certificate which will be different than the msp one

yacovm
2016-11-24 12:09
(the one you use to sign messages manually)

yacovm
2016-11-24 12:10
But my question is- have these things been decided and coded? @garisingh ?

satyam_agl
2016-11-24 13:47
has joined #fabric-crypto

warm3snow
2016-11-26 09:34
Hi, guys. How the Tcert is used in the fabric network? I mean what field is necessary in the Tcert (x.509). From the whitepaper on http://github.com, I found the content of Tcert includes: [ TcertId, AES_Encrypt(pre_k, EnrollmentID), AES_Encrypt(TcertOwner_EncryptKey, TcertIndex), Sign_Verification_PublicKey, Key_Agreement_PublicKey, Validity_period) .etc. Here I want to know how to put these things into the Tcert.

warm3snow
2016-11-26 09:37
@garisingh @yacovm @muralisr

warm3snow
2016-11-26 09:45
The same meaning is that how do you guys use the Tcert. Just to verify the user's signature and check if the transaction is modified? I know users are anonymous in the fabric network, but what's the purpose of attributes in tcertRequest.json.

warm3snow
2016-11-26 09:46
And if it is a must, how can i put all the attributes stuff into the X509 certificates.

garisingh
2016-11-26 15:04
@warm3snow - the idea of Tcerts is to provide a mechanism for transactions to be "un-linkable" from the ledger perspective unless an authority provides the "key" to "re-link" the identities. The primary crypto is how TCert "private keys" are derived from the public enrollment key for an identity (the pre_k and tcert index stuff). As you gathered, the only "identities" in the system are provided via the public key which is used to sign transactions (and endorsements in v1.0). The default mechanism is X509 / PKIX so one includes the X509 public key along with the signature. While "un-linkable" identities solve one problem, they also create a challenge: if identity comes from the signing certificates and you never use the same signing certificate twice (as that would defeat un-linkability), how can you make any type of access control decision based on these identities? In order to solve that problem, we came up with the idea of *optionally* including encrypted attributes as part of TCerts. In the X509 case, we simply use standard X509 extension attributes as the "carrier" mechanism So when a batch of TCerts is created, you can specify which attributes to include (assuming they have been associated with the enrollment ID). In the end, these attributes are included to the certificate signing request for the TCert public key(s) included in the batch

warm3snow
2016-11-27 01:48
Thank you so so much, @garisingh.

jjmiranda
2016-11-28 00:22
has joined #fabric-crypto

weeds
2016-11-28 16:37
We are working on trying to get JIRA updated with this:

weeds
2016-11-28 16:38
This document contains work-items originally assigned to Crypto squad some of which were refined after our face-to-face: 1. MSP/chain configuration documentation. In RTP we had long discussions on what information needs to be passed to fabric MSPManager and/or to the default MSP (X509 based and/or COP-based). Configuration relates to parameters associated to the crypto material used by each MSP, but also policies that need to be respected to validate certificates/members or to reconfigure an MSP. We reached to certain conclusions that are to be documented with a changeset (partially done here: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2677/), and by updating its description here https://docs.google.com/document/d/1_vf5X5WPpECr0PsHM1XfPHB0gmoPJX9j_iGJ5_0mlmI/edit) Elli 2. Integration of MSP logic / flow to orderers. Ordering service nodes need to sign certain proto messages as well as reconfiguration transactions (e.g., genesis blocks). Currently this is done by them directly calling the corresponding crypto library. Here one would need to integrate the MSPManager and related interfaces to do signature generation and verification. Angelo 3. PeerMSP implementation. Here we need to implement the default MSP in golang, that is used by the peer, to parse tcerts/ecerts and confirm signatures generated with these tcerts/ecerts. This is already work that Ale has started within item (5). Ale 4. Integration of MSP Manager / MSP interfaces to the policy framework used for endorsement policies, certificate validation, etc. The policy framework mentioned above leverages an abstractly defined signing and signature verification interface that currently does nothing. We would need to implement that interface using MSPManager/default MSP. In addition, we may want to extend the MSP interface with the notion of MSP membership", e.g., a function that leverages certificate validation mechanisms to decide whether the certificate owner is a member of an MSP or not. This would work as a building block to support "identity group definitions" that could be leveraged inside policies. Ale 5. Continue and finalize security work needed on the endorser and committing peer side. VSCC parts that relate to policy evaluation would need to leverage interfaces defined in (3). This item also includes the bootstrapping of the security components of the system using a configuration file, and the components associated to channel security configuration when a channel genesis request is provided to the peer. Finally this also includes the creation of a a separate MSPManager per channel that is instantiated using the channel genesis block information. Ale https://jira.hyperledger.org/secure/RapidBoard.jspa?rapidView=65&view=planning&selectedIssue=FAB-581 https://jira.hyperledger.org/secure/RapidBoard.jspa?rapidView=65&view=planning&selectedIssue=FAB-580 https://jira.hyperledger.org/secure/RapidBoard.jspa?rapidView=65&view=planning&selectedIssue=FAB-399 https://jira.hyperledger.org/secure/RapidBoard.jspa?rapidView=65&view=planning&selectedIssue=FAB-824 6. Integrate MSP logic for the needs of the gossip network. Gossip squad has defined an interface to obtain a peer signature/verify a signature. We would need to implement this using MSP Manager/interfaces. This item requires collaboration with the consensus squad. Angelo 7. BCCSP support with keystore. We need to provide to BCCSP a pluggable keystore interface, where keys are stored. Angelo

weeds
2016-11-28 16:38
8. Application libraries design & implementation: - build a simple and attribute-based invocation access library; at a first stage this would be the definition of an MSP for the application purposes that leverages MSP capabilities to show attribute ownership/verify attribute ownership proof. Elli - build a simple (even as a small bc-csp extension of) encryption/decryption library as discussed with Binh. Design all. Implementation: Angelo 9. Security configuration schemas for peer initialization and chain setup. Elli. - content for it in changeset https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2677/

weeds
2016-11-28 16:45
Here is discussion from the above copy/paste of information Elli shared---> Gari is wondering how we make this more consumable. BCCSP seems clear,.. the overall design seems overly- complex though. COP in itself is x509 and straight forward. He suggested an incremental approach. Maybe I need an x509 certificate and we are going to do something based on organization-- all access control is done at org layer,.. map org to it's root. But what is MFP provider per organization isn't very clear in the specification.

weeds
2016-11-28 16:47
I want a create a chain- We decided to support multiple peers, we are not going to do at an individual peer level. We are going to do something at an organization level. I need to have one methodology- x509 based entities. In simplest terms,.. bank a, b, and c-- they need to provide root authorities they are going to use to issue their certificates. And then, there is a policy around how people are allowed to change the configuration and that has to be verified. I don't think you want a policy to change their own MSP- it should be a blockchain wide decision.

weeds
2016-11-28 16:47
We seem to be managing individual certificate authorities- but do we really want to support that?

weeds
2016-11-28 16:51
Elli thought maybe we need a hardcoded policy for admin access. She feels you do need to have that some entity needs to have some representation for an administrator. You may have root certificate authority and another "bank" to be added. What happens if two entities bank b and c use the same root certificate authority. Gari-> Then, we need to come up a model... go get an intermediate authority to issue, but then we would differentiate with distinguished name. But there is a lot of options here with a lot of complexity that is going to get very confusing. Elli-> We could actually remove some of the extra parameters, but what part do we want static and what do we want configurable? Configuration does increase the complexity...which can become a problem.

weeds
2016-11-28 16:53
Elli agreed with Gari and wondered if we stand back and refactor design after discussion. Gari is wondering do we start with simplest case and building up perhaps...

weeds
2016-11-28 16:55
Maybe what we do in the specification we write it as what problem we try to solve and go step by step on how you solve it.

weeds
2016-11-28 17:01
Question got asked-> how is the peer expected to learn the Genesis block? Jeff Garrat is concerned about bootstrapping and they are trying to work that out. On peer side- the genesis block is only there when peer joining channel. SDK would pass the peer (whichever peer they want on channel) it would send a transaction to system through configuration system chaincode and pass along the genesis block. that CRCC would try to understand and manipulate and start the gossip layer to contact what we call the anchor peers and start up the chain that way. Of course, eventually they would commit that block into the chain's ledger. Every ledger would start with genesis block that contains that information. And that configuration block will be modified at any time. That CRCC would get the modified information and would go through the same steps. The first draft of this is out there, but it's not complete yet. The change set is out there

weeds
2016-11-28 17:03
Assuming we have one MSP manager per chain- who is going to provide the MSP Manager with the root CA for that channel. Is it always going to come from CRCC? Or some stores on the peers filesystem? The MSP Manager is instantiated by some function of the peer or from CRCC. The part not included is not there yet. For every chain, there has to be an MSP Manager and a few other things and gossip group as part of that. --- whoever instruments will hand to MSP manager and will hand two things 1) stuff from genesis block 2) the local signing key pair and certificate pair for signing that change. Yes, that is correct assumption. The local stuff we get from YAML file currently. Any combination of peer and CRCC will pass that into the MSP manager per chain.

elli
2016-11-29 14:30
Hi, you may find here an updated version of the config files for the peer and chain init here:

elli
2016-11-29 14:30
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2677/

elli
2016-11-29 14:30
Also a diagram depicting the peer init config schema is attached here:

elli
2016-11-29 14:30
@elli uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/elli/F38U4H6CF/msp-config-diagram.ppt

elli
2016-11-29 14:52
@tuand , @jyellick you asked the mapping between this config and the configuration protos

elli
2016-11-29 14:53
IMHO since we now have no configurable policiess on the MSP side, we can represent each MSP's configuration as a single configuration item, whose modification policy would point to that MSP's admin

elli
2016-11-29 14:55
For chain readers/writers/deployers we would need the approval of chain admins

jyellick
2016-11-29 14:55
I haven't had a chance to review your changes since my comment, but, there was lots of other information in there, like ordering client byzantine assumptions etc.

elli
2016-11-29 14:55
right

elli
2016-11-29 14:55
this was based on the discussion we had

elli
2016-11-29 14:56
it can be that ordering service client component is already another config item with that ordering service admin implementing the modification policy for that item

elli
2016-11-29 14:57
overall chain config includes:

elli
2016-11-29 14:57
- list of msps: this is one config item per msp, with modification policy that msp's admin

elli
2016-11-29 14:58
- ordering service client config including the orderers certs, f, and one or more admin certificates: modification policy for that would be the hardcoded one provided by the admin certs

elli
2016-11-29 14:59
- chain permissions, for which modification policy is the hardcoded chain admin

elli
2016-11-29 14:59
- and chain admin a list of certificates again that need to cosign things.

elli
2016-11-29 15:00
Does it make sense?

jyellick
2016-11-29 15:02
Loosely yes, but it is the details that I'm wondering about. Concretely, what are the configuration items, their types, keys, values (with encoding), and modification policies (by name).

jyellick
2016-11-29 15:02
Basically what we started doing on the board in RTP the day your flight left

elli
2016-11-29 15:05
right so, to me there are no longer policies that need to appear in the chain sort of, cause "policies" are fixed (at least for the MSP) and hence relate to a list of certificates.

elli
2016-11-29 15:05
So as soon as we have the list of root certificate for an MSP, we use that one to validate certificates.

elli
2016-11-29 15:06
MSP admin is also a dedicated certificate that cn be the same as the root CA

anton
2016-11-29 15:14
has joined #fabric-crypto

jyellick
2016-12-01 19:54
@aso @adc What was the motivation for picking a `[]byte` for the `chainID` as opposed to a `string`? In one of @muralisr's recent changesets, he was referencing chainID by string and then converting it to a byte at the end. The string value has some advantages like being able to be used as a key in a map. @binhn had suggested changing the data structure, what do you think?

garisingh
2016-12-01 20:01
it its a string it should be a string :wink:

jyellick
2016-12-01 20:16
I think the idea was that it was a hash of some things, which, obviously can be represented as a hex string or something, but, it will be more compact in a byte representation. Enough more compact that we care? I doubt it, but maybe there are some other encoding problems with a string representation? I wouldn't think so, but since @aso and @adc picked bytes, I thought I'd make sure there wasn't some reason I'm blind to

adc
2016-12-01 20:18
Hi All, if I remember well in 0.6 the ChaincodeID is bytes because we wanted to encrypted it. We opted for the same in v1 having that in mind. Actually, string shouldnt be a big problem, we can always encode in base64 a ciphertext and put in a string.

muralisr
2016-12-01 20:25
@adc chainID is different from ChaincodeID and ChaincodeID was bytes only because it was a composite struct {path, name}

adc
2016-12-01 20:26
oh then that was good for us already :slightly_smiling_face:

adc
2016-12-01 20:29
anyway, it is fine to me to move it to string

muralisr
2016-12-01 21:09
now that Block2 change has been done, Ill take care of the remaining easy proto changes today (did I jinx it already :slightly_smiling_face: )

aso
2016-12-02 09:19
as a matter of fact, there's a bunch of fields which are `[]byte` because of the reason Angelo mentioned. This should be revisited

aso
2016-12-02 09:20
@jyellick @muralisr @adc can we quickly go through the protobufs and decide what has to stay a byte array and what can become an actual type?

aso
2016-12-02 09:25
examples: - Proposal.Header - ProposalResponse.Payload

aso
2016-12-02 09:25
(there are probably others)

adc
2016-12-02 10:11
I guess, those need to stay bytes for the marshaling issue, no?

muralisr
2016-12-02 11:58
@aso, @adc just saw this.

muralisr
2016-12-02 11:58

muralisr
2016-12-02 12:27

adc
2016-12-05 16:40
@garisingh @jzhang @binhn @muralisr @keithsmith @elli @aso @jonathanlevi Hi All, I have submitted this change-set https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2983/ to address ECDSA signature malleability

adc
2016-12-05 16:40
somthing that also bitcoin had to address in the past https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0062.mediawiki

adc
2016-12-05 16:41
I would like to ask to have a look at it, especially everyone who is working on client-sdks.

adc
2016-12-05 16:41
The change-set that I have submit enforces the same validity rules that bitcoin is enforcing on ecdsa signatures

adc
2016-12-05 16:42
it means that the client-sdks have to generate signatures in accordance in order to avoid rejection from the fabric

gemsiva

vdods
2016-12-07 10:01
There are two ways to specify configuration values -- they're both via this library "viper". One is via the command line, e.g. MEMBERSRVC_CA_ACA_ENABLED. This turns into the viper key "membersrvc.ca.aca.enabled", so for example, you could search for aca.enabled and find ``` srv := grpc.NewServer(opts...) if viper.GetBool("aca.enabled") { logger.Debug("ACA was enabled [aca.enabled == true]") aca.Start(srv) } ```

vdods
2016-12-07 10:01
that's in server.go

vdods
2016-12-07 10:02
The yaml files specify configuration values via the viper names, i.e. lower-case, where the periods delimit elements of the hierarchy of config vars

vdods
2016-12-07 10:02
so it's really just two ways to specify config values.. you might use env vars in a docker-compose.yml file

synblockchainteam
2016-12-07 10:15
Yes, its found in the "http://github.com\hyperledger\fabric\membersrvc\server.go" file. which is set as true... srv := grpc.NewServer(opts...) if viper.GetBool("aca.enabled") { logger.Debug("ACA was enabled [aca.enabled == true]") aca.Start(srv) } eca.Start(srv) tca.Start(srv) tlsca.Start(srv)

2016-12-08 14:53

yacovm
2016-12-08 14:55
in another context- @adc we only use self signed SSL certificates for unit tests. When the gossip runs inside the peer, a different constructor is used, and the gRPC service instance is passed from the peer to the gossip constructor. Also, the Dialoptions are passed, and a client TLS option can be included in that.

adc
2016-12-08 15:10
@yacovm, got it. @tuand So, for kakfa we need a proper TLS infrastructure. I guess, the administrator of the kafka network is in charge of put in place such a network and release appropriate TLS certficates for the client (in our case the orderers), no?

tuand
2016-12-08 15:20
we only want orderers from known orgs to connect to kafka ... so we need to give the kafka admin our org CA certs

tuand
2016-12-08 15:21
Kafka admin will in turn give us the CA cert for the Kafka brokers

adc
2016-12-08 15:23
but the orderers then need a TLS certificate signed by an authority that the kafka netwrok trusts

adc
2016-12-08 15:23
no?

tuand
2016-12-08 15:26
right ... we would put our org CA certs into Kafka's truststore ... when an orderer connect , it uses a certificate signed by one of our CAs so Kafka will accept the connection

kostas
2016-12-08 15:29
(Not following this discussion closely, but I just want to put it out there: @tuand let's make sure that whatever flow we adopt also works for this case: org A owns brokers 0-2, org B owns brokers 3-6, etc. This may or may not be completely orthogonal to the discussion.)

tuand
2016-12-08 15:31
right, kafka admin(s) might give us multiple CA certs which orderer would need to slurp in via a configurationItem

adc
2016-12-08 15:44
mhh, not clear, Tuan, you first said that fabric will put CA certs in kafka and then you said the opposite confirming what Kostas was saying, no? Am I missing something?

tuand
2016-12-08 15:53
the orderers need to have the Kafka brokers CA certs and Kafka needs to have the orderers' CA certs ... now, you can have multiple orgs owning kafka brokers or you can have a totally separate group owning kafka brokers ... we're ok as long as each side of the connection has the other side's CA certs so they can check incoming connection requests

adc
2016-12-08 15:56
ah okay, this I parse. I agree.

adc
2016-12-08 15:57
now, who is gonna generate TLS certificates?

adc
2016-12-08 15:57
I think it is not recommended to use the enrollment certificate for that

tuand
2016-12-08 15:57
it took me days to figure out what kafka wanted ! :weary:

adc
2016-12-08 15:58
heheh :slightly_smiling_face:

tuand
2016-12-08 16:00

adc
2016-12-08 16:00

tuand
2016-12-08 16:01

2016-12-08 16:01

adc

tuand
2016-12-08 16:04

garisingh
2016-12-08 16:16

vdods
2016-12-08 19:03
Hi all, what are the configuration vars relevant to choosing if ECerts or TCerts will be used in transactions? The docs mention that two schemes can be used -- look for "depending on whether the transaction is anonymous" under https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/docs/protocol-spec.md#433-replay-attack-resistance

vdods
2016-12-08 19:12
I'm finding it difficult to write code using TCerts only (though I believe what I'm doing should eventually be possible this way), and would prefer to start with using fixed ECerts, so that I can work directly with users' identities via ECerts.

vdods
2016-12-08 19:42

Is this correct? I don't see any indication of this ECert/TCert choice in HFC.

oliverledger
2016-12-08 21:15
has joined #fabric-crypto

binhn
2016-12-08 23:41

garisingh
2016-12-09 00:00
It's actually just writing some common code to load the raw certificates into the proper Go types that we are talking about here. Basically taking raw pem encoded certs and loafingvthem into the proper Go crypto objects

keithsmith
2016-12-09 00:03
Yes, will work and if someone wants a separate TLS cert for some reason, you could enroll twice ... once for TLS and once for ECert

vdods
2016-12-09 01:14
Can someone give me a sanity check? I'm running a peer with privacy enabled (which means that it uses TCerts that aren't linkable to the user identities, if I understand that correctly), and submitting transactions with confidentiality enabled (which means that the ledger state is encrypted). I run through a sequence of transactions, write to a particular key in my ledger state, shut all the services down, then run through the sequence again, checking that the state I set in the previous run is still there. The call to stub.GetState fails with "Decryption failed". However, if I run this whole scenario twice with transaction confidentiality disabled, it works fine. Is there some step I'm missing, or maybe I'm making a bad assumption (such as "enabling transaction confidentiality has no impact on the chaincode itself, confidentiality can just be enabled")?

garisingh
2016-12-09 11:39
@vdods - how are you submitting transactions? Via the REST API or via the SDK? FYI - the "privacy" setting in core.yaml is actually for encryption
