fbenhamo
2017-01-09 15:02
has joined #fabric-crypto

donna-dillenberger
2017-01-11 19:57
has joined #fabric-crypto

yacovm
2017-01-12 16:23
Who publishes CRLs / revokes root CAs and how is it done?

jonathanlevi
2017-01-12 16:41
Where, in general?

jonathanlevi
2017-01-12 16:41
Or in COP ?

jonathanlevi
2017-01-12 16:42
Also, CRLs for revoking E/TCerts or CA certs?

keithsmith
2017-01-12 16:46
I had originally intended to have an option in COP to do it so that it would not have to be implemented multiple times in apps ... when COP is being used, that is

keithsmith
2017-01-12 16:47
CRLs for revoking all of the above ... E/T/CA certs

yacovm
2017-01-12 16:49
How does that get to the ledger?

yacovm
2017-01-12 16:49
Or doesnt it?

keithsmith
2017-01-12 16:50
Yes, that is what I'm talking about. The COP server already supports revocation. What it doesn't currently support is pushing to the ledger

keithsmith
2017-01-12 16:51
So if you revoke an ECert, the COP server will prevent future requests for TCerts

keithsmith
2017-01-12 16:52
The COP server would have the private key to sign the request to the ledger to make the config change, so it seemed to make sense to have that as a default policy to allow the owner of a root of trust to revoke any cert that has been issued by that CA (i.e. COP server)

keithsmith
2017-01-12 16:54
Obviously other options, but this seems like one

yacovm
2017-01-12 16:54
So it contacts the orderer?

keithsmith
2017-01-12 16:54
yes

keithsmith
2017-01-12 16:55
Assuming the policy is a single signature by the root of trust

yacovm
2017-01-12 16:59
And revokes per chain? In all chains?

yacovm
2017-01-12 16:59
Is this implemwnted?

yacovm
2017-01-12 16:59
And who triggers cop?

keithsmith
2017-01-12 17:01
Yes, one orderer update per channel that the COP server is a member of.

keithsmith
2017-01-12 17:01
It is not implemented

keithsmith
2017-01-12 17:01
An administrator calls "cop client revoke" to the cop server

keithsmith
2017-01-12 17:02
cop client --> cop server --> multiple calls to orderer

yacovm
2017-01-12 17:02
Hmmm so the cop is per org or something right?

keithsmith
2017-01-12 17:02
yes

yacovm
2017-01-12 17:03
Got it. Thanks for the answers!

keithsmith
2017-01-12 17:03
yw

jokepk
2017-01-17 08:58
Hello guys, Im wondering if anyone knows if it is possible to get caller's user id from transaction from within the called chaincode function and how to do it?

dsanchezseco
2017-01-17 09:10
has joined #fabric-crypto

tsluthra
2017-01-17 15:57
has joined #fabric-crypto

jyellick
2017-01-17 18:24
@aso @adc @elli Are any of you around?

jyellick
2017-01-17 18:26
I am defining a `HashingAlgorithm` configuration parameter for the genesis block, and was wondering what reasonable parameters would be? The most simple would obviously be a `name` which could be `sha3_shake256` or whatnot, but I didn't know if there was a more standard way of representing this, maybe something like: `family=sha3` `algorithm=shake` `width=256`

jyellick
2017-01-17 18:34
(or perhaps a `string name = 1; bytes parameters = 2;` would be more flexible?)

elli
2017-01-17 18:35
I would follow the JCA example and add it as a string :slightly_smiling_face:

jyellick
2017-01-17 18:39
@elli Thanks! That sounds like a great idea to me. I see a whole bunch of names.... but nothing jumps out to me as sha3shake256

elli
2017-01-17 18:39
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/security/MessageDigest.html

jyellick
2017-01-17 18:39
I'm looking https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/guides/security/StandardNames.html Is there a beter reference?

elli
2017-01-17 18:41
ah so i would say that we either specify a type to include the hash functions we would support at the fabric, and add this as a field in the proto message, but no need to separate the hash function name from its length (e.g., SHA256)

elli
2017-01-17 18:42
or we can represent it as a string inside the genesis block and depending on the version we make the decision later if is among the ones we support

elli
2017-01-17 18:42
were you closer to the first path?

jyellick
2017-01-17 18:44
Yes, I think so

elli
2017-01-17 18:45
@jyellick the link you sent, only contains SHA-1, SHA-256, SHA-384, and SHA-512

jyellick
2017-01-17 18:45
Right, I'm trying to find the JCA name for sha3 shake256 with 512 bytes of output

jyellick
2017-01-17 18:45
(ie, what `util.ComputeCryptoHash` produces)

garisingh
2017-01-17 18:45
don't use SHA3

garisingh
2017-01-17 18:45
:wink:

jyellick
2017-01-17 18:46
I think configurable is good... we are already using sha-3 (shake256 with 512 bits of output) for our hashes, that seemed easiest.

garisingh
2017-01-17 18:47
I was joking of course

jyellick
2017-01-17 18:47
Oh, and here I thought I'd heard people actually complaining about sha-3 being too slow...

elli
2017-01-17 18:47
:slightly_smiling_face:

garisingh
2017-01-17 18:47
well I'd default to SHA2-256 or SHA2-384 (but that's just me)

elli
2017-01-17 18:48
right, i would vote for the same

jyellick
2017-01-17 18:48
I'd think switching hasing algorithms shouldn't be too painful.... we just need a way to specify it. The JCA ID sounds like a good plan to me, just can't find a list that includes the sha-3 shake256 in it

elli
2017-01-17 18:49
sha3 is relatively (to the others) new, and people complain about it not having been tested enough, or that it is not supported by their systems.

garisingh
2017-01-17 18:49
the SHA3 names analogous to above: SHA3-224, SHA3-256, SHA3-384, SHA3-512 SHAKE128, SHAKE256

garisingh
2017-01-17 18:49
(well that's how NIST lists them)

jyellick
2017-01-17 18:50
Perfect, so, to start since it's what's working, we'll just use a string, and require it to be `SHAKE256` and later, we'll add support for the other ones, possibly changing the default

garisingh
2017-01-17 18:52
glad to be of service sir :wink:

jyellick
2017-01-17 18:52
Thanks much!

jyellick
2017-01-17 19:47
@garisingh You still around?

jyellick
2017-01-17 19:57
Posting it here in case anyone else would like to chime in, but the second piece of chain configuration I was about to add is regarding the `BlockDataHashingStructure`. In particular, this could like be a flat concatenation, or a Merkle tree. In the case of a Merkle tree, it needs a width (how many nodes per level in the tree). Most likely for efficiency reasons, this will not be binary. So, I was looking at how to encode this, we could: 1. Use the proto oneof structure, explicitly enumerating which hashing schemes are supported (at the cost of third parties not being able to easily extend this field) 2. Use a "string name" and "bytes parameters" structure, so that more arbitrary structures could be supported (at the cost of the opacity of the parameters requiring yet another unmarshaling of binary data) 3. Only support the type of Merkle, where in order to replicate flat hashing, we would simply set the width of the Merkle tree to be equal to the maximum number of messages.

garisingh
2017-01-17 19:59
I am

garisingh
2017-01-17 20:03
@jyellick - definitely agree that we should not have multiple "types" - I like point 3 above for just that reason. In that same vein, is there really a reason to allow different hashing schemes? (I understand having something for future proofing / future pluggability, but is there some specific reason you can think of to have multiple options on day 1?)

garisingh
2017-01-17 20:04
2) makes sense to me for extensibility

jyellick
2017-01-17 20:05
I mostly wanted us to be able to flip between tunable Merkle and flat, since there seemed to be some dissent about which was better. And, figured "if we allow two, do we really want to allow only two"?

garisingh
2017-01-17 20:06
ah - ok - so the scheme is merkle or flat - not the actual hashing algorithm

garisingh
2017-01-17 20:06
makes sense to me - and I am fine if "flat" = Merkel with max num messages

jyellick
2017-01-17 20:06
Well, I broke it into two pieces. HashingAlgorithm, which today we only support shake256, and then scheme which I called BlockDataHashingStructure

garisingh
2017-01-17 20:07
got it

jyellick
2017-01-17 20:07
Perfect, so, Merkle only, and set the width to batch size or MAX_UINT32 if you want flat

jyellick
2017-01-17 20:07
Thanks again @garisingh !

garisingh
2017-01-17 20:08
seems to be the most expedient way to go

jyellick
2017-01-17 20:08
Was my favorite option as well

daisaku
2017-01-17 23:27
has joined #fabric-crypto

jyellick
2017-01-20 06:53
Tagged many as reviewers, but this may be of general interest to the channel. https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4599/ The above CR defines a deterministic marshaling scheme for block headers.

alanlee
2017-01-20 12:36
Hi, we traced the source code in v0.6. It seems that there is no checking to prevent malicious node to join the peer network(to trigger INVOKE and QUERY) as long as the malicious node get the shared chain key from other nodes. Is it true? Thank you.

garisingh
2017-01-20 12:39
@alanlee - if they have not obtained their enrollment material (ECert) from membership services they will not be able to invoke or query the network. this of course assumes that you enable security

garisingh
2017-01-20 12:40
all invoke and query requests must be signed by a valid certificate issued by membership services

garisingh
2017-01-20 12:41
but if you are saying that they "steal" someone else's enrollment private/public key pair then yes - they can join

alanlee
2017-01-20 12:42
But another node does not Check the Ecert, right?

alanlee
2017-01-20 12:42
I mean Node B won't check the Ecert from Node A..... They only check the ECert's CA validity..?

alanlee
2017-01-20 12:43
Thus, if Node A (malicious) generated its own Ecert.....Node B will not know ?....

garisingh
2017-01-20 12:45
well in v0.6, when Node A tries to communicate with Node B (with security enabled), Node B will actually check with membership services to see if membership services issued the certificate and actually downloads the public X509 cert for Node A (at least as I recall)

garisingh
2017-01-20 12:46
so Node A would need to compromise membership services for what you mention to work

garisingh
2017-01-20 12:51
@adc @jonathanlevi ^^^^

alanlee
2017-01-20 12:58
Thanks @garisingh . I am actually with below 2 situations in v0.6. (Moment 1) For Peer-to-Peer Connection, we have enabled TLS (with a bit code changed). When Peer A connect to Peer B (Root Validator), Peer A will check Peer B(Root Node) TLS cert. (Not sure if Peer B(Root) has checked the Peer A TLS). (Moment 2) When node A is "INVOKE" and send to node B(Root), T-cert(from membershipservice) at Node A will be used to sign the transaction. ...... can you remind me which step will we use ECert ?(Thank you). ....and ..... it seems Node A can be malicious if this is true.... Thank you.

garisingh
2017-01-20 13:06
If you are using REST to perform an INVOKE against Peer A, in this case Peer A is actually acting as more of a "virtual client / wallet" as well as a validating node (assuming it's a validator and not an NVP). Recall that with security enabled, before you can INVOKE chaincode via REST you must login. When you login via REST what happens is that Peer A enrolls with membership services on your behalf. When you later pass the enrollID in the SecureContext field of the REST request, Peer A uses the enrollment certificate to call membership services and receive TCerts on behalf of the client

alanlee
2017-01-20 13:43
In this case, suppose Peer A is compromised, and Peer A generates fake TCert and send to Peer B(Root Node). Peer B will verify TCert come from real membership service, right ? (Let me try to trace then ....) Thank you.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:45
Good morning. I dont understand this part *Peer A generates fake TCert*

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:45
(not to be picky, just making sure that we are on the same page/scenario):

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:46
So PeerA requests (say a batch of) TCerts when we know that he/she might have been compromised or a bad actor?

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:47
[because its the MS that actually issues them TCerts, right?]

alanlee
2017-01-20 13:48
Good morning Johnathan. For example, I set up two clusters: first clusters are truely used by banks (with memebership service A). second cluster with membership service). ...... If I copied the TCert generated in the second cluster node rocksdb to NODE A in first cluster .... (it means NODE A is compromised) .... will other node in the first cluster notice this ?.....

alanlee
2017-01-20 13:48
Actually, I want to see if NODE A is compromised... and use "some ways" to generate T-certs, can it trick other nodes ...

alanlee
2017-01-20 13:49
(Note: second cluster use another membership service B)

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:49
OK, we should split this to two cases. Sorry :wink:

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:49
Yes, got you.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:50
1. A compromised/rogue Membership Service server, say MS_B

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:50
2. A compromised/rogue player working with an honest Membership Service server

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:52
The main thing here is about the trust-model, right? That is, on basis did cluster A nodes, that work with MS_A, based their trust on (T)Certs signed/issued by the MS of cluster B, our lovely MS_B.

alanlee
2017-01-20 13:53
yes.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:54
OK, thanks for confirming.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:54
So now, when you are asking *will other node in the first cluster notice this ?*

alanlee
2017-01-20 13:54
yes. (to identify malicious node in the cluster)

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:54
In the first place, we do verify signatures and their validity.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:54
Wait, heres the catch.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:55
The dry-cold-boring-has-no-feelings kinda of MS_A, does not really know what is compromised...

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:56
It either accepts (or say, verifies successfully) a given signature, or not (that is rejects, or fails to verify it)

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:57
In a way, Fabric and MS in particular, provide you with the framework for issuing certs/validating signatures, etc.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:57
Now, it is possible to set up a policy as to what a server should (and of course *should not*) trust.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:57
If you agree with me so far.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:58
Then we get back to this point:

alanlee
2017-01-20 13:58
yes.... sorry, i don' understand "set up a policy as to what a server should (and of course *should not*) trust."

alanlee
2017-01-20 13:58
and agree all the rest...

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:59
Oh, good you stopped me. Thanks.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:59
When you have only one MS, and everybody just trusts that one it is simple but there is less flexibility.

alanlee
2017-01-20 13:59
yep

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 13:59
That is, if we invalidate / not trust any certs from that MS, we wont be able to trust anything issued by that MS from a certain point in time, or otherwise.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:01
When you work with more than one, there is some from of a PKI hierarchy, so that anyone validating a cert, kinda trusts signatures that are/were issued by both MS_A and MS_B.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:01
Otherwise, you cant inter-operate. You would trust only MS_A from the get-go. Yes?

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:02
Now, if you never trusted MS_B..

alanlee
2017-01-20 14:03
yes..... so MS_A and MS_B have to co-operate somehow to make it happen ...

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:03
Right

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:03
Thank you. So now when you see a certificate, you validate it against the Public key of the MS_*.

alanlee
2017-01-20 14:03
yes

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:04
So MS_A and MS_B will issue diffferent certificates and you can check/validate/verify it.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:05
The question in your case I believe is what to revoke"

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:06
Do we revoke all of MS_B or is it just one node.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:06
When its one node, I simply revoke its ECert and BOOM, he/she is out.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:07
(You need the ECert to obtain subsequent TCerts)

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:07
But if its the entire MS_B then we need to inform MS_A about it.

alanlee
2017-01-20 14:07
but Node will get a batch of 200 Tcert from membership service at once ...

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:08
(Its customizable, but yes). I have 1..200 TCerts.

alanlee
2017-01-20 14:08
so, we need to invalidate those Tcerts in Node A

alanlee
2017-01-20 14:08
when ECert is out

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:08
Yes, I invalidate everything.

alanlee
2017-01-20 14:09
... and NODE B (in cluster 1) can verify it by checking the TCert ?

alanlee
2017-01-20 14:09
in the transaction ( INVOKE at node A)

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:10
OK, thats the policy bit from above. The way I implemented something similar on top of Fabric/MS we always check that no certificate has been revoked.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:11
It comes with a price (longer set-up, can be slow for more high-frequency usages) but sometimes (probably like in your case), you need it.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:12
We revoke everything right away, keep the log of why and actually provide it to the manager as something to consider with new enrollment requests"

alanlee
2017-01-20 14:12
so the "policy" means "NODE B will verify" is optional/configurable ?

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:12
I know that there are many that use Fabric/MS v0.6 without these checks, and its indeed quicker.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:13
Yes, its like in your web-browser, in a way.

alanlee
2017-01-20 14:13
i see... And in our case, we need it... because we worry that nodes got compromised ....

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:14
Obviously I dont have all the info, but for financial applications - I would go slow and steady.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:14
Dont trust TCerts blindly. I agree.

alanlee
2017-01-20 14:14
...but how to make it work if we really need it ? .... to check the TCert at Node B?

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:15
So to summarize:

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:15
1. Each issued certificate has that signature that tells you who is the issuer

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:16
2. You can have your own logic on a receipt of such a cert at the membership services layer", and make decisions whether youd trust that.

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:16
3. You can invalidate certs and keys of a node and even a full MS cluster"

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 14:17
4. There is logic that many add to the application layer when it comes to trust (what to trust, how much, for how long, etc.)

alanlee
2017-01-20 14:20
Thanks @jonathanlevi . I intend to make it work. What is the good way to verify TCert at Node B? Real-time connecting to MS and checking revoke status ? ... (Sorry for bother you and garisingh for so long...you both are smart and knowledgeable...)

jyellick

silliman
2017-01-20 15:08

elli
2017-01-20 15:16
So the dataHash is shake256 on protobuf marshalled bytes correct?

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 15:17
DataHash in BlockHeader?

adc
2017-01-20 15:19
@jyellick, thanks. I read your comment, I'm fine with ti. Then I would ensure that there is a version somewhere that can be used to bind the way the blockheader is converted to bytes

adc
2017-01-20 15:19
because the way you marshal, you are implicitly assuming that the hash function has always 256 bits of about

adc
2017-01-20 15:19
but this might change in the future

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:19
@elli So, the hashing algorithm gets defined in the genesis block, for now, the only supported one is shake256

adc
2017-01-20 15:19
right, right

adc
2017-01-20 15:20
actually, I found out that yesterday

adc
2017-01-20 15:20
and I found it pretty neat

adc
2017-01-20 15:20
the only thing to change is that the hash should be computed by the BCCSP

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:20
The `DataHash` will actually be computed via Merkle tree of configured width, and for flat hashing, we can just make the width `MAX_UINT32`

adc
2017-01-20 15:20
but that I can change easly

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:20
Perfect.

adc
2017-01-20 15:21
so, If one customize the hash function to be SHA2-384

elli
2017-01-20 15:21
@jonathanlevi I refer to this description: This changeset chooses the following simple scheme: Concatenate the following: 8 bytes BigEndian encoded Number PreviousHash DataHash

elli
2017-01-20 15:21
I am guessing that DataHash is the Merkle root of the transaction tree

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:21
It is

elli
2017-01-20 15:21
in that block

elli
2017-01-20 15:21
but transactions are protobuf marshalled no?

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:22
Will have another CR to address DataHash

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:22
Ah, but the transctions are _stored_ marshaled

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:22
So they are already bytes, no need to worry about re-marshaling them.

elli
2017-01-20 15:23
right right

jonathanlevi
2017-01-20 15:23
@elli thanks for the context.

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:23
So, @adc I'm quite happy _not_ to use the concatenation scheme, if ASN.1 is normal, we should do normal

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:23
We were simply using protbuf before, which is certainly wrong

elli
2017-01-20 15:24
Right so no window for non-determinism there, you are saying cause it is the same tx bytes that everyone receive

adc
2017-01-20 15:24
yes, please. By default, ASN.1 guarantees the minimum representation

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:24
And my crypto-naive mind thought concatenation was easy

adc
2017-01-20 15:24
and we will be generic enough

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:24
Great, I will fix that up then

adc
2017-01-20 15:24
perfect :slightly_smiling_face:

garisingh
2017-01-20 15:25
and you can nicely serialize Go structs to ASN1 encoding

adc
2017-01-20 15:25
yeah :slightly_smiling_face:

elli
2017-01-20 15:26
But we should use ASN.1 for all the fields no? meaning also for the DataHash bytes.

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:26
Well, the `DataHash` we said is going to be computed via a configurable width Merkle tree

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:27
And since `BlockData` is nothing but repeated byte arrays, it seems like there's no need for any ASN.1 representation?

ashutoshkumar
2017-01-20 15:28
ASN1 seems the right way to go.

ashutoshkumar
2017-01-20 15:29
go ASN lib is pretty cool.

elli
2017-01-20 15:29
@jyellick, right right. My bad :slightly_smiling_face:

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:30
Perfect, thanks, you had me doubting myself

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:51
So, my naive attempt to use `encoding/asn1` over the block header gives me: `asn1: structure error: unknown Go type: uint64` is there a standard way of handling uint64's in asn1?

jyellick
2017-01-20 15:56
(@elli @aso @adc @garisingh @ashutoshkumar ^)

adc
2017-01-20 15:58
https://jannewmarch.gitbooks.io/network-programming-with-go-golang-/content/dataserialisation/asn1.html

adc
2017-01-20 15:58
Go places real restrictions on ASN.1. For example, ASN.1 allows integers of any size, while the Go implementation will only allow upto signed 64-bit integers. On the other hand, Go distinguishes between signed and unsigned types, while ASN.1 doesn't. So for example, transmitting a value of uint64 may fail if it is too large for int64.

adc
2017-01-20 15:59
it is a mess :slightly_smiling_face:

jyellick
2017-01-20 16:23
Not a great pitch for asn1 but, I suppose we will have to leave a chain running for quite a while before we exhaust the 63 bits

jyellick
2017-01-20 16:25
So the suggested solution would be to declare some shadow structure, where block number is an int64, and marshal that?

jyellick
2017-01-20 16:25
@adc ^

adc
2017-01-20 16:27
right, but then we have to check that the int64 is non-negative

adc
2017-01-20 16:28
just to be sure that nothing strange happens

jyellick
2017-01-20 16:28
Right, will test for that and panic

garisingh
2017-01-20 16:29
don't panic @jyellick - all will be ok :wink:

garisingh
2017-01-20 16:29
haha

jyellick
2017-01-20 16:35
Got it! ``` asn1Header := asn1Header{ PreviousHash: b.PreviousHash, DataHash: b.DataHash, } if b.Number > uint64(math.MaxInt64) { return []byte("@garisingh says don't panic!") } else { asn1Header.Number = int64(b.Number) } result, err := asn1.Marshal(asn1Header) if err != nil { return []byte("Just ask @garisingh!") } return result ```

jyellick
2017-01-20 16:41
(@aso @adc @elli @garisingh pushed an update to the CR if you care to review)

garisingh
2017-01-20 16:49
hehe

elli
2017-01-20 16:53
("@garisingh says don't panic!") :smile:

tuand
2017-01-20 19:48

jyellick
2017-01-25 15:36
@jzhang @rickr @adc Since #fabric-dev seems a little busy, can we move the ASN.1 discussion here? > I'm still trying to understand why the SDK ever needs to compute this hash

adc
2017-01-25 15:58
sure,

adc
2017-01-25 15:58
@jyellick, may you join the discussion here

jyellick
2017-01-25 16:00
Yep, I'm here

adc
2017-01-25 16:03
so, I don't want to stress on using ASN.1

rickr
2017-01-25 16:03
The block header has the headerNumber

adc
2017-01-25 16:03
it is used for cryptographic objects

adc
2017-01-25 16:03
but it might be avoided in certain case

jyellick
2017-01-25 16:03
Ah, it is still encoded as protobuf, but when we compute the hash, we marshal it to ASN.1

adc
2017-01-25 16:03
expecially if there is a signature that authenticate everything

jyellick
2017-01-25 16:03
@rickr You do not need to understand ASN.1 to simply read the block header

jyellick
2017-01-25 16:03
We are only encoding to ASN.1 when computing the hash

rickr
2017-01-25 16:04
I'm seeing a need for that some time in the future

jyellick
2017-01-25 16:04
What is the need?

rickr
2017-01-25 16:05
in case of an eventHub looking at blocks on a fail over we don't want to process the same block again

jyellick
2017-01-25 16:06
@rickr I do not follow. With only protobuf, and no ASN.1, you can read the block number from the block header.

rickr
2017-01-25 16:07
y

rickr
2017-01-25 16:07
we can unmarshal it as regular protobuf

jyellick
2017-01-25 16:08
Yes, the block structure is protobuf

rickr
2017-01-25 16:08
if it's encoded it in ASN.1 then we need libaries to handle that . That would would mean the same for any other toolkit /languse

jyellick
2017-01-25 16:08
It is not encoded in ASN.1

rickr
2017-01-25 16:08
ok maybe I missed that

jyellick
2017-01-25 16:09
When we compute the _hash_ of the block header, to get the bytes to compute the hash over, we temporarily encode the header via ASN.1 to bytes deterministically. We then compute the hash over these temporary bytes, and store the hash normally in the proto structures.

rickr
2017-01-25 16:10
ok so when it comes to the toolkit doing the verification so we can trust it .. does it not need to do the same ?

jyellick
2017-01-25 16:11
It depends on how you are establishing trust. My understanding, was that the toolkit does not retain the entire blockchain, but simply queries against a peer to get ledger state. Is that correct?

rickr
2017-01-25 16:12
From the eventHub we get block events . One block at a time .

jyellick
2017-01-25 16:25
And how do you ensure that the eventHub is sending you real blocks?

jyellick
2017-01-25 16:29
@rickr This is my ignorance, but I'm not sure where the difference is between the peer and the SDK. If the SDK needs the full blockchain, and needs to validate the full blockchain, then it seems to me like it is acting exactly as a peer. So it seems like that cannot be the case to me. If you are querying the blocks from the peers, and trusting the peer to reply with the correct block requested, then I do not what computing the block header hash could be useful for.

rickr
2017-01-25 16:31
@jyellick Probably my ignorance. As of the moment I only think we need verify each block we get from the event hub

jyellick
2017-01-25 16:32
What does it mean to verify a block from the SDK perspective?

rickr
2017-01-25 16:35
@pmullaney To verify each block we get from the eventhub stream what signature and across which bytes will we need to verify against ?

jzhang
2017-01-25 16:43
@rickr @jyellick @pmullaney i dont know if the SDK needs to do any verification of blocks

jzhang
2017-01-25 16:43
it needs to be hooked up to a trusted event source (a trusted peer) in the first place

jyellick
2017-01-25 16:44
If the SDK trusts its peer, then I don't foresee any reason why the SDK needs to recompute the block header hash

jyellick
2017-01-25 16:44
(And therefore, no ASN.1 is needed at the SDK side)

jzhang
2017-01-25 16:44
if that assumption is not true, then many things start falling apart

rickr
2017-01-25 16:44
@jzhang Then why the need for verification anywhere else ?

yuki.k
2017-01-25 16:48
has joined #fabric-crypto

jzhang
2017-01-25 17:08
@rickr the only other place that SDK is doing verification is when it receives proposal responses from endorsers, and that check is needed because endorsers from other orgs are not to be trusted

jzhang
2017-01-25 17:10
i should say that SDK needs to do verification .... (because node.js hasnt done that yet and as far as i know neither does Java SDK) :wink:

gennady.laventman
2017-01-25 17:10
has joined #fabric-crypto

matanyahu
2017-01-25 19:15
has joined #fabric-crypto

sukrit
2017-01-25 21:33
has joined #fabric-crypto

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:40
so continuing the discussion on #fabric-pr-review re: importing private keys.

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:40
@ashutoshkumar @jzhang current BCCSP only needs the SKI

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:40
@vpaprots says: - get private key pem file, parse - if a SKI PEM header, great, how we should do it - else try to import key into currernt/default csp

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:41
no need for a path

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:41
but that requires the bccsp impl of getKey(ski) to know how to work with an arbitrary external key store

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:41
right

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:41
which I dont know how thats possible unless its pkcs11

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:41
that is part of bccsp initialization

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:41
but theres no equivalent spec for software based key stores right?

ashutoshkumar
2017-01-25 21:41
it is file based AFAIK for SW based system.

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:41
the sw bccsp initialization takes a directory location for keystore

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:42
but that happens only at initialization

ashutoshkumar
2017-01-25 21:42
so , if you have .p12 or java keystore ,it is not going to work.

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:42
it does but how to actually do the look up with the keystore given the ski, thats all implementation-specific

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:42
so in the end a bccsp impl can only work with one specific keystore

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:42
well.. that would mean another bccsp perhaps if you want a java keystore..

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:42
in other words, the private key must exist in the bccsps own key store

ashutoshkumar
2017-01-25 21:43
yes.

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:43
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4397/8

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:43
have a look at the testdata directory

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:44
I've created a sw keystore and imported it so that the test cases had something static to run against

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:44
the sw keystore (@adc 's invention) stores keys by ks/<ski>_<type>

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:45
given an `ski []byte` it will do a directory lookup for `ks/<ski>_*`

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:45
suppose i have java-based tool that does the CA enrollment for my app, so the private key is stored in a `keystore` file in my jvm folder

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:46
how am i to find those keys from node.js SDK?

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:46
!

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:46
now its getting interesting! :smile:

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:46
i would have to code up an adapter of some sort that understands jvm keystores

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:46
and this goes on for every different kinds of keystores

ashutoshkumar
2017-01-25 21:47
from Node , you cannot read java key store.

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:47
so what im saying is instead this could be done using the procedure i was describing earlier, as a one-time import

ashutoshkumar
2017-01-25 21:47
you need to convert java key store to p12 and then read from node.

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:48
@ashutoshkumar exactly what im saying (well i suppose you could have node call java to read, etc.) but the point is youd have to write code to do that, vs. doing a manual export -> import procedure thats a one-time deal

ashutoshkumar
2017-01-25 21:49
Jim , you are out of luck with using existing key store in bccSP for SW based system.

ashutoshkumar
2017-01-25 21:49
that might improve in future.

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:49
A bit confused about the situation.. java tool that handles enrollment?

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:50
could any other kind of tool that enrolls with a CA thats not fabric-ca

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:50
cant we have a golang tool? :smile:

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:50
that uses BCCSP? :smile:

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:50
just using java as an example to illustrate the point

ashutoshkumar
2017-01-25 21:50
but it has to be done natively in SDK , I guess.

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:52
I was talking to Jeff earlier, he was showing me the boostrap feature he is working on.. got me thinking how it would integrate with BCCSP. Its CLEARLY a problem :disappointed:

adc
2017-01-25 21:53

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:53

adc

vpaprots

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:53

adc
2017-01-25 21:53

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:53

adc
2017-01-25 21:53

jzhang
2017-01-25 21:53

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:54

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:55

jzhang

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:57
@adc secrets in pem files only work with SW bccsp. Well, technically I got it to work with PKCS11 BCCSP, but @tvi tells me key import is disabled for FIPS lvl>3

vpaprots
2017-01-25 21:58
a 'fairly transparent' interface is to use the same option that specifies the key-pem for actually reading in a SKI, which is then used to load from default bccsp keystore

adc
2017-01-25 22:01
ah but then I would say that for behave tests, the best you can hope is to use SoftHSM no?

adc
2017-01-25 22:01
actually, we should move the fabric to digest SKIs directly

adc
2017-01-25 22:01
without having to do key import, no?

vpaprots
2017-01-25 22:01
yep

vpaprots
2017-01-25 22:01
wont happen immediatelly

vpaprots
2017-01-25 22:01
so import it is for now

vpaprots
2017-01-25 22:02
but we need to move that way

vpaprots
2017-01-25 22:02
(I would certainly want to be able to run behave with actual crypto card)

vpaprots
2017-01-25 22:04
@jzhang https://developers.yubico.com/yubico-piv-tool/YKCS11_release_notes.html

vpaprots
2017-01-25 22:05
since some people might run nodejs on their own machines..

vpaprots
2017-01-25 22:05
using yubico for them to store their certs.. through Gong's pkcs11 implementation.. that would be very neat.

vpaprots
2017-01-25 22:06
we are probably nearly there too

vpaprots
2017-01-25 22:06
(not sure if you've heard of yubico before..)

vpaprots
2017-01-25 22:06
I have one that I use for my password manager and email..

jzhang
2017-01-25 22:12
@vpaprots so i think you and @adc are essentially proposing to have bccsp be based on pkcs11 so itll have a standard protocol with private key management via SKI, and thus can delegate the storage to different keystore impls (software or hsm), do i understand it right?

vpaprots
2017-01-25 22:13
right on "private key management via SKI, and thus can delegate the storage to different keystore impls", but disagree with "bccsp be based on pkcs11"

jzhang
2017-01-25 22:13
not completely

jzhang
2017-01-25 22:13
just for the key storage part

vpaprots
2017-01-25 22:14
well.. current SW bccsp has two keystore already.. FileBasedKeystore and a DummyKeyStore.. we could probably add a few more

vpaprots
2017-01-25 22:16
as part of SW bccsp configuration, one can specify which keystore to use, so we could acomodate JKS and P12 perhaps? the point is, apart from SKI, the 'developer' should not care about how the key is stored

vpaprots
2017-01-25 22:16
the FileBasedKeystore actually stores things are pem files (back to where we started? :smile: )

ashutoshkumar
2017-01-25 22:25
you can store PEM files as concatented form. But that requires BCCSP to change.

adc
2017-01-25 22:32
actually, if you want to change the way crypto objects are stored, you just need to provide a new implementation of the KeyStore interface

adc
2017-01-25 22:32
that's it

vpaprots
2017-01-25 23:17
https://github.com/pavel-v-chernykh/keystore-go :wink:

jonathan.tan
2017-01-26 02:58

jonathan.tan
2017-01-26 03:17

oiakovlev
2017-01-26 09:34
Hi, all. Maybe a bit silly question but: how consensus work when confidentiality is enabled? As if it is set I guess that other peers will receive encrypted transaction payload, right? If they don't have appropriate keys they will not be able to decrypt them and execute the transaction? Or do I mess up the things peers will always have needed keys to decrypt/encrypt and only enrolled user will miss them (which I guess is not the case as peer also has enrolled user, so has only some subset of certificates, right?)? My question is based on v06 but I guess it would be similar for v1 if we are talking in context of single channel?

elli
2017-01-26 12:04
When confidentiality is on transactions are encrypted on the sdk side using a chain-specific public (encryption) key. The corresponding decryption key in V0.6 is given to all validators that can decrypt transactions and execute them accordingly.

elli
2017-01-26 12:04
It is only the payload of trnasactions that is encrypted, so all the rest of information, i..e, signing certificate, nonce, are in the clear.

elli
2017-01-26 12:05
In v1 there is no fabric encryption capabilities yet.

oiakovlev
2017-01-26 12:13
thanks @elli just to double check my understanding - so let's say I invoke transaction: "transfer A 1 to B" which will be stored in encrypted way in ledger but during execution time all peers see raw data, right?

elli
2017-01-26 12:13
correct

oiakovlev
2017-01-26 12:14
if so, is not there an option for some sort of "man in the middle attack" so if I listen to VM bytecode execution on the peer - I technically can grab all raw data?

oiakovlev
2017-01-26 12:15
so the data stored to the ledger is encrypted - this is fine but there still seems to be a gap when some sensistive data can be read or do I misunderstood it?

garisingh
2017-01-26 14:47
not sure why it's a gap? of course you need to protect your own peer if you don't want people interfering with its internal operations

oiakovlev
2017-01-26 15:36
my own peer - yes but let's say the idea is that if I have 3 banks (A, B and C) and I want that they see only transactions addressed to each other. This is possible to manage using enrolled users, right? so data in ledger is encrypted and only users with correct attributes can encrypt it, right? So as soon as transaction is stored to the ledger, if I have correct permissions I can decrypt it, otherwise - no. But during execution each peer see raw content, so technically bank C can monitor transactions between A and B is not it an issue? Or do I get things wrong?

oiakovlev
2017-01-26 15:40
This question is about v06 and I realize that in v1 there will be channels, which should some sort of address this issue but even having channels question seems to be still valid.

oiakovlev
2017-01-26 18:08
Any thoughts on this? Is my understanding correct or do I miss something?

elli
2017-01-26 18:19
So in v0.6 we have validators doing the ordering of transactions and afterwards the execution / commitment of transaction results. If banks A, B, C have no validators and have only clients in that blockchain network, then a technique similar to what you way can be leveraged, i.e., have client of Bank A encrypt its transaction, send it to the validators for execution and give bank B the keys to decrypt the transaction payload/and chaincode state if they are given the ledger.

elli
2017-01-26 18:20
However execution of chaincode that takes place within a peer and if its infrastructure is properly secured no leakage should come from there.

oiakovlev
2017-01-26 18:26
Thanks. So to summarize this: 1. If A, B and C all are validators - they will see raw data anyway, right? 2. I understand that if peer is protected it will work - but the idea here, that A and B want to hide their transactions from C and C has also validating peer, so this means that technically C can read the data during transaction execution, right? And confusing thing here is that owning membership service I can grant correct users to A, B and C so as a client they will have limited access to sensitive data but owning a peer they actually have full access... right? For me logical might be following behavior: if peer can't decrypt the data for some reason it would say - I can't validate, I would not take part in consensus and as the data is not mine I don't care - I'll accept data from other peers... Also what I actually want is some sort of subledgers/chains which we'll have in v1, right?

elli
2017-01-26 18:34
In v0.6 we do not support confidentiality of contracts against validators. If A, or B, or C have validating peers, they will see the plaintext of all transactions advertised in the chain.

elli
2017-01-26 18:34
In v1.0 we move to an architecture that would allow for finer-grained of encryption-based confidentiality. However, this is not yet supported.

elli
2017-01-26 18:36
In v1.0 pairwise business logic can be supported at the level of two-party participant channel.

elli
2017-01-26 18:36
That is A, and B can have their own channel, and B, and C can have their own channel. All of them so far however need to trust orderers to see their transactions.

silliman
2017-01-26 19:09
@elli My understanding is that orderers are agnostic to the contents of the transaction, they are just ordering the transactions they receive..... so in normal operations would an orderer be seeing encrypted transaction contents? Of course I may be completely misunderstanding things!

elli
2017-01-26 19:11
If the content is encrypted, no they would not be able to.

elli
2017-01-26 19:11
But in v1.0 as of now we do not offer encryption-based confidentiality.

elli
2017-01-26 19:12
Hence you can protect your data of collaboration with organization X if yyou and X have a channel restricted only within the two of you. Because transactions in that channel are ordered through the orderers, the orderers would see the content of your transactions but not endorsers, e.g., belonging to other organizations outside your restricted channel.

silliman
2017-01-26 19:18
@elli thanks! so to make sure i've understood.... an orderer will serve multiple organizations, beyond the subset that are in your restricted chain... so if you have orgs A B C X Y Z in your network, even if X Y have their own "private" channel, the orderers service A B C X Y Z?

elli
2017-01-26 19:20
correct, and by "service offered by orderers" I mean "order transactions on behalf of different channels owned by a combination/any subset of A B C X Y Z".

silliman
2017-01-26 19:24
@elli Say in my example with 6 orgs, and suppose each org stood up their own orderer service. Do these orderers "talk amongst themselves" before settling on a batch to send back to the committers? I suppose they'd have to.

elli
2017-01-26 19:27
correct

elli
2017-01-26 19:27
the set of orderers need to jointly agree on the order of all transactions advertised in each channel

elli
2017-01-26 19:27
so they see all the transactions

silliman
2017-01-26 19:29
@elli got it! Thank you very much.

elli
2017-01-26 19:29
@silliman sure!

oiakovlev
2017-01-26 20:40
thanks @elli !

2017-01-26 20:58
has joined #fabric-crypto

sagmeister
2017-01-30 14:51
has joined #fabric-crypto

yuryandreev
2017-01-31 10:55
What is Attribute Certificate Authority in v 1.0? https://github.com/hyperledger-archives/fabric/wiki/Attribute-Certificate-Authority https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/docs/tech/attributes.md

ashutoshkumar
2017-01-31 13:26
we do not have concept of Attribute Certificate Authority in V1.0.

ashutoshkumar
2017-01-31 13:28
During TCert generation , user specifies which attributes it wants to include in TCert , query is being done on Database and attribute value is being populated

ashutoshkumar
2017-01-31 13:29
We do not have validity period for attributes whereas user can setup validity period of TCerts.
